54710	[Contexts] Renamed EnabledSubmission to ContextSubmission	"as people don't really like the word 'submission', how about this:EnableRequest (and in the commands API, HandleRequest)other options might be (but i prefer the above..):RequestToEnable, RequestToEnableContext.the API methods could change to addEnableRequests(..), etc?lemme know..p.s. i don't like ContextSubmission or variants, especially because of itsequivalent in the commands API: CommandSubmission is confusing, when I'm reallyrequesting a handler for a command. In the future there might need to be otherproperties of a command (or even context) contributed in this way, so i'd liketo leave the names more specific.  Too late, I think.  This is API now.  wontfix  The type EnabledSubmission would be better named ContextSubmission. Clients browsing for context-related APIs generally look for types named *context*. Since the name has no relation to contexts, it's difficult to remember. And lastly, the name is almost oxymoronic. While the API may say ""add"" and ""remove"" EnabledSubmissions, clients logically think of this as enabling and disabling the submissions. Just saying ""then we disable our EnabledSubmission"" makes my head hurt. :)I think it's cleaner to call them ContextSubmissions, because that's what clients are really doing - submitting a context. "	2013-03-17 09:59:10	1363530000.0	resolved fixed	06800eb	1363640000.0	java/org/apache/tomcat/websocket/pojo/PojoEndpointBase.java java/org/apache/tomcat/websocket/pojo/PojoMessageHandlerBase.java java/org/apache/tomcat/websocket/pojo/PojoMessageHandlerPartialBase.java java/org/apache/tomcat/websocket/pojo/PojoMessageHandlerPartialBinary.java java/org/apache/tomcat/websocket/pojo/PojoMessageHandlerPartialText.java java/org/apache/tomcat/websocket/pojo/PojoMessageHandlerWholeBase.java java/org/apache/tomcat/websocket/pojo/PojoMessageHandlerWholeBinary.java java/org/apache/tomcat/websocket/pojo/PojoMessageHandlerWholePong.java java/org/apache/tomcat/websocket/pojo/PojoMessageHandlerWholeText.java java/org/apache/tomcat/websocket/pojo/PojoMethodMapping.java
54709	[ContextMgmt] Enhance ContextManagerEvent	"I propose the following API for ContextManagerEvent. These are the methods I'd like the event to have (no more and no less).   getContextManager()   submissionAdded(String contextId)   submissionRemoved(String contextId)   contextEnabled(String contextId)   contextDisabled(String contextId)   contextDefined(String contextId)We in debugland want to know when submissions are added in order to promote views. It's important that we hear about submissions, not just enablement. A context will stay enabled for the life of a debug session, but we want to react when the user's selection switches between enabled contexts. Telling us when submissions are added is basically a way for us to know which context is the ""most active."" The story we want to implement in debug land is:Responding to context changes:1. When a debugging context is enabled, actions bound to that context appear (the workbench gives us this for free).2. When a debugging context is submitted, views bound to that context appear (our code).3. When a debugging context is disabled, actions bound to that context disappear (the workbench gives us this for free).4. When a debugging context is disabled, views bound to that context and no other active context are closed (our code).Activating contexts:1. When an element in the Debug view is selected (and the element provides the right adapter), we submit a context request.2. We keep a mapping of launches to the context requests they've submitted. A launch won't maintain more than one submission per context id. If it tries (say, by selecting multiple stack frames), a new request will be submitted and then the old one will be removed.3. When a launch terminates, all context submissions from that launch are removed. Since the IWorkbenchContextSupport API supports adding and removing multiple submissions at once, the methods I'm proposing should actually be plural. submissionsAdded(String[] contextIds), contextsEnabled(String[] contextIds), etc. I've got a first cut of this up and running in my workspace. Created attachment 8625org.eclipse.ui.workbench.20040316.patchHere's a patch with an initial implementation of the requested API. I've alsorewritten our client to use this new API and everything appears peachy at thispoint. I wouldn't feel comfortable calling this shippable until I've tested itsome more, but I figured I'd share what I've got so far. Created attachment 8678org.eclipse.ui.workbench.20040318.patchPlease consider the attached patch for submission to the workbench.I have our client code rewritten to use this new API and it is sufficient forour needs. Created attachment 8714org.eclipse.ui.workbench.20040319.patchChanges have been released to the project. This new patch is based on thecurrent HEAD stream contents. Created attachment 8757org.eclipse.ui.workbench.20040322.patchAfter talking with Doug on IRC, we decided to remove the idea of submissionnotifications. It represents a big change to the way contexts work that the UIteam doesn't want to make right now.Instead of using the submission notification, the Debug View now directlyinforms its context listener in cases where a submission event would have beenreceived. MVM has asked me to apply this patch for I200403300800.  The patch has been committed to CVS with two minor changes: 1.) The old methods on ContextManagerEvent are still supported (kind of) with deprecated warnings.  They will be removed before M9 ships. 2.) The ""toArray"" methods are passed arrays of the correct size (to avoid unnecessary object creation).  reopening this bug.1. the change returns String[]. did anyone notice that *all* of the othercontext, commands, or activity apis return collections instead of arrays?2. the change creates unnecessary asymmetry withing its own class:where is the getUndefinedContextIds() method?3. the change creates unnecessary asymmetry across other api's: where's theequivalent changes to CommandManagerEvent? ActivityManagerEvent?4. @deprecating the boolean methods is not correct. all of the other eventclasses across contexts, commands, and activities use this model to indicatechange. i don't want to have to check (enabled.isEmpty() && disabled.isEmpty())just to know if there was change to the overall set of enabled contexts. (orcommands.. or activities..)5. i can go fix this myself, but debug can expect to break due to my fix forpoint #1 above. i'd really rather these methods not have been added at all. imade a case on platform-ui-dev why i didn't think they were necessary andhaven't been given a valid use case in response. i've copied the originalrequest, and my reply below. sometimes there are good reasons why i would ask aclient (like debug) to do a couple of lines of calculations themselves.(see points #3 and #4 below)>The current ContextManagerEvents don't provide enough information for>our needs. In terms of the current API, I want to be able to register a>listener that's told every time someone adds an EnabledSubmission to the>workbench and everytime a context enables or disables. I also need to>know which contextId is involved.>>I think the ContextManagerEvent should have the following methods:>  getContextManager()>  submissionAdded(String contextId)>  submissionRemoved(String contextId)>  contextEnabled(String contextId)>  contextDisabled(String contextId)>  contextDefined(String contextId)>>An example execution flow:>1. ClientA submits contextA -  submissionAdded(contextA)>2. contextA becomes enabled - contextActivated(contextA)>3. ClientB submits contextA - submissionAdded(contextA)>4. ClientA removes contextA - submissionRemoved(contextA)>5. ClientB removes contextA - submissionRemoved(contextA)>6. contextB becomes disabled - contextDisabled(contextA)1. ContextManagerEvent does provide the method getContextManager().2. Regarding submissionAdded and submissionRemoved, why would you want to trackthis information? The submissions themselves aren't important, only the actualenabled contexts are. In fact, if someone submits a request to enabled a contextfor a particular part and that part isn't active at that time, theContextManager is not affected at all. Also, the ContextManager knows nothingabout the EnabledSubmission class, it only cares what contexts are actuallyenabled, so if you really needed this for some reason, the listener methods (anda new event object) would have to go someplace else, like on ICommandSupport.3. ContextManagerEvents are broadcast when the set of enabled contexts changesor the set of defined contexts changes (and tells you why it broadcast theevent). It doesn't tell you the specific deltas in the event, but you could keeptrack of that yourself with Set operations: i.e. Set newlyEnabledContexts = newHashSet(contextManager.getEnabledContextIds()).removeAll(previouslyEnabledContexts);If you would like the actual deltas included for you as well, please file anenhancement request and prefix [ContextMgmt] to the summary.4. ContextEvents are broadcast when a specific context is enabled/disabled ordefined/undefined, so you can watch individual contexts easily:i.e. IContextManager.getContext(""debugging.java"").addContextListener(..); The String[] to Collection change is no problem. If you release the changes to HEAD, I'll just fix up our code. I thought I'd already addressed your concerns either on the mailing list or the phone, but maybe I just *thought* of my answers and forgot to actually give them to you. :)#3 - ""Do it yourself""My argument here is that it's not a client's job to keep track of a manager's state. That's what the manager is for.#4 - ""Listen to contexts""The problem with this is that you hear about the activations in sequence. Our support allows clients to map multiple contexts to an element and the submission API allows for multiple submissions to be enabled at once. If multiple contexts are activated at the same time, I want to know about it.Hearing about them in sequence would introduce UI instability on my end. i understand your point about #4, though i disagree with point #3. asking formore information from an event is a common api sticky-point. that being said, ihave made the following changes:to ContextManagerEvent I have added two methods:Set getPreviouslyDefinedContextIds()Set getPreviouslyEnabledContextIds()to CommandsManagerEvent I have added three methods:Set getPreviouslyDefinedCategoryIds()Set getPreviouslyDefinedCommandIds()Set getPreviouslyDefinedKeyConfigurationIds()to ActivityManagerEvent *should* be added three methods:Set getPreviouslyDefinedCategoryIds()Set getPreviouslyDefinedContextIds()Set getPreviouslyEnabledContextIds()this introduces the idea that the events from managers should consistently passalong their previous states for the convenience of clients. (ICommandManageractually has a lot more properties that it could provide previous states for,but for now i started with the three properties that return Collections)the compromise is this: you no longer need to keep track of any state, but youdo need to do the set math yourself if you are interested in findingdifferences. i.e.Set getNewlyAddedEnabledContextIds(ContextManagerEvent contextManagerEvent) {    return newHashSet(contextManagerEvent.getContextManager().getEnabledContextIds()).removeAll(contextManagerEvent.getPreviouslyEnabledContextIds());}Set getNewlyRemovedEnabledContextIds(ContextManagerEvent contextManagerEvent) {    return newHashSet(contextManagerEvent.getPreviouslyEnabledContextIds()).removeAll(contextManagerEvent.getContextManager().getEnabledContextIds());}i don't want to add these convenience methods to the event classes right nowbecause of method bloat. i plan on checking these changes into head within the next half hour. ps. those changes were put into head already. i'm only leaving this open toremind me to do the activity event changes.. Doug, could you look into the Activity event changes? ActivityManagerEvent changes are in CVS.  Verified that the API exists in I200405190010, but not whether it works. 54702	Provide a way to block unused imports from being merged in	"If you tailor a generated file in such a way that certain imports are no longer required, and you remove those imports, each subsequent regen will bring them back.  It sould be nice to have a way to block those imports from showing up.We'll add support so that a pattern like this in the emf-merge.xml:  noImport=""\s*//\s*no\s+import\s+([\w.*]*)\s*;\s*\n""can be specified and will have the effect that any import comments matching that pattern will block the matching import from being merged, e.g., instead of deleting an import introduced by the generator, you can comment it out like this:// no import org.eclipse.emf.ecore.provider.EcoreEditPlugin;And then it won't come back. We'll simply the pattern to this noImport=""\s*//\s*import\s+([\w.*]*)\s*;\s*\n""so that you only have to do this:// import org.eclipse.emf.ecore.provider.EcoreEditPlugin; The fix is available in the latest 2.0 integration driver. 54660	"""Rebuild project"" entry in project context menu"	"In the package explorer, in the context menu of a project, there should be a ""Rebuild project"" entry. We tried hard to come up with context menus that are not too large. The rules we used are:- action with prominent short cuts are not part of the context menu- action executed not so often aren't in the context menu either.Since rebuild project isn't a frequent action it is only available via the global Project menu. This surprises me since I use ""Rebuild project"" very often. So do my collegues who encouraged me to send this report.Plus there is no shortcut set for it by default. Why do you need Rebuild project so often. Eclipse incremental builder shouldn't require losts of full rebuilds. It often happened when we had to import and re-compile old projects developed on other IDEs, for example.In any way, I think that the context menu of a project should contain all direct project operations.In Java, you expect a class Project to have an object method rebuild() so that you can write ""project.rebuild();"" instead of having a static method rebuild(Project p) and writing ""rebuild(project);"". This might be a metaphore for the difference between context menus and application menus. That's the reason why build is in the context menu. 54536	[Content Assist] Completion list presented inappropriately for dynamic_cast statement.	"Test Configuration:   Eclipse 3.0 M7 (ID: 200403040800)   CDT 2.0.0.200403040925   Windows 2003 ServerTest Case:1. Create a managed make C++ project, call it MgdCpp (for example).2. Add a new file, call it main.cpp.3. Insert the following code into main.cpp:	class C {	  public:	    int i;	    int j;	    int k;	};	class B {	  public:	    bool b;	    bool b2;	};		class A : public B, protected C {	  public:	    float f;	    float f2;	};		void foo(A* a)	{	    dynamic_cast<B*>(a)->b=false; // Ok	    dynamic_cast<C*>(a)->[^SPC];  // Should not work as C is protected	}Result: A completion list is presented to the user containing ""i"", ""j"", and ""k"".Expected: ""No completions available"" error message as 'C' is an inaccessiblebase of 'A'.* Also tested on Windows XP Dynamic cast has different rules for visibility than normal casts.  CompleteParseASTFactory needs to be updated.   foo() could be called with another subclass of A which does publicly (or virtually) inherit from C.  we do not know if the runtime cast is going to succeed or fail for all uses unless we look at all of the references to foo() and see what parameters are being passed in.  if 'a' was (instead of a parameter) an object that we knew the absolute type for, then we could make that call.  However, in my opinion, the behaviour we give at this point is correct, as if I was attempting to dereference a dynamic_cast<>, I would have to be pretty sure the cast would succeed.  Regardless, I'll let Dave rule on whether or not its a requirement to take this further.  The symbol table currently doesn't differentiate between 'absolute' and 'expected' types, so we would have to have some heuristic along the lines of ""if the parameter is pointing at a variable and not a parameter"".   This is a minor problem.   It is not worth any effort to fix.  (I would place this as a P4...) Actually, the expression 'dynamic_cast<C*>(a)' is a compile error:../tmp.cpp: In function `void foo(A*)':../tmp.cpp:23: error: `C' is an inaccessible base of `A'All bets are off if you are trying to complete code that has a compile error. "	2013-02-07 12:33:41	1360260000.0	resolved fixed	ef9ed07	1360700000.0	java/org/apache/catalina/valves/ErrorReportValve.java test/org/apache/catalina/valves/TestErrorReportValve.java

Tod, how is arbitration done when multiple label decorators want to setcolors/font? Is it just random which one is used? I think there should be somesort of defined prioritization or ""merging"" of colors, such that we can ensurethat e.g. error color is always more important than team color.Note that the old decoration types allows multiple decorations for the sameelement: text can only be added, but not replaced; images should only be smalloverlays and let the rest of the icon alone. We don't intend to change the suffix/prefix addition algorithm - replacing the text was not something people wanted to happen whenthey had no control over it due to a contributed decorator from another plug-in.If there is conflict between the decorator and the font or color provider of the viewer the decorator takes precedent. If two decorators are trying to do the same thing or decorate the same quadrant we do not currently do any conflict resolution. See Bug 36007 BTW you could add a color or font provider to the packages view and then allow the CVS decorator to override it when they are on as the decorator takes precedence. Closing are there is nothing else to do on our part. Verified that our support is in M3 (thanks for moving it back - I missed it in my test pass). Actually label decorations for warning/errors/cvs conflicts are only represented by a small icon or a "">"" sign. Sometimes it's really difficult to see such small labels, expecially if you have more decorations.Allowing users to select a backgroung/foreground color for labels will really improve user experience.A similar feature is currently implemented in instantiations codepro, but only using custom views (they call them package explorer+, resources+). It sound strange to reimplement views only to add a (also if useful) background color... it would be really great to have a support for this feature available in the base UI framework, so that could be used in any view.This is a screeshot from codepro colored view:http://www.instantiations.com/codepro/ws/docs/images/package_explorer_plus_view.gifAnd the preference page where users can choose colors:http://www.instantiations.com/codepro/ws/docs/images/preferences_browsers.gifThis would be a nice addiction in the new [workbench]->[colors and fonts] preference page just added with the new look'n feel. I'm all for nice addictions <g>. Actually, once the ILightweight decorator implements IColorProvider and IFontProvider we could possibly allow customization of these for the CVS decorator. Until then, since our decorator is an ILightWeightDecorator, we can't do anything about it. We won't be doing this in the 3.0 timeframe. Marking later Reopening now that 3.0 has shipped Related to Bug 61869 This is actually not that hard.We would need to change IDecoration to also allow colours but as no one is meant to implement that this would not be a breaking change.Likewise IDecoratorManager could add a getColorProvider method and a getFontProvider method which would not break anyone.Jean-Michel is this something you would do in the 3.1 timeframe? 54476	[KeyBindings] User needs access to multiple configurations	"The workbench should support multiple, orthogonal keybinding configurations. For example, for a WYSIWYG HTML editor (or any other non-source editor), ""emacs"" configuration makes no sense.  They would instead want to define configurations for other HTML keybindings, such as ""FrontPage"", ""DreamWeaver"", etc.  The user should be able to activate simultaneously the ""emacs"" mode for the Java editor, and the ""frontpage"" mode for the html editor. This is interesting, but complicated.  It is also a fair departure from tools such as Microsoft Visual Studio.  Arguably, contexts provide a similar mechanism, but without the same ease in configuration (i.e., you would have to define key configurations -- e.g., ""Emacs Text / DreamWeaver HTML"" or ""Eclipse Text / Emacs HTML"").  It might be possible to make the argument that Emacs key bindings do make sense for an HTML editor.  I'm not a fan of them myself, but Emacs does have HTML plug-ins which do define additional key bindings (google: html-helper-mode).   Doug, ""E-macs"" keybindings don't make sense for a WYSIWYG HTML editor.  Maybe ""Frontpage"" or ""Dreamweaver"" might make sense instead, which is why I opened this bug.  If I had been talking about an HTML *source* editor, then I would agree that e-macs could be activated for the source view, while frontpage might be activated for the ""design"" view (wysiwyg).I know that a possible implementation might use contexts, but it doesn't change the problem with the UI presentation in the keybindings preference page. I currently use Emacs mode in Eclipse for both code and HTML.  I cannot fathomwhy the poster asserts that emacs keybindings make no sense for documents otherthan code.  It's ironic that I stumbled on this request while searching for a set of Emacskey bindings for Dreamweaver... (In reply to comment #3)> I currently use Emacs mode in Eclipse for both code and HTML.Really, which HTML editor are you using? Reassigning to Platform-UI-Inbox (I left IBM 18 months ago..) Moving Dougs bugs Is this still a problem in 3.3?PW yes. bug 154130 should refer to this. There's no plans in bug 154130 to address mutliple co-existing schemes.PW (In reply to comment #9)> There's no plans in bug 154130 to address mutliple co-existing schemes.that's why I said ""should"". Eclipse is an ""extensible IDE for anything"", which means more than just source editing. This bug hasn't had any activity in quite some time. Maybe the problem got resolved, was a duplicate of something else, or became less pressing for some reason - or maybe it's still relevant but just hasn't been looked at yet.If you have further information on the current state of the bug, please add it. The information can be, for example, that the problem still occurs, that you still want the feature, that more information is needed, or that the bug is (for whatever reason) no longer relevant. Maybe the problem got resolved, was a duplicate of something else, or became less pressing for some reason - or maybe it's still relevant but just hasn't been looked at yet. 54466	ant formatter preference page should include preview window	"The preference page for the ant formatter should allow users to see the effectof various formatting options in a pane which includes a short sample buildfile. c.f JDT. We should just be able to reuse the code I have done for the Ant editor syntax tab and its previewer. John-Mason, do you have the time to whip up a sample buildfile that I could use as the preview code for this? Sure. One idea about the preview window: you may want to set a max line length at something small ( < 30 ? < 40 ?) for the sake of the preview window since it is so much smaller than the normal editor area. Example code for this is in the test for the new API stuff I submitted last night.This is a cheesy example but it touches most everything the formatter handles. I may be able to dream up a prettier example with some more thought.----<?xml version=""1.0"" encoding=""UTF-8""?><project name=""create-buildfile"" default=""build"">	<!-- - - - - - - - - - - - - - -->	<!-- target: build             -->	<!-- - - - - - - - - - - - - - -->	<target name=""build"" description=""Display a valid buildfile which greets the user with the value of ${favoriteGreeting}."">		<echo>The following is a valid ant buildfile:</echo>		<property name=""favoriteGreeting"" value=""buenos dias""/>		<xml-greeting greeting-text=""${favoriteGreeting}""/>	</target>	<!-- - - - - - - - - - - - - - -->	<!-- macrodef: xml-greeting    -->	<!-- - - - - - - - - - - - - - -->	<macrodef name=""xml-greeting"" description=""This macrodef echos a hello world buildfile to stdout."">		<attribute name=""greeting-text"" default=""hello world"" />				<sequential>			<echo>					<![CDATA[<?xml version=""1.0"" encoding=""UTF-8""?><project default=""greeting"">	<target name=""default"">		<echo>@{greeting-text}</echo>	</target></project>]]>			</echo>		</sequential>	</macrodef></project> unfortunately this code seems to expose a bug in the formatter :-)The echo after the CDATA is not formatter correctly. Wouldn't you know it. :$ I don't have my ant workspace with the new CDATA code here at work so I'll fix this from home tonight. Obviously I should have written a testcase for this. I guess I have now. ;) Logged as bug 62569. 54450	requestInUI seems to have a race condition (fails most times)	"I'm trying to exercise the job API that lets me query the user via a UI job and the requestInUI call.  I get no Status back from the call unless I step through the logic in the debugger.  Only then do I get a non-null return from the method.This is my logic:   private boolean askUserForHelp() {      UIJob uiJob = new UIJob(""Help Request"") {         public IStatus runInUIThread(IProgressMonitor monitor) {            if (MessageDialog.openQuestion(PlatformUI.getWorkbench()                  .getActiveWorkbenchWindow().getShell(), ""Choose"",                  ""Should we run the runnable?""))               return Status.OK_STATUS;            else               return Status.CANCEL_STATUS;         }      };      IProgressService ps = PlatformUI.getWorkbench().getProgressService();             IStatus choice = ps.requestInUI(uiJob, ""Help Me"" + getName());      if (choice.getCode() == 0)         return true;      else         return false;   }The job I have processes some work and then does more (a runnable passed to the job for fun).  I'm trying to make that 2nd bit of work optional based on the user prompt.  This works only if I step through the logic, deep down into feedbackManager.requestInUI(job, message) where it sets up another UIJob and then uses a join() to wait on the response.Not sure if it is because of the async job execution (Something I had not noticed before on my API tour), or what.  Another observation is that it seemed like the inUI request was not removed from the prompt dialog.The general purpose Errors Running Jobs dialog gets opened, but it is not helping identify what exception is thrown (I'm wondering if this dialog actually shows enough information, even when you open details it is redundantly showing the same thing twice - and little specific info that I can find a way to influence so far). I have to go to the error log to see that it is a NullPointerException; this is due to the fact my choice var above is null after the requestInUI call.An aside; I got the impression from EclipseCON that this user request would be a hint to see what was needed vs a dialog that opened on top of their current work.  Is this prompt technique still under development or finalized?I've been running my code on both M7 and I20040310. Any UI job is executed asynronously in the UI Thread - this is a requirement of it.The purpose of this API is to stop the current process pending the result of a UI Job that you are requesting execution on. The requestInUI brings up the dialog to deal with the request and when the user runs the job you continue.I am not sure what the problem is here. Could you be more specific as to what you think is wrong? When I use the api and just let it run an exception is thown.  If I run in debug with breakpoints I can step through the lower layer logic that uses the passed UIJob to ask the question and I actually get the result back in the API call.  When it runs free the result is null.  (this is from memory - I'll try and work up my exact error again later). As I understand the API I can do the following:// JDG2E: 2D2 Get progress service and run the UIJobIProgressService ps = PlatformUI.getWorkbench() .getProgressService();IStatus choice = ps.requestInUI(uiJob,  ""Job needs help deciding what to do next."" + "" Job: "" + getName());The above has a uijob that opens a yes/no dialog.  The response create an IStatus returned at the completion of the uijob, which I expect to get in the choice IStatus above.  The result of running the code above returns a null IStatus value in choice.If I follow the requestInUI code a bit I find that the problem is down in ProgressFeedbackManager.requestInUI():-------openProgressJob.schedule();  try{    job.join();  }  catch (InterruptedException exception){    return ProgressManagerUtil.exceptionStatus(exception);  }		return statuses[0];-------The schedule above is a uijob to open the dialog that will list the uijob I provided on my call to IProgressService.requestInUI().The join is on my passed uijob.  But as my uijob does not get scheduled until it is selected in the ""Jobs Awaiting Progress"" dialog, the join does not wait; instead it returns and a null status is returned.  The null status triggers an exception later (as I did not check for null).I guess I could join on my own uijob, but that was not required per my reading of the IProgressService.requestInUI spec. This was due to a faulty blocking algorithm which effectively never blocked.I beleive this fixes your cases but as they are quite thorough I would like to go through them all before I close this.Thanks for your help Pat - that simple example at the end really helped me get to the root of the problem right away. Adding John for some advice. I'm tempted to suggest pulling this API for 3.0.  We are not using it in theSDK. Jean-Michel tried it and found some improvements that would be needed tomake it truly useful (bug 50044). To fix this particular bug, we would need tospec more clearly how long the caller is blocked (if at all). If the user closesthe request dialog, what happens (think of how many people ignore the WindowsUpdate prompts)?  It currently doesn't work because the call to job.join() will not block if thejob has not yet been scheduled. It would instead have to wait on a flag that isset in the JobChangeListener's done() method. I think this API is a great idea, but needs a bit more work (and some referenceimplementations) to make it real. Sounds like something for 3.1 at this point. That is probably fine, users of this API would be advanced users of the Job capability, and that will be a learning/growth curve for all.I'm not sure who else you should ask first - just in case some have thought about possible scenarios where this api would be useful.  I know from soft questions that some of the teams down my way are starting to 'wake up' to the possibilities provided by the Jobs API. This API has been  deferred to 3.1 Reopening now that 3.0 has shipped Closing this as adding anything else is not currently planned. 54387	[Navigator] Provide ability for users to add filters to base UI Navigator view interface	"Problem/Feature Request:In the base Navigator view (e.g. as in Resources perspective) there is no way for the casual user to add their own filters.Workaround/Warning:As an unofficial ""workaround"", you can edit {WebSphere Studio Install Dir}\eclipse\plugins\org.eclipse.ui_2.1.1\plugin.xml   ...   <extension         point=""org.eclipse.ui.resourceFilters"">      <filter            selected=""false""            pattern="".*"">                  </filter>      <filter            selected=""false""            pattern=""EJS*"">      </filter>         </extension>...to add a filter in the base workbench/eclipse Navigator View. In this case I added the ""EJS*"" filter. It works, but is not officially supported. You can use this at you own discretion. However any core workbench problems reported with any such change present are not be supported. At the current time, the only sanctioned way to add a filter to the Navigator view, is  to create separate plugin and contribute the filters instead of modifying an existing product plugin. The UI is a separate plug-in in core Eclipse which happens to own this base Navigator view. WebSphere Studio Workbench or Eclipse development does not support any modification to the base. The UI plug-in is part of that base. Example:In WSAD v5.x there is a large set of filters in the base Navigator view. The various plug-ins added these through a plug-in api()...etc. The good news is that apart from thissanctioned mechanism to add filters to the base Navigator view, adding a filter to the plugi-in.xml file of the UI file will ony affect the Navigator view. This change does not carry over to say the Explorer Package view of the Java perspective or the Project Navigator of the J2EE Perspective. Similarly any change to filters in a custom Navigator, such as adding a filter in the J2EE Project Navigator, will not show up in the base Navigator view. There is  a clean and logical separation of concerns in the design.Clearly, writing a plug-in is not an option for many users or an activity they may wish to invest time in to just a filter(s). Our customers raised the need to be able to add filters to the base Navigator for general use across all perspectives. This basic add filter capabilityis present in base Navigators of other IDE technologies.I have create this eclipse bugzilla defect/feature request to provide a add/remove user filters capabilty in the UI Navigator GUI (e.g. an add filter button at minimum,and maybe a remove button restricted to filters not associated with a plug-in). Thanks, Bob D *** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 1970 *** "	2013-01-08 12:58:37	1357670000.0	resolved fixed	334c466	1357820000.0	java/org/apache/catalina/deploy/WebXml.java test/org/apache/catalina/deploy/TestWebXml.java

54381	(Plat) Cumulative time as reported by the profiler is larger than time reported by the program	"Consider the following test scenario:----Purpose:	Tests console input and output and times collected.Instructions:1. Start workbench2. Launch (locally/remotely) InOut3. Enter text strings with length at least four characters and containing atleast one blank, when prompted in the Trace Console4. Verify that the text strings that are printed following the lines ""Stringread in :"" are the same as the strings that were entered.5. Open the Method Statistics view and verify that the Cumulative Time for theInOut.main() method is slightly greater than (less than 200 milliseconds) theelapsed time value printed in the Trace Console.---The difference between the Cumulative time in the method statistics view and thecumulative time printed in the trace console is much larger than 200ms. In my run, the time in the console was 55.292 sec, and the cumulative timereported in the method stats view for the main() method is about 57.736sec. Created attachment 8475the class used for testing targetting future instead of M10 since this bug doesn't always happen.  This problem is particularly prevalent on AIX.  Rob, this should have been fixed.  Can you verify and close as appropriate?  Thanks. The problem still exists on AIX. The problem seems to be related to the ad-hoc way that the piAgent determinesthe _ticksPerMicrosecond value, which is then used for converting the ""timestampin ticks"" to a wall-clock time. The AIX Technical Reference(http://www.ncsa.uiuc.edu/UserInfo/Resources/Hardware/IBMp690/IBM/usr/share/man/info/en_US/a_doc_lib/libs/basetrf2/read_real_time.htm)indicates that the way the value obtained from read_real_time() should beconverted is by using time_base_to_time(). It's not possible to do this the way the code is currently structured, but I didsome hacking (not for check in -- just to run some tests) and found that if weuse the time_base_to_time() method for converting the high-precision time into awall-clock time, the problem reported in this bug goes away. As a proper fix, we should consider scrapping the code that determines_ticksPerMicrosecond (on the platforms where possible) and using other API'sprovided by the platform which probably yield more accurate results.  Ran some more tests, and I'm convinced that the problem is that we'reunderestimating the _ticksPerMicrosecond value. Suppose we calculate the _ticksPerMicrosecond to be 5, but the actual value is 10. If we observe 10 ticks having elapsed, then we will calculate that as 2microseconds real-time having elapsed, but in reality it will only have been 1microsecond. If we observe 40 ticks having elapsed, then we will calculate thatas 8 microseconds real-time having elapsed, but in reality it will only havebeen 4 microseconds. The longer the program runs, the larger the differencebetween the time we measure, and the actual time that has elapsed. However, theratio between the time we calculate and the time in reality will be constant(e.g. we calculate 2 microseconds, but only 1 microsecond has elapsed: 2:1ratio; we calculate 8 microseconds, but reality 4 microseconds has elapsed:again 2:1 ratio). I generated to following table as evidence of this from a number of tests (thiswas using the InOut test case as specified in the original description of thisdefect):Cumulative time as         Cumulative time as                A/Breported by Hyades         reported by console (A)                         (B)20.129009	           19.293		             1.043332245.719063                  43.86                             1.0423863171.577636                 164.683                           1.0418661220.597418                 211.745		             1.0418069Notice that the longer the program executes, the larger the discrepancy betweenthe time we calculate as having elapsed and the actual time that has elapsed.Moreover, the ratio between these two values (the third column) is roughlyconstant. This indicates that we are consistently underestimating the_ticksPerMicrosecond value.  Deferred (with other normal+P3 defects) from 4.1 due to resource constraint. As per today's data collection call: defer normal defects to 4.3 Not containable in 4.3 and retargetting to 4.4 as per Oct 26 Platform Collection & Communication Meeting. This was of major or lower sev and never made the cut for a specific iteration over the life of 4.3. cleaning up assignees As of TPTP 4.6.0, TPTP is in maintenance mode and focusing on improving quality by resolving relevant defects and increasing test coverage through test creation, automation, Build Verification Tests (BVTs), and expanded run-time execution. Since this defect is more than 2 years old, it may be no longer relevant. As part of the TPTP Bugzilla housecleaning process (see http://wiki.eclipse.org/Bugzilla_Housecleaning_Processes), this defect is resolved as WONTFIX. If this defect is still relevant and reproducible in the latest TPTP release (http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/home/downloads/), please re-open. As of TPTP 4.6.0, TPTP is in maintenance mode and focusing on improving quality by resolving relevant enhancements/defects and increasing test coverage through test creation, automation, Build Verification Tests (BVTs), and expanded run-time execution. 54284	[Scalability] Search fails to give all declarations of a medium large project	Build 040304  RAM 512 (could only use 330)In Search, part of the scalability requirement, as a P1, is to search for all declarations named * of any type.   The workspace would have a large number of tokens in the scope.I took a project that had a total 738 .c, .cpp, .hpp and .h files. Please see me for the project.Steps:1) Load the project in Eclipse/CDT2) Bring up the Search C/C++ Dialog3) Credentials:Search For: Any elementLimit To: DeclarationsScope: Workspace4) Click on SearchIt could never finish it.  It seemed that after 30 minutes, Eclipse did not have enough memory to perform the operation.  It started at a reasonable pace believing it will finish in 7 minutes or so. But the search slowed down exponentially. It was at about 85% that CDT looked stuck. By cancelling the Search, Eclipse/CDT took 10 to do it.I am just reporting the fact that CDT can not handle such a search even though an experience developer will not do this as he will do a more specific search.  Should we discourage the use of * with a message or other UI indicators? We need to analyze what's happening here w/memoryI'll accept the defect for the time being Raised to P2 since it failed a test case (thus affecting pass rate) Mathieu, Can send me an email pointing me towards the project (unless its one you think I already have). This project does not build as it is, and is not setup whatsoever.  There are no include paths discovered (due to the build failures) and the compiler being used is Microsoft Visual C++.  That being said ... I didn't even try running this w/256 MB of RAM, I skipped right to the advanced steps. Running w/512M RAM: Indexing completes fine and then Search craps out @ 7119 matches (but only done 13%).  This took about 12 minutes.  Running w/1024M RAM: Indexing completes fine and then Search continues on for 45 minutes and completes w/a total of 28,625 matches.  While I agree that we can do better, markers are not free and at some point, irregardless of how much memory Search and the parser take up, a wildcard search will run out of memory on a large enough project.  We need to add a user preference which by limits wildcard search results from the dialog (to 1000, say), as this is generally a recipe for disaster, particularly when we search on Any Element.  I would even be alright with disallowing Search for *.  Even displaying this many search results in the Search View causes significant refresh problems. This cannot be fixed for 2.0, moving the defect off to 2.0.1 we shall address it there with our scalability review.   The really sad thing is that Searching takes almost 8 times as much time as Indexing.  I am positive that it would be faster to ignore the indexer results and parse the transitive closure calculation for these wildcard search cases.  Update in 2.0.1 : Indexing does not complete @ 256 MB of RAM. 512 MB RAM : Indexing completes in a couple of minutes.  Search takes 8 minutes to complete, reporting > 30,000 matches.   With Bogdan's latest fixes on the HEAD, Search takes 6 minutes.  Moving defect off to 2.1 for Indexer < 256MB work item.  W/Search using offsets, this is as best as we can do.  Search uses constant time and linear memory to the number of matches.  	2012-12-12 15:51:40	1355350000.0	resolved fixed	113c0bd	1357590000.0	java/org/apache/catalina/core/ApplicationContext.java java/org/apache/catalina/deploy/FilterDef.java java/org/apache/catalina/deploy/ServletDef.java test/org/apache/catalina/core/TestApplicationContext.java test/org/apache/catalina/deploy/TestFilterDef.java test/org/apache/catalina/deploy/TestServletDef.java

54207	j9 launcher plugin uses deprecated -bp: flag	"The -bp: flag for specifying bootclasspath entries has been deprecated for quite a long time.  The preferred flag is -Xbootclasspath.  The j9 launcher plugin uses -bp, and this causes warning messages to appear each time an app is launched. Created attachment 8445Patch to fix bugThis patch switches the j9 launcher from using the -bp: flag to using-Xbootclasspath:. Isn't this just a duplicate of bug 19406? Oh, I guess I forgot that I'd mentioned this earlier, sorry.  However, this patch I provided is probably better than the one in bug 19406 since I understand the plugin better now.  I would mark the other one as a dupe of this one, and use the patch here instead. BTW, I understand Photon is no longer supported.  Do we still support AIX for the Eclipse SDK?  If so, does it use J9 still? *** Bug 19406 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** David, looking at this patch, the fix uses the ""append to bootpath"" option. The launching infrastrucure now supports prepend, append, and ""replace"" bootpath options. Does J9 support ""-Xbootclasspath/p:"", ""-Xbootclasspath/a:"" and ""-Xbootclasspath:""? If so, we should add support as is done in StandardVMRunner.addBootClassPathArguments(...). Probably ""prepend"" is the correct approach.  I will look at the method you mentioned. The launcher needs to honor whatever the user specifies in the tab - i.e. the container that identifies the JRE (JRE_CONTAINER) represents the default bootpath. If they put something before the default bootpath, we prepend. If they add something after, we append (they can also do both at once). If they remove the default container, we specify an explicit bootpath. Created attachment 8541Improved patch to fix bugI fixed the bootclasspath to respect the various append and prepend options. Also fixed the debugging support, since J9 for the last 2 releases is usingstandard JDK debug options, instead of proprietary j9proxy.exe. Applied patch with small modification - the bootpath support has changed slightly to be less ""breaking"" for existing launch delegates. Changes to #addBootClassPathArguments(..) in JavaVMRunner. Marking as verified (David can let us know if it does not work). Will the update be posted on the below page?http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/index.cgi/%7Echeckout%7E/jdt-debug-home/plugins/org.eclipse.jdt.launching.j9/index.html It's there. 54143	Site editor: Added features should be published by default	"When adding features it is not intuitive that a context menu has to be run on each of the new features to make them visible for users. Who would add a feature without the intent to publish it??? Default behavior should be to publish new features. A wizard may make sense to ask if a new category should be created before publishing the features? *** Bug 54144 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Actually, there are valid cases where feature is added but not published. In complex feature hierarchies where features include other features, only the root features are published. Other are placed on the server but not surfaced in site.xml. Great. But unclear to 95% of feature writers, who don't have complex feature hierarchies, and who are just struggling to get one simple update site with one simple feature with one single plugin to work.Those with complex feature hierarchies should press the ""Advanced Options..."" button.  Or at least the UI should have an affordance to indicate that the user *does* need to explicitly publish the feature. Fixed.  All features visible in the redesigned site editor are published. It really depends what you are doing. If you are comparing to merge a lot of changes or compare often against the same branch/tag then you can simply remember the comparison and have it update automatically by having it added to the sync view. This can be useful, but as you mentioned, not all the time.The naming really depends on what you consider ""Synchronizing"" to mean. If you are comparing or merging to change local resources, IMHO, you can consider this a synchronization task.Next weeks I-build will fix this by providing a dialog by default, then optionally allowing you to remember it in the sync view. 53854	implement State#compare	Some questions, Jeff:- what is the comparison criteria? Bundle ids (longs)? Location? Symbolic namesand versions?- what level of comparison are you thinking of? Bundle presence/absence? Orshould we go deep and compare constraints and bundle description attributes?- regardless the answers for the questions above are, it seems to me that wedon't need any priveldged knowledge on the state implementation internals. So, Iwould suggest we could provide such method on the new StateHelper API instead. Agreed that we should not need internal knowledge.Not sure about the criteria.  Starting point is symbolic name and version.  The main usecase I am thinking of here is for commit().  There you need to know what things to installBundle() and uninstall().  YOu don't have control over the long id or the constraints.  Assuming the resolvers are the same you should end up with the same constraint setup after the commit.As for level of detail, perhaps as deep as can be represented in a delta?  Not really sure what that means.We have a new StateHelper API? About the new StateHelper API: I moved the non-essential methods inBundleDescription/State (and some internal convenience methods) such asgetUnsatisfiedConstraints and others to the StateHelper interface. Initially, Ithought of it as a class with static methods in theorg.eclipse.osgi.service.resolver package. But then we decided to provide itfrom PlatformAdmin#getStateHelper. I am still not happy with that - in 1stplace, because it should be a class with only static methods. 2nd, because itshould be made less prominent, maybe in a util package.About matching bundles in two states: in the commit scenario, the bundle idsseem to be the best choice, since one state was created from the other, so thebundle ids (for the common bundles) match. Using symbolic names is hard becausethey are not mandatory. What about locations? Are they mandatory/unique?BTW, since the PlatformAdmin and State implementations are tied together, weknow the internals of both states. Thus, we don't need compare as API for thecommit case. I know that there are others, but cannot remember... what are theother use cases? the other case is for things like update and PDE where they are allowing the user to explicitly configure the state.  They want to be able to iterate add/remove, resolve and may need to compare to show the user what they are about to do. So I change my mind... PDE/Update will be using the factory provided by thestate if they are willing to commit the changes later. In that case, theplatform admin knows the implementation for the state object provided. That(knowing the internal implementation) makes comparison using bundle ids simpleto implement. If a bundle has to be changed, State#update should be used, thuspreserving the bundle id.Any concerns if I follow this path? sounds good. Released to HEAD. Retrofitted PlatformAdmin#commit to use State#compare. Need towrite tests.  State#compare had its semantics changed to so the state taken as argument is thebase, and the target state is the one containing changes.Comparison can be done between arbitrary implementations, and is as simple as this:- changed state has a bundle (location is the key) that the base does notcontain: bundle has been ADDED - changed state does not have a bundle that the base does contain: bundle hasbeen REMOVED- both states have a bundle (again, location is the key) - the bundle will beseen as UPDATED only if State#updateBundle was called on the changed bundle.Otherwise they be deemed equal and not change will be reported (no smartin-depth comparisons here).Test cases added to org.eclipse.osgi.tests (StateComparisonTest). Implement State#compare. Spec is:/** * Returns a delta describing the differences between this state and the * given state. This state is taken as the base so the absence of a bundle * in the given state is reported as a deletion, etc. *  * @param state * @return */public StateChangeEvent compare(State state);BTW, it should return a StateDelta instead. 	2012-09-11 20:28:09	1347410000.0	resolved fixed	a3e0f09	1349030000.0	java/org/apache/naming/resources/BaseDirContext.java java/org/apache/naming/resources/FileDirContext.java java/org/apache/naming/resources/WARDirContext.java

53714	Search result tree may be a bit to precise	"I200403030818I did a search>write access>workspace on the local variable 'type' in the methodorg.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.ui.actions.ManageBreakpointActionDelegate#manageBreakpoint(),the result was (in the New Search view) :org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.ui.actions [...]+ ManageBreakpointActionDelegate  + manageBreakpoint(IEditorInput) : void (1 match)    + IType typeorg.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.ui.actions.ManageBreakpointActionDelegate#manageBreakpoint(IEditorInput)(1 match)I don't really care that the second match is in a local variable declaration,that doesn't give me any interresting information and break up the list ofmatches for the method. This is by designed. The local variable 'type' is initialized. This is considered a write access. If you put a field modification watchpoint on a field that is initialized, the debugger would stop at this breakpoint.OK to close? Indeed, initializations are write accesses. Gnaaaaa ...It looks like I was not clear in the explanation of the problem.I totaly agree that the local variable declarations are write access and have tobe displayed in the search results.My problem is in the how it's displayed, we currently get two element in theresult tree (when using the New Search view) : the method and the local variabledeclaration :  + manageBreakpoint(IEditorInput) : void (1 match)    + IType typeorg.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.ui.actions.ManageBreakpointActionDelegate#manageBreakpoint(IEditorInput)(1 match)I think that having one element for the method that contains the two matchesshould be enought :  + manageBreakpoint(IEditorInput) : void (2 matches)I don't think that having an extra leaf for the local type declaration gives anyinformation. Local variables are elements now, but it is a UI decision to render them in search result view or not. Maybe this could be an option, unclear ?Moving to UI. Well, I disagree, if we're currently showing the innermost element that we canassing a match to. If we're deciding to depart from that policy, we should allowgrouping on any level, basically. Luc, I can't find the class ManageBreakpointActionDelegate anymore.I tested it with searching for references to z. All matches are grouped directly below method foo.public class Z {	public void foo() {		Z z= null;		Z zz= z;		z= null;	}}Please reopen if you still see this. 53700	[MPE] [EditorMgmt] MultiPageEditorPart should be supported better by editor manager	"Eclipse Forms add support for multi-page editors where some pages are forms, but one or more pages are source editors.Here is the scenario that will represent a significant problem for PDE:Imagine a multi-page editor based on MultiPageEditorPart that has more than one source editor as tabs. Each source editor opens a different file in the project. Example: new PDE manifest editor will open plugin.xml, META-INF/MANIFEST.MF and build.properties in their corresponding tabs all the time.The same editor is registered for all three files - the only difference is thatdifferent pages are initially selected for each file.Imagine that you opened plugin.xml. Since there are source editors in MultiPageEditorPart, some have editor input for files opened by the editor itself (not by the user).Now imagine that while the editor is still open, you select 'build.properties' and open it as well.Today: a new instance of the multi-page editor is openedDesired behaviour: editor manager should detect that an instance of MultiPageEditorPart is opened and that one of its nested editors has the matching input. The editor should simply be brought to front (ideally, a suitable page should also be shown but we can think about it later).The UI team has all that is needed to achieve this behaviour - MultiPageEditorPart belongs to the UI team and it can do something like this:if (editorPart instanceof MultiPageEditorPart) {   MultiPageEditorPart multiEditor = (MultiPageEditorPart)editorPart;   for (int i=0; i<multiEditor.getEditorCount(); i++) {      IEditorPart nestedEditor = multiEditor.getEditor(i);      if (nestedEditor!=null) {         IEditorInput nestedInput=nestedEditor.getEditorInput();         // if the nested input matches the desired file to open,         // just activate the multi editor intead of creating a new instance.      }   }}I am marking this as major because it will be a serious usability issue for the incoming multi-source PDE editors. Dan, please look at this request and check if it will cause problems with your editors that extend MultiPageEditorPart. If you are for it, please add your vote - it is very important for PDE editors that handle multiple files. Marking this as an enhancement.  Just to get a feel for priority: how many people have complained about this besides Jeff?  Is this something that is needed for 3.0.x, 3.1 or beyond?   This will become a big problem as more and more people start creating plugins with the new format (i.e. with the OSGi manifest.mf file).  I can easily see people open the manifest.mf file (pde editor #1) and then, out of habit or curiosity, they would want to see what goes into the plugin.xml file(editor #2).  Bring in the build.properties file into the equation and now you have three editors open on the same file.  It has happened me a hundred times.So it's not of those only-Jeff scenarios (and believe me there exists several only-Jeff scenarios :-), it will be a common source of confusion as we move into 3.1 when users would have become more educated about the new runtime and PDE tooling will start ""promoting"" the creation of plug-ins with manifest.mf instead of labeling this option as ""for advanced users only"" as it is for 3.0. cc my good friend Jeff as I referenced his name several times in my previous comment and I don't like to talk about people behind their backs. Glad to see it was used accurately... ;-)  some points.- This should be a 3.1 issue.- The current situation is quite confusing and will only get worse- Other scenarios include any multi resource model objects (e.g., elements in the web space etc etc)- This may impact usecases in the logical to physical world (BTW, Wassim, you should likely talk to Jean-Michel about PDE as a use case for the logical-physical work) See also bug 74263.Note that the workbench proper currently has no knowledge aboutMultiPageEditorPart.  MultiPageEditorPart was designed to use public workbenchAPI as much as possible (there are some exceptions in that it needs to implementsite interfaces which are currently internal), and without the workbench havingto have special case support for it.  While we want to expand the support for nesting parts, this should be donethrough more general API rather than adding special case hacks forMultiPageEditorPart. >I can easily see people open the manifest.mf file (pde editor #1) and then, >out of habit or curiosity, they would want to see what goes into the >plugin.xml file(editor #2).  Bring in the build.properties file into the >equation and now you have three editors open on the same file.  It has >happened me a hundred timesI don't see what the problem is.  These three editors should be sharing the same in-memory document.  What is the difference to the user if a file is opened as a page in a multi-page editor, or as a new editor?  The only difference should be where the Tab appears which allows you to switch to that file.How is the proposed change going to address multiple WorkbenchWindows?  If I do the above steps, but I open each file in a different WorkbenchWindow, then you still have the same problem that a file will be edited by 3 different editors.  The live document must be shared across editors anyway, so that makes this proposal not so critical. See bug 64763 comments 6 and 7. Moving Dougs bugs As per http://wiki.eclipse.org/Platform_UI/Bug_Triage_Change_2009 Remy is now responsible for watching the [EditorMgmt] component area. This bug hasn't had any activity in quite some time. Maybe the problem got resolved, was a duplicate of something else, or became less pressing for some reason - or maybe it's still relevant but just hasn't been looked at yet.If you have further information on the current state of the bug, please add it. The information can be, for example, that the problem still occurs, that you still want the feature, that more information is needed, or that the bug is (for whatever reason) no longer relevant. 53541	F: Provide extensible and more flexible filtering in navigators	"Valentina, please assign to me.Currently, the filtering in the Hyades navigators is hardcoded. A common mechanism for all Hyades navigators should be provided. This will be done via an extension point element <filterSet .../> under the <navigatorExtensions .../> extension point. This extension specify a label, icon, navigatorID, implementation, and will allow filters to be declared as common, which means they appear directly in the navigator view's menu, and whether the filter set is enabled by default.This functionality will be placed at the INavigator level, and will apply to all Hyades navigators. Content providers will be wrapped in a FilteredTreeContentProvider, which will consult all filterSet extensions and take care of the filtering.The interface should also be updated to comply with the Hyades UI guidelines. Filters should also be general, and can include a broad category of items (hence the name filter set), rather than a single item type (e.g. Monitor). Curtis please check if the Working Set/Filters approach is more appropiate here instead of a Hyades custom Filter Set. Just to follow the current Eclipse way (see Package and Navigator views). Working sets apply only to specific (existing) items, rather than general categories of items, or types of items. This can be added in the future. Will consult with Wayne about this and open a separate defect if needed.As far as filtering, there is no standard ""Filters..."" item for navigators, or filters dialog. What Eclipse provides is a ViewerFilter, which works at the Viewer level. The Navigator and Package Explorer have their own extension points, Filters menus and dialogs, and use ViewerFilters. We will have to do the same. However, ViewerFilters make it somewhat complicated to filter out an item without filtering out its children. Investigating further.. Curt, we already have a set of profiling set ecxtension points, make sure that your new extension point name doesn't collide with what we have. Finished. Closing bug. house keeping "	2012-07-12 18:16:08	1342130000.0	resolved fixed	432bd0f	1344630000.0	java/org/apache/naming/resources/VirtualDirContext.java

Needs to be tracked down. Found the bug. Steps to reproduce involve (but are not so easy):- have custom background (or foreground color) in Java editor- move or rename the document in a way that the caret gets moved by the rename  and that this causes horizontal or vertical scrollingThe bug is as follows: in cases where the editor gets reused (e.g. if reuse isenabled or a file gets renamed or moved) we call unconfigure() and configure()on the viewer. We dispose the text widget's foreground and background colors inJavaSourceViewer.unconfigure() which later during configure() can cause anexception if the text widget's foreground or background color  is accessedbefore it has been set again (in JavaSourceViewer.configure()). *** Bug 77962 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Verified in code of I20050217-2000 that the fix is in place. 53535	[java launching] java_type_name variable doesn't resolve selected binary type	"I created a jar file with a java class with a main method, added this jar to thebuild path of a project, selected the class from the package explorer.I tried to use a java launch configuration with '${java_type_name}' as typename. I failed with an error : ""The selected resource doesn't resolve to a Javaelement"". I'm inclined to say ""That's just how it works"". The SelectedResourceManager just tracks selected resources. It doesn't handle java elements. We could make it cache the selected Object, but then we'd end up creating references to objects of unknown origin (memory footprint problem). And we can't just ask the active part for its selection because variables aren't resolved in the UI thread.Unless anyone has a better idea, I plan to mark this one WONTFIX. Any objections, Luc? Luc points out that the selection isn't likely to stay the same for long. So chances of us holding onto something that we shouldn't are actually quite slim. I'm not sure what I think about this now. I'm inclined to say this one can wait. It's not critical - it works for the intending case of selecting a "".java"". Deferred Reopening to close. JDT core spec'd that class files inside jars do not have an underlying resource. Without a resource we cannot infer the type, which will not allow for the sustitution of the variable. marking as WONTFIX, since there is nothing we can do about this. 53529	"Allow bypassing ""workspace in use"" check for RCP applications"	"I would like to be able to specify a commandline option (say, ""-concurrentOk"")or some other mechanism that would allow running multiple instances using thesame workspace simultaneously.  Without this ability, RCP applications willoften need to be wrappered with some cumbersome launch mechanism that eithero creates a new workspace for each instance (probably losing any chance of  persisting state), oro implements some mechanism for rendezvousing with an already-running instance  of the app.If such an option were supported, I believe it would be acceptable to followa ""last writer wins"" policy when it comes time to save the application state. The Eclipse kernel is actually being restructured to not require a workspace atall.  However, the vast majority of plugins will still need a workspace, and wecan't dictate that they tolerate multiple concurrent instances. It is not assimple as ""last one wins"", since one instance writing metadata while another isreading can crash instances and permanently corrupt metadata.  Your proposedchange would offload a great deal of responsibility onto every plugin that usesthe metadata area (and they would likely end up needing to introduce locks oftheir own).CC Jeff in case you have further comments. In effect this is now possible.  As John mentioned, the runtime is trying to stop using the instance area (aka workspace in the IDE context).  We only use the instance area if some one calls API which uses the instance area (e.g., getStateLocation()).We are also getting out fo the business of locking, checking, setting the instance area.  The new API is around Platform.getInstanceLocation().  This gives back a Location.  This location can be locked, read, ...  The IDE scenario is to come up, prompt the user for the location of the workspace, then lock it, verify that it is the right version etc etc and continue running.RCP applications can choose to lock or not lock, check or not check, ...I think that this functionality will address your usecases.  If not, please enter a bug against the Equinox product. "	2012-07-10 11:27:42	1341930000.0	resolved fixed	3ea8285	1343430000.0	java/org/apache/catalina/tribes/group/GroupChannel.java java/org/apache/catalina/tribes/group/interceptors/NonBlockingCoordinator.java java/org/apache/catalina/tribes/group/interceptors/TcpPingInterceptor.java java/org/apache/catalina/tribes/membership/McastServiceImpl.java java/org/apache/juli/AsyncFileHandler.java java/org/apache/tomcat/util/net/AprEndpoint.java java/org/apache/tomcat/util/net/NioBlockingSelector.java java/org/apache/tomcat/util/threads/ThreadPoolExecutor.java
53526	Run Profile context menu not available	"In Eclipse 3.0, a Run cascade menu is available in the context menu.  What appears in the cascade menu is the Launch shortcuts that are relevant for the selected file in the navigator. We should add our own Profile shortcuts for all available configurations.This is the extension point :   <extension         point=""org.eclipse.debug.ui.launchShortcuts"">      <shortcut            label=""%launcher.junit.name""            icon=""icons/obj16/julaunchpgn.gif""            modes=""run, debug""            class=""org.eclipse.pde.internal.ui.launcher.JUnitWorkbenchShortcut""            id=""org.eclipse.pde.ui.junitWorkbenchShortcut"">         <perspective               id=""org.eclipse.jdt.ui.JavaPerspective"">         </perspective>         <perspective               id=""org.eclipse.jdt.ui.JavaHierarchyPerspective"">         </perspective>         <perspective               id=""org.eclipse.jdt.ui.JavaBrowsingPerspective"">         </perspective>         <perspective               id=""org.eclipse.debug.ui.DebugPerspective"">         </perspective>         <perspective               id=""org.eclipse.pde.PDEPerspective"">         </perspective>      </shortcut>  </extansion> Curt, can you please take care of this Stanley can you please take care of this. For any existing launch configuration type, Hyades should not be responsible for implementing any additional launch shortcut for profile mode. The existing launch shortcuts should be enabled for the ""profile"" mode. This is because the ""profile"" mode is not Hyades-specific, and is defined at the Eclipse platform level (it is one of the three fundamental modes: ""run"", ""debug"", ""profile""). So, they should be handling this mode even if Hyades didn't exist. Launch shortcuts aren't mode-specific; that is, there shouldn't be any mode-specific launching happening therein (this should be delegated to the platform via DebugUITools.launch(...)).As for any new types we define, we should implement our own launch shortcuts, and specify any modes that make sense (even if we don't implement them, it doesn't cost us anything). An exception might be the ""Attach - Java Process""; I don't see how we can automatically launch without knowing the host, port, and agent. Users can't ""open"" an agent in an editor or have one selected before they are attached to it (at least not to my knowledge). Thank you CurtStanley, please open a defect against Eclipse Hi all,Defect has been opened against Eclipse/JDT UI, bugzilla #53736, requesting that the existing launch shortcut also handle the profile mode. I also opened a defect on the PDE for the runtime workbench launch shortcut.https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=53782 About the External Java Application shortcut, I'm not sure it would really be useful to have this. The difference with this one and Java Application is that it supports launching from outside the workspace, as well as inside the workspace but not in java projects and source folders. Since you can only browse _within_ the workspace in the navigator, the only added benefit of this shortcut would be the ability to launch java and class files and JARs outside the build path. But, clearly we can't handle java files that have not been compiled, or whose class files we can't find. This essentially leaves class files and JAR files.So the question is whether this is worth the effort or not. The implementation would involve searching the workspace, determining whether a class file has a main (somehow), and possibly decompressing a JAR file to read its manifest. What do you think, Valentina? *** Bug 53898 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Correction: It is not the launch configuration type's responsibility to specify the ""profile"" mode, but the profiler's. See Darin's post in #53736. This is because the default launch configuration attributes have to be set, and it cannot be assumed that the profiler uses the same attributes as with run/debug.However, there is currently no feasible way to implement launch shortcuts in ""profile"" without using JDT internal API. Darin lists 3 options:* Open a new feature request or re-open this feature request as enhancement aksing for new API (likely will not happen in 3.0).* Subclass the internal stuff knowning that you will be broken, but hope for API in a future release.* Contribute a fixFor now, we can subclass the internal launch shortcuts. I have opened a new request for API. See #54072. *** Bug 56400 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Curt, can this be done for M9 ? I believe it can. Done.Implemented new shortcuts that support the profile mode. Extending the existing shortcuts for run/debug required a workaround, because it is currently not possible to 'extend' toolbar launch shortcuts to a new perspective. The shortcuts had to be redefined in our plugin.xml in run, debug modes (separately from profile) without contextual launch support. This is because the toolbar menu is perspective-based, and the context menu is not. Requested better extensibility in #54072. As of TPTP 4.6.0, TPTP is in maintenance mode and focusing on improving quality by resolving relevant enhancements/defects and increasing test coverage through test creation, automation, Build Verification Tests (BVTs), and expanded run-time execution. If this enhancement/defect is still unresolved and reproducible in the latest TPTP release (http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/home/downloads/), please re-open. Then format some source like the following:SomeObject someObject = new SomeObject(""Parameter1"", //$NON-NLS-1$                                       ""Parameter2"",  //$NON-NLS-1$                                        null);This will end up like:SomeObject someObject = new SomeObject(""Parameter1"",                                        //$NON-NLS-1$                                       ""Parameter2"",                                         //$NON-NLS-1$                                        null);Which defeats the whole purpose of using the non-internationalizable comments. 53498	EclipseStarter should not alway refreshPackages	"EclipseStarter.loadBasicBundles() attempts to install the base bundles and then always does a refreshPackages() on the base bundles even when no actual installs have occurred.  This is causing most all bundles installed on the platform to be refreshed each startup even when nothing has changed.  This is pretty expensive.  Should try change it so it only does a refreshPackages if something has changed. I'm not sure that this is a big deal.  The code installs bundles only if they need to be installed. Then passes the list of bundles it just installed to refreshPackages.  I did not go in great detail but typically that list should be empty or full of nulls.  The net effect should be a near noop.In actual fact, a thread is forked and likely some work is done.  I have added a simple test to not call refresh if installBundle() was not called.To be released after tomorrow's I build Your fix will probably address the issue.  But the current code in EclipseStarter.loadBasicBundles does end up passing an array of the four basic bundles to refresh packages every startup whether installBundle() was called or not.  This is because we create a Bundle[] and fill it will bundles that are either already installed or with newly installed bundles with the call:	// don't need to install if it is already installed	bundles[i] = getBundleByLocation(location);	if (bundles[i] != null)		continue;	bundles[i] = context.installBundle(location);This Bundle[] is then always passed to refreshPackages.  This is rather expensive because most every plugin is dependent on one of the four basic bundles. d'oh, I was misreading the code and thought that nulls were being put in the bundle array for ones that were already installed.  My fixed does appear to eliminate the actual calls to refreshPackages on second run. 53445	[DCR] [DOM Comments] Provide extended ranges including leading/trailing comments for AST nodes	Currently jdt-core does not offer any way to get extended ranges of compilation unit AST nodes hierarchy.As now, we build and store comments table in compilation unit, it's possible to compute and give users acces to these extended ranges... Fixed.Now users have getCommentList(), getExtendedStartPosition(ASTNode) and getExtendedLength(ASTNode) accessible on org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.CompilationUnit.[jdt-core-internal]Implementation of CommentMapper heuristic done in org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.DefaultCommentMapper.Note that Scanner has been modified to store only the text of line comments and not trailing '\r' and '\n' characters. This is internal table of Scanner which has been impacted but have a side on IMethod.getSourceRange() when the node has a trailing line comment as it will length 2 characters less...Test cases added in jdt.core.tests.dom.ASTConverterJavadocTest Here are some additional information on this feature implementation...Unlike ASTNode#getStartPosition() and ASTNode#getLength() the extended source range may include comments and whitespace immediately before or after the normal source range for the node.The compilation unit will now store a instance of DefaultCommentMapper which will be initialized when the compilation unit is converted into DOM/AST nodes hierarchy (see ASTConverter.convert(CompilationUnitDeclaration, char[])).For each node of hierarchy, the comment mapper will look for leading and trailing comments. If some exist, then store their indexes (first and last) in corresponding tables.When user request extended range to compilation unit for a node, it requests it from its DefaultCommentMapper which searches in its tables possible leading and/or trailing comments. Returns start position of first leading comments for extended start position or node start position if no leading comments was found.Returns length including last trailing comments for extended length or node length if no trailing comments was found. Here are also some details on the heuristic implemented in DefaultCommentMapper for leading and trailing comments.:1) for leading comments, it searchs first comment before node start position. Then it goes up in comments list until one of the following condition is true:  - comment is over previous end  - there's other than white characters between current node and comment  - there's more than 1 line between current node and commentIf all these conditions are false, then found comment becomes current node and loop with previous comment.If at least one potential comment has been found, then no token should be on the same line before, so remove all comments which do not verify this assumption.If finally there is a subset of comments, then store start and end indexes in leading comments table.2) for trailing comments, it searchs first comment after node end position. Then it goes down in comments list until one of the following condition is true:  - comment is after next start  - there's other than white characters between current node and comment  - there's more than 1 line between current node and commentIf all these conditions are false, then found comment becomes current node and loop with next comment.If at least one potential comment has been found, then last comment should be separated from next start line (ie. at least two lines after). If this is not the case then skip all comments which were not on the same line than the end of the node.If finally there is a subset of comments, then store start and end indexes in trailing comments table. Verified in build I200403250800. *** Bug 29178 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** 	2012-06-20 19:20:53	1340230000.0	resolved fixed	4e010fc	1340740000.0	modules/jdbc-pool/src/main/java/org/apache/tomcat/jdbc/pool/ConnectionPool.java modules/jdbc-pool/src/main/java/org/apache/tomcat/jdbc/pool/DataSource.java modules/jdbc-pool/src/main/java/org/apache/tomcat/jdbc/pool/interceptor/SlowQueryReportJmx.java modules/jdbc-pool/src/test/java/org/apache/tomcat/jdbc/test/TestSlowQueryReport.java
