53266	[CellEditors] ComboBoxCellEditor dismissed on first click in Properties View	When you click in the properties view on an entry that uses a ComboBoxCellEditor it will activate the cell editor correctly, but when you try to click on the dropdown, the cell editor is dismissed.  You then need to click again to activate the cell editor again, and then you need to click the dropdown again, which fortunately works the second time.  Any property that uses a ComboBoxCellEditor needs to be clicked four times to access the dropdown the first time.  Every time a new input is passed to the properties view, the behavior is reset and four clicks are necessary yet again.One place to reproduce this is in the PDE's .exsd editor.  EMF relies heavily on the properties view, so this problem is a serious usability regression that needs to be addressed before 3.0 is final. I suggest you vote on the duplicate bug.*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 46479 *** 	2012-05-20 14:32:34	1337540000.0	resolved fixed	37e8c59	1339450000.0	java/org/apache/catalina/startup/ContextConfig.java

53354	"can not launch ""runtime workbench"""	"Using M7 as a development environment, I can not run ""Run ... runtime workbench"" with last weeks integration build (I20040226) as the target. I get the following message in log. I marked as ""blocker"" since I'd think this would be a common way of doing development on Eclipse (that is, use milestone build as development platform, and latest integration build as target). I would be surprised if not already found, but I couldn't find existing bugzilla. A workaround would be appreciated. BTW ... using just the integration build, and launching runtime workbench seems to work fine. !SESSION ----------------------------------------------------------------------!ENTRY org.eclipse.core.launcher 4 0 Feb 28, 2004 21:17:37.924!MESSAGE Exception launching the Eclipse Platform:!STACKjava.lang.IllegalStateException: Bundle reference:file:D:/builds/Daily/eclipse-SDK-3.0M7-win32/eclipse/workspace/org.eclipse.osgi.util/ [2] is not active	at org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.EclipseStarter.ensureBundlesActive(EclipseStarter.java:123)	at org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.EclipseStarter.run(EclipseStarter.java:93)	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(Unknown Source)	at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(Unknown Source)	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Unknown Source)	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.basicRun(Main.java:279)	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.run(Main.java:742)	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.main(Main.java:581) In the I build the pde, update and some part of runtime have been reorganized insuch a way that they are mot compatible with M7.Use your I build as your dev environment.Please close as invalid if it works for you. Well ... it might work for me personally, but I'm just a small part of a large team. So, are you saying that everyone who wants to ""keep up"" with integration builds, has to start doing development with an integration build as their development environment?! This seems a little dangerous, since I builds are not completly stable and not completely tested (by definition). Or are you saying there's no easy work around at the moment ... but there is still efforts being made to fix this incompatibility by the next integration build? If no hope of being compatible, then we (as a large team) have two alternatives, either all move up to do developement on potenitally unstable I builds, or all sit back and wait for M8 (and get further out of synch with base) ... neither seem like good alternatives, so I'm reluctant to close as invalid.  Your concerns are valid however there is not much we can do about this.  The new function/structure we are putting in place needs more/different information than the older environments can offer.  As I'm sure you can appreciate, it is very difficult for us to manage our code and artifacts to capture the vision for 3.0 if we have to maintain N iterations of the structure we did along the way.  As was noted, this issue is not specific to the runtime.  At least several components have conspired to break things all at once :-/As for what you should do, I suggest moving to the latest I builds.  There are problems to be sure but we all use them and are not losing data or crashing. I'm going to close this.  If someone can offer up the relevant fixes or take some other work we can reopen but we just don't have the cycles. Jeff, can the PDE not organize itself so that part of its functionality/implementation is provided by the *TARGET* version of Eclipse, instead of the developement version? Or perhaps they could provide fragments for each target runtime, but that blows up pretty quick.It seems like this is the only way to prevent this in the future.  After all, Eclipse is an extensible IDE, and it would be naive to think that developers do not have lots of custom tools installed and running in their development environment.  The extreme case is people who use WSAD to develop for WSAD. moving to PDE 'cause I know it will make Wassim happy... In M7, update.configurator expects ""platform.cfg"" and PDE generates one for it.In 0226, update.configurator expects ""platform.xml"" and PDE generates one for it.You are using M7 as a host platform to target a 0226 (a later build). I'm not sure why you expect PDE in M7 to be forward-compatible.  I'm no psychic on what the future holds for update.configurator ;-)In your scenario, you are using M7, so PDE generates a ""platform.cfg"", which is not understood by 0226's update.configurator.Note that update and core runtime are still moving targets and PDE is not expected and cannot be expected to provide backward compatibility on a build-date granularity level.While we acknowlege the inconvenience this may have caused you, there is nothing that can be done in this case.  There is a breaking point where update.configurator changed its platform config file format.PDE provides backward-compatiblity with 2.x releases, and that's as far as backward compatibility goes. So there is something in 0226 which knows how to generate a ""platform.xml"" file. So the suggestion was that you make that functionality visible to the older IDE (M7), so that it could know how to launch 0226.  Or better yet, it actually asks 0226 to launch iteself.Obviously you can't do this after the fact and I don't expect an M7.0.1 release.  But, going forward you could take this approach to avoid the problem the future.  That way Eclipse R3.0 could be used to develop for Eclipse 4.0. I have to agree with Randy on this one.  In our case there are plugins we require for development that have not been upgraded to a 3.0 base.  We have no choice but to stay back a level for our workbench, but we are required to launch, debug, certify our work on 3.0.  It's untenable.  As more tools are acquired from more sources, workbenches are going to be held back by their weakest link.  This is going to be a much more common scenario.  Its akin to requiring that all nodes of a network be upgrade the same level of software at the same time which is something we all know customers will not accept. I don't understand why you think that forward-compatibility on the part of PDE is feasible and expected.The suggestion made by Randy in comment #7 is simply impossible.Let's use Randy's R3.0 and R4.0 hypothetical scenario as an example:When we ship R3.0, update.configurator (from the Update component) expects a platform.xml file that it could launch successfully, and PDE generates one for it.Let's say in R4.0, the Update team decided to go with an (arbitrary) platform.ini file instead of platform.xml.  PDE in R4.0 could adapt to that change and be even backward-compatible so that it could be used to target R3.0 patforms.On the other hand, PDE 3.0 could not have foreseen these breaking changes obviously, so what could have possibly been done in the 3.0 development cycle to account for the future unforseen breaking change?  Nothing.Randy is suggesting that 3.0PDE could call 4.0 update.configurator (from the target platform) to have it generate the correct configuration file.How is that possible?  The host platform instance (3.0) and its plugins don't have plugins from the target platform on their runtime classpath.  The only update.configurator a 3.0 PDE would have on its classpath is the one that was shipped with it.  It cannot call APIs from the 4.0 update.configurator in the target platform. In other words, PDE will always require that the target platform be the same or older than PDE itself. This is a perfectly reasonable requirement - the self-hosting Eclipse is typically the latest stable build from Eclipse.org and as long as it is backward-compatible with previous releases, all is well. It seems there are 2 possibilities (other than doing nothing):1) Support N+1 hosting. Provide a 2.1.x version of PDE which can launch a 3.0 version of Eclipse.  Worst case you double your work load.  The alternative is that users wait for every tool they have installed to support the latest version of eclipse before they themselves can do so.2) I thought bundles could come from anywhere.  In fact, I though I saw a demo at EclipseCon where a ""plugin"" was loaded over a network instead of from the plug-ins folder.  Could you not use the new runtime support to do what you said is impossible? Dynamically define a bundle in the target runtime and ask core to activate it? Regarding solution #1:Maybe I just can't relate to the workflow that requires forward compatibility.  Once upon a time when I was on the WSADIE team, I remember using the latest and greatest lightweight Eclipse to target my product that was based on a previous version of Eclipse.  I don't remember anybody using a platform as their host workbench that is older than the target platform.Plus, in this proposed solution, which would require a double work load at worst, I'm not sure this so-called patch really fits the criterion of a critical fix that should go into a service release.  So I can't see it happening.Regarding solution #2:Although it is technically possible in the Eclipse of tomorrow to point at a bundle and dynamically install it, two main problems come to mind immediately:1. When you install update.configurator 4.0 dynamically, the 3.0 counterpart gets deactivated and who knows what the ramifications of this might be.  There is no guarantee there is binary compatibility between update.configurator 4.0 and the rest of the Update plug-ins in 3.0.  Spend a day with the Update team, and see what happens if people start mixing plug-ins themselves.  You could end up with a pretty messy configuration.2. Back to the whole crystal ball thing, you are making the assumption that the plug-in needed to read the configuration file is always going to be update.configurator.  What if they change it to something else?  After all, the name did change between 2.x and 3.0.  PDE simply can't make assumptions and predictions about future platforms and what plug-ins to dynamically install. ""when I was on the WSADIE"".  You were at the bottom of the stack, and there was significant lag in what your target version of eclpise was and what was ""latest and greatest"".  In addition, WSAD has reduced the lag time and is very much in-step with the workbench.  Also, the number of add-in tools has increased over time.""When you install update.configurator 4.0 dynamically, the 3.0 counterpart gets deactivated and who knows what the ramifications of this might be""Obviously this would have to be split into 2 pieces. the 3.0 counterpart would never even get loaded since that is not the target runtime. One piece is would be contant and part of the IDE, and it would load the dynamic second piece from the target IDE. I suppose if I went into preferences and changed my target platform, then at that point the portion provided by the target runtime would get shutdown and swapped out. "	2012-06-03 19:16:25	1338770000.0	resolved fixed	b82c47e	1338760000.0	java/org/apache/catalina/startup/ContextConfig.java

This is blocking any further work on progress. Created attachment 8225Patch against workbench for my work in progress The TrimLayoutData class is completely undocumented so understanding the implications of choices is currently not possible. Okay, I can't get your patch to apply, but I found the problem:TrimLayoutData animationData = new TrimLayoutData(false, progressRegion.getControl().computeSize(SWT.DEFAULT, SWT.DEFAULT).y, getStatusLineManager().getControl().computeSize(SWT.DEFAULT, SWT.DEFAULT).y);I suspect that the width hint should be "".x"" rather than "".y"":TrimLayoutData animationData = new TrimLayoutData(false, progressRegion.getControl().computeSize(SWT.DEFAULT, SWT.DEFAULT).x, getStatusLineManager().getControl().computeSize(SWT.DEFAULT, SWT.DEFAULT).y);When you attach a TrimLayoutData to a control, TrimLayout will use the info inthe layout data instead of calling the control's computeSize method. Iintentionally attached a TrimLayoutData to animationItem in order to preventTrimLayout from using animationItem's preferred size (the preferred size ofanimationItem was badly behaved).If progressRegion has a well-behaved computeSize method, you can omit theTrimLayoutData entirely (or set both hints to SWT.DEFAULT), and TrimLayout willuse the preferred size as you request.I will add JavaDoc to TrimLayoutData to prevent future confusion. 53056	[Workbench] level of detail option for view title bar	"One of the common new look gripes is that if you have a view pane with severalviews, and the tabs for those views don't fit, then the inactive views ""fall offthe end"" and are no longer visible.  This is made worse by the extra space usedby the curvy active tab.  Many applications solve problems like this by makingthe information displayed in tabs configurable (text only, icon only, or both).The initial configuration shows text to help out the novice user, but theadvanced user can turn off the text and just use the icons.  This would allowyou to have quite a lot of views within a pane and not have them ""fall off the end"". 52957	[KeyBindings] Keybinding Service consumes keystrokes for unregistered commands	"My editor has no ""Content Assist"" action handler.My editor's canvas does not receive CTRL+SPACE KeyPressed event.From mailing list:> I'm pretty sure Nick said that if the action bound to a keybinding is> disabled (or bound to NULL), then the keybinding service would stop> consuming that key.  But this is not the behavior we are seeing.  ForWe check whether the command has a handler (i.e., action) associated with it. If it doesn't, then we don't eat the key.  We eat all keys that: (1) have a key binding currently in context; and (2) have a handler currently active.> example, we also need to receive CTRL+SPACE, which has universal meaning> of ""toggle selection"" of item with focus. But the keybinding for Content> Assist is getting in the way. Why do native Trees and Tables receive> CTRL+SPACE, but our Canvas does not?Likely because a handler is registered for your part.  I'm just guessing, asI'm not sure of the details of your set-up.Nope, we are not registering a handler-Randy I need the following information from you: + The build you are running + The console output when running with the key binding debugging information.  This is available in the options file for Platform UI.  Please set both the debugging and verbose debugging flags to true.  You are not experiencing ""crashes, loss of data, severe memory leak"", so please do not mark the bug as critical.  Downgrading to ""major""....  The PDE launcher is still busted M7 so I cannot enable tracing.  Anyway, you can reproduce quite easily.Here are the steps reproduce. Use the PDE wizard to create a new plug-in project.  Choose the template ""plug-in with View"", and then choose to ues a TreeViewer (which will be deleted later), and deselect all of the unrelated stuff like toolbars, context menus, filters, sorting, whatever.Now, open the generated class ""SampleView"", and change it to read:public class SampleView extends ViewPart {public void createPartControl(Composite parent) {  new Text(parent, SWT.MULTI | SWT.V_SCROLL)      .addKeyListener(new KeyAdapter() {    public void keyPressed(KeyEvent e) {      if (e.character == ' ' && e.stateMask == SWT.CTRL)        ((Text)e.widget).append(""Ctrl+SPACE"");    }});}public void setFocus() {}}Run the runtime workbench and note that CTRL+SPACE is not being received by the view's Text control.  Also, not that COPY/CUT/PASTE do not work either, yet the view has not provided and action handlers for *any* of these actions. a comment in passing (i.e. i didn't think too much about it, so take it with a grain of salt.. ):cut, copy, and paste are 'global' actions, so they are registered on startup (opening a workbench window). [search backwards from WorkbenchWindow.registerGlobalAction to org.eclipse.internal.ide.WorkbenchActionBuilder.makeActions to see this unfold..]that means, for global or 'retargetable' actions, the command manager always thinks there is a handler. (i don't think the workbench window never unregisters global actions.)if a RetargetAction doesn't have a handler in the active part, it simply says its disabled. that doesn't help us down at the command manager. the workbench is not making the distinction between 'unhandled' and 'handled but disabled'.not sure about content assist.. maybe the same problem. i don't think ui registers content assist as a global action, though.anyway, food for thought.. Yup, I was thinking the same thing, which is why I decided not to start off by saying ""come on guys, this is so obvious ... cut/copy/paste has been busted for ages"" :-) So, the second form of this problem is that keystrokes are consumed for commands which ARE registered with a Global Action, BUT for which there is no Action Handler.  This has been around forever, and it is why Undo/Redo/Cut/Copy/Paste do not work inside simple Text controls. Confirmed on Randy's reproduce case from comment #2.  Key binding service recognizes the command identifier ""org.eclipse.ui.edit.copy"", but replies that the command is disabled.  Chris' guess was an alarmingly good one.  I would suggested making getActionHandler public on RetargetAction.  The class is flagged as not intended to be subclassed, and there are only ten descendents in Eclipse.  :)  None of them attempt to override the behaviour of this method.  Now, in ActionHandler, we can make one of those icky downcasts to RetargetAction when appropriate.  This will allow us to distinguish between the disabled and unhandled cases of RetargetAction.   Alternatively, we can make it so that disabled actions don't eat key bindings.  This is more direct, but I think the semantic is backward somehow.  I would expect that if some command were disabled that it wouldn't be allowed to continue to the widget hierarchy -- where it might be interpreted as something else altogether.   How do people feel about these options?  This is being deferred from M8, and will be fixed for the first integration build in M9.  The reasons for deferral at this point is that: + It's too close to M8. + While it does not seem risky, it could have unintentional side effects. + This bug has not been noticed very often.   It will be ready for I200403300800.  I believe this bug is now fixed in CVS.  There were two separate problems.   First of all, I've expanded RetargetAction to expose its internal handler.  ActionHandler and Command now use this extra information (if present) to decide whether a command is *really* handled.  Secondly, the perfect match branch of the press method seemed to contain a logic error.  It said to swallow the key if there *weren't* previous key strokes and a perfect match occurred.  I believe it was intended to be if there *were* previous key strokes.  In general, though, it might be better to remove that check all together.  Really, it might be better if the defined/handled state of a command was all that controlled the eating of keys.  Let me know if you see this problem again/still post-I200403300800.   Verified in I200405190010 by using the test case in Comment #2.  Solaris 8,Motif, CDE. 50860	[interop] NoClassDefFoundError when using SWT_AWT after applying workaround for manifest file	<Pyinson Data Over Head> Created attachment 7628project workspace, sources incl binary pluginZip file contains the plugin workarea, java sources, compiled classes andplugin archive. Described behavior was produced on 3.0M6 build including the recommended workaround to avoid the initial NoClassDefFoundException that was caused by the wrong package name in the manifest file for class SWT_AWT. Plugins that are executed via the runtime-workbench seem to work fine, actually deploying the plugin and restarting the main workbench throws the exception. *** Bug 50878 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** This looks like a problem in the plugin class loader. Moving to core to get more input.  The problem happens because there was a bug in the OSGi manifest for SWT thatshipped with M6. It exported a package org.eclipse.swt.internal.awt, althoughthe right package should be org.eclipse.swt.awt. You didn't get the error while running from Eclipse because you probably had SWTimported from CVS (the manifest was fixed on 20031230) instead of importing fromthe M6 as binary project. Is that correct?So, using a more recent integration build (or manually fixing the manifest forSWT on M6) solves the problem. This is actually a duplicate. Silenio, this has already been reported: bug 49401 and bug 50377. Feel free tomark as duplicate of one of them (BTW: one of them should be marked as duplicateof the other, shouldn't it?). *** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 50377 *** 	2011-03-03 06:51:14	1299150000.0	resolved fixed	e092870	1332260000.0	modules/jdbc-pool/src/main/java/org/apache/tomcat/jdbc/pool/DataSourceProxy.java modules/jdbc-pool/src/main/java/org/apache/tomcat/jdbc/pool/PoolConfiguration.java modules/jdbc-pool/src/main/java/org/apache/tomcat/jdbc/pool/PoolProperties.java modules/jdbc-pool/src/main/java/org/apache/tomcat/jdbc/pool/PooledConnection.java modules/jdbc-pool/src/main/java/org/apache/tomcat/jdbc/pool/jmx/ConnectionPool.java

you may want to incorporate some of this back into the CDT code, or at least figure out the RIGHT way to fix the problem ;-)Here is my snippit from CDebugTarget (version 1.2).  This could certainly be done a little more cleanly.	/* (non-Javadoc)	 * @see org.eclipse.cdt.debug.core.ISwitchToThread#setCurrentThread(IThread)	 */	public void setCurrentThread( IThread thread ) throws DebugException	{		if ( !isSuspended() || !isAvailable() || thread == null || !(thread instanceof CThread) )		{			return;		}				//		// CS: 02-19-04		//		// If thread selection fails, revert the selection to the old thread		//		CThread oldThread = null;		try		{			oldThread = (CThread)getCurrentThread();			if (oldThread == null || !oldThread.equals( thread ) )			{				if (oldThread != null)				{					oldThread.setCurrent( false );				}				getCDITarget().setCurrentThread( ((CThread)thread).getCDIThread() );				((CThread)thread).setCurrent( true );			}		}		catch( CDIException e )		{			if (oldThread != null)			{				oldThread.setCurrent( true );			}			targetRequestFailed( e.getMessage(), null );		}	}Note that this still calls targetRequestFailed(), and so this in and of itself if not enough to get rid of the dialog box.  I then also modified CDebugUIPlugin to not call errorDialog().  I suspect this is not what you will want to do, but here is the snippet:	/* (non-Javadoc)	 * @see org.eclipse.ui.ISelectionListener#selectionChanged(IWorkbenchPart, ISelection)	 */	public void selectionChanged( IWorkbenchPart part, ISelection selection )	{		if ( selection != null && selection instanceof IStructuredSelection )		{			if ( ((IStructuredSelection)selection).size() == 1 )			{				Object element = ((IStructuredSelection)selection).getFirstElement();				if ( element != null && element instanceof IThread )				{					if ( ((IThread)element).getDebugTarget() instanceof ISwitchToThread )					{						try						{							if ( !sameThread( (IDebugElement)element ) )							{								((ISwitchToThread)((IThread)element).getDebugTarget()).setCurrentThread( (IThread)element );							}						}						catch( DebugException e )						{							//							// CS: 02-19-04 							//							// Don't bring up this error dialog, just fail silently							//							//errorDialog( e.getMessage(), e );						}					}				}				else if ( element != null && element instanceof IStackFrame )				{					if ( ((IStackFrame)element).getThread() instanceof ISwitchToFrame )					{						try						{							if ( !sameThread( (IDebugElement)element ) )							{								((ISwitchToThread)((IStackFrame)element).getDebugTarget()).setCurrentThread( ((IStackFrame)element).getThread() );							}							((ISwitchToFrame)((IStackFrame)element).getThread()).switchToFrame( (IStackFrame)element );						}						catch( DebugException e )						{//							errorDialog( ""Switch to stack frame failed."", e );						}					}				}			}		}	} Does this happen because you have a non-CThread selected in the Debug view? No, the thread becomes initially selected when the attach occurs and the target is suspended.  Then the target is resumed, and a breakpoint is hit.  At this point, the thread that was previously selected really does not exist any more.  I suspect this is some kind of thread having to do with attaching gdb to the process under debug, but I really don't know much about the Windows debug architecture and gdb to validate this ""gut feeling"" Wait, my above comment isn't quite true.  After the process is resumed, I am selecting my launch (the top level in the debug hierarchy).  It implements ISuspendResume, I am resuming it.  So it is the guy that is currently selected when the breakpoint is hit.  It is certainly not a CThread, so I guess the answer to your previous question is, ""yes"" Ok, I'll check both cases. Thanks. I suspect this is a synchronization problem, but I can't reproduce it with the current version. Can you try the latest version from the HEAD or 1.2.1? I can reproduce it in 1.2.1 also.  Remember that my CDT target is not the only thing in my launch, I have non-CDT targets in my launch as well.  I don't know how this might impact things, and obviously would be difficult for you to reproduce. The only place when this can happen is the ""selectionChanged"" method of ""CDebugUIPlugin"". But we always check if the target is an instance of 'ISwitchToThread' or 'ISwitchToFrame'. This should filter out other targets and threads, unless you use the same interfaces.Can you send me a longer trace? The one that starts when program hits the breakpoint.Thanks.BTW, this code (the synchronization of the selected thread and frame with the current thread and frame in gdb) will be removed in 2.0. <Pyinson Data Over Head> PR was not targeted to any particular release. Changing target milestone to 2.1 We don't synchronize the thread selection in the Debug view with the current thread in gdb anymore. Assuming that the problem is gone because the ""ISwitchToThread"" interface no longer exists. 51237	cannot launch a 2.1 target instance from 3.0	"Reported by Daniel Megert in bug 49379.Bug 49379 comment 11:""I have I20040204 and developping for the 3.0 stream works fine. However, since Ihave to provide a fix for 2.1.3 I started my 2.1 maintenance workspace up usingI20040204. This works as expected. But when I try to launch a target workspaceusing PDE's Run-time Workbench launch configuration (I clear the workspace) I get:!SESSION ----------------------------------------------------------------------!ENTRY org.eclipse.core.launcher 4 0 Feb 05, 2004 12:52:26.28!MESSAGE Exception launching the Eclipse Platform:!STACKjava.lang.IllegalStateException: Unable to acquire application service	at org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.EclipseStarter.run(EclipseStarter.java:100)	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:39)	atsun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:25)	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:324)	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.basicRun(Main.java:279)	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.run(Main.java:742)	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.main(Main.java:581)I deleted all possible .config directories  - no luck. Before the OSGI story Iwas able to run my old workspace and also run targets. This is now no longerpossible.""Bug 49379 comment 12:""Note: I now restarted my 2.1.x workspace using 3.0 M4, added a new Run-timeWorkbench launch config (as I did before) and it works like a charm hence Iassume this to work with latest 3.0 builds as well."" ""...I started my 2.1 maintenance workspace...""The problem you described shows that the runtime for 3.0 is being used to startEclipse from Eclipse (not what you want). Can you confirm you have only 2.1.* plugins in your launch configuration (eitherby importing from a 2.1.* install, having a 2.1.* as target platform, orchecking them out from CVS)? I guess I found the problem: the target platform was I20040204 and hence it usedthis one for launching. I changed the target platform to be 2.1.2 and now it works.I can't tell for sure but I think PDE automatically ""updated"" the targetworkspace and launch config. Ok, this is good. I will close this one. Feel free to open a different issueagainst PDE/UI. Agree.FYI: I guess PDE automatically updates the target unless set manually. I did notnotice this since I launch without any external plug-in from the target location(I have everything in the 2.1.2 workspace). BUT: the target seems to have aneffect on the  Run-time launch config behavior itself. There were a number of changes in PDE to handle the new launch requirements for the 3.0 runtime.  PDE detects the flavour of target and uses different techniques depending on the target.  So yes, the nature of your target does affect how the target is launched.As for updating the target automaticaly, you would have ot ask the PDE folks but there is a ""use this applicaiton as the target"" option.  If that is selected, I would expect it to be updated as I change what Eclipse I was using for the dev environment. >but there is a ""use this applicaiton as the target"" option.  If that is Well that's what I did and that preference has gone and this probably triggeredthe error. The ""Use this application"" option was redundant and confusing to users.  PDE is able to determine this implicitly without confusing the user with two options.Your host platform remains equal to your target platform, until you explicitly change the target platform value to a different one.This way, if you launch different instances of Eclipse on the same workspace, every time your worbench opens, your target platform would be adjusted to be equal to your host platform (as if the old option were still there).In your case, you launched a 3.0 platform on a 2.1 workbench, so the target platform is 3.0 and that is why you ran into the error.  No surprises there.  It is the expected behavior since in this workspace, you had the default behavior (target == host).If you do development for a 2.1 platform using a 3.0 host platform, you have to explicitly change the target platform in the preferences.  This is how things work and always have worked. Dani, regarding comment #4, which is what is causing the confusion:To be able to launch, PDE needs to specify the location of startup.jar.  This JAR is the one found in the target platform.So when all your external plug-ins are uncheked, you would be running with workspace plug-ins only as you expect, but with the startup.jar of your target platform.In the case here, the startup.jar is a 3.0 JAR which is incompatible with your 2.1.x workspace plug-ins.  That is why it is necessary to always specify the target platform against which your workspace plug-ins are meant to be deployed, even if all the external plug-ins remain unchecked. Wassim,sounds all fair and I understand the technical implementation when reading yourcomments BUT it is still confusing for a user (at least it was for me): I haveall needed plug-ins in my workspace and when running I have nothing checked fromthe external plug-ins. Since I used 3.0 builds (before OSGi) to launch myself-containing (at least I thought so ;-) 2.1.x workspace I saw no reason whyit should no longer work. Hence I filed the bug report.If there is a dependency to the target location when launching then this shouldbe indicated somewhere in the launch configuration. The fact of the matter is that being aware of the target platform is a requirement for any developer using Eclipse, if you are not going to have all your plug-ins in your workspace including the one supplying the startup.jar.>If he has to set the target property then he can expect a human readable >dialog which tells...A tad harsh...Aborting the launch and telling you exactly what plug-ins you are missing from your configuration seems pretty reasonable.>PDE could detect what's my workspace version and also what's at the target >location we can determine if your target platform is OSGi-based or not, and that is how we determine if we should do things in legacy mode or OSGi mode, since this is the platform against which you are supposedly developing your plug-ins.What versions of plug-ins you are working on in your workspace is irrelevant and not taken into account. Your workspace plug-ins can have version 6.0 on them, for all we know (much like WSADIE).Bottom line is that PDE does a lot magic behind the scenes and hides as many details as possible from the user, but at the very least one should be aware of a target platform is, as it is the foundation of our self-hosting story.It does not seem to be too much to ask. 52792	Ecore model doesn't match XML schema	"On Linux 2.4.22, Sun JVM 1.4.2_02, Eclipse 3.0M7, EMF 2.0.0_20040127_1738SL:I created an XML schema: <?xml version=""1.0"" encoding=""UTF-8""?><xs:schema attributeFormDefault=""unqualified"" elementFormDefault=""qualified""targetNamespace=""http://coalition/xml/schema"" version=""1.0""xmlns=""http://coalition/xml/schema"" xmlns:cool=""http://coalition/xml/schema""xmlns:xs=""http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"">  <xs:simpleType name=""IdT"">    <xs:restriction base=""xs:string"">      <xs:whiteSpace value=""preserve""/>    </xs:restriction>  </xs:simpleType>  <xs:simpleType name=""NameT"">    <xs:restriction base=""xs:string"">      <xs:whiteSpace value=""preserve""/>    </xs:restriction>  </xs:simpleType>  <xs:complexType name=""SomethingT"">    <xs:sequence>      <xs:element name=""Name"" type=""cool:NameT""/>    </xs:sequence>    <xs:attribute name=""locationId"" type=""IdT"" use=""required""/>  </xs:complexType>  <xs:element name=""SomethingList"">    <xs:complexType>      <xs:sequence>        <xs:element maxOccurs=""unbounded"" name=""Something"" type=""cool:SomethingT""/>      </xs:sequence>    </xs:complexType>  </xs:element></xs:schema>When I create an Ecore model from that schema, the names for the elements arebeing munged in an unpleasant fashion.  SomethingList becomes SomethingListType,and its sub-element ""Something"" becomes ""something"".  When I generate code fromthese munged names, and try to serialize the objects to XML, the resulting XMLdoesn't match the schema. Created attachment 8100genmodel file created by loading the schema Created attachment 8101ecore file generated by loading the schema Craig, this is working as designed. The original XML names are recorded as annotations and the correct options for the resource will ensure that those annotations are used. Since colliding element and attribute names are possible, since many elements (or attributes) with the same name but different namespaces are possible, since element and attribute names aren't neccesarily valid Java identifiers, and since anonymous types are possible, you'd better expect names to be mangled in general.  (Lowercase element and attribute names is probably better style to follow anyway.) "	2012-02-28 20:30:12	1330480000.0	resolved fixed	7cec4ff	1331150000.0	java/org/apache/naming/NamingContext.java

It just appears as if none of the files in my projects contains any //TODO: comments, which as I stated, is not the case.Most disturbingly, exiting and restarting Eclipse does not resolve the problem.  In fact, I get a message upon startup, apparently as Eclipse is trying to reload the workspace settings which were saved upon the previous exit.Once started up, Eclipse gives me the same error every time I click on any column header of the Tasks view. The error is:ERROR: Searching for markers in Tasks view: An internal error occurred during: ""Searching for markers in Tasks view"". I'm using Eclipse 3.0M7. Found a workaround for this bug, in 2 parts.To clear up the corruption:1. Bring up the Filters dialog   a. From the Tasks view...   b. ...click the Filters icon, or    c. ...select Filters from the drop-down arrow icon2. Toggle the ""Java Task"" checkbox (I'm assuming it's checked already, you want it unchecked).3. Click OK to save and dismiss the dialogTo redisplay your tasks:Repeat steps 1-3 above, but in step 2, you want the ""Java Task"" box to be checked. Downgrading severity since there is now a workaround for the ""corruption"" -- but unless people know about the workaround, I'd say it's at least NORMAL severity. I cannot reproduce the bug at will since following my own workaround, so I'll mark this to resolve later. As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported.Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you. The problem could occur if a fragment bundle's host changes due to adding/removing/updating the installed plugins.This situation seemed to have occurred because the state returned a fragment BundleDescription from getResolvedBundles() that either did not have its HostSpecification set or its HostSpecification did not have its supplier set. Hmm... it appears that this is due to a difference in the behavior of SWT onparticular GTK setups.BTW, the likely cause is this: when Eclipse creates a detached window, it checksif the window is within the bounds of the Display and moves the detached windowback to the monitor containing the main Eclipse window if it doesn't lieanywhere in the display. It is possible that on GTK, SWT is returning a client region for the Displaythat does not cover all the monitors. I'm not sure if this is a bug or whetherwe're misusing Display.getClientArea. Reassigning to SWT for comment. Chrix can you comment? It's possibly a bug in Display.getClientArea().  In a multi-monitor situation, it should return the same as Display.getBounds().  You should be using Monitor API to play ""shell positioning"" games. Re comment 9: Steve is right. We should really begin by checking if the detachedview interects the client area of any monitor rather than the client area of thedisplay. If this bug was being caused by having a display area that did notencompass all the monitors, this should fix it. I've submitted a patch that implements comment 10. However, if this fixes theproblem then it means that there was definitely a monitor whose client area wasoutside the range of Display.getClientArea(). Stefan, this doesn't seem like an SWT problem.  Can you confirm this?  If not, please close this problem report or take ownership.  Thanks. If the patch mentioned in comment 11 is in the head and made M8, it did not do anything. Can you post the output of 'xdpyinfo -ext all' on your machine? <Pyinson Data Over Head> <Pyinson Data Over Head> I dug deeper into this. I'm guessing the binary part of GTK or GTK itself is doing this to me. Following the pointers from Stefan I followed the shell and opening it. The bounds are set correctly into the shell, but at shell.open(), the bounds change automatically! Steping through Shell.open(), this is the result:  From Shell.java:   public void open () { 	checkWidget ();     // After call: Bounds are { 400,200,100,100 } 	setVisible (true);  // After call: Bounds are { 400,200,100,100 } but shows at { 2000,200,100,100 } 	bringToTop (false); // After call: !!! Bounds change to { 2000,200,100,100 } !!! 	if (!restoreFocus () && !traverseGroup (true)) setFocus (); }  This must be using the position of the parent shell somehow, because if I have eclipse on screen 1, the dialogs always open on screen 1 (and open() adds 1600 to the x coordinate of the dialog if needed), if eclipse is on screen 0, it opens on screen 0.   Now I did manage to do shell.setBounds(2000,200,100,100) after open() and it repositioned to the correct screen. So I am guessing somewhere within setVisible(), it, on linux/gtk, checks the bounds of the parent shells screen and positions it within it? Or maybe gtk itself does this check I don't know..     Wow.  I'm really sorry, but I probably should have realized this sooner.  KDE tries to centre dialogs over the parent shell.  Since we are currently creating our detached views with parents, it will try to centre detached views over the workbench window.  Would this accurately describe what you're seeing?  Yes, playing a little more its not really monitor related. Changing the summary, as this applies to all configurations.  Basically, Eclipse just needs to change one line.... Is this issue still being investigated?Douglas, can you specify the one line Eclipse has to change, so that we could dosome testing?Morten, did you find a workaround?I'm a bit frustrated, having bought just yesterday an additional LCD monitorjust for eclipse... I assume that the one line fix Doug is referring to would be setting the parentpointer for the detached window's Shell to null.On windows (and probably other platforms), this will allow the detached windowto end up behind the main workbench window with no way to bring it in front --and this is much more severe than losing the window's position, which is veryannoying but still usable.Since Eclipse is giving the correct window location to the OS, it sounds likethe best we could do is report this bug to GTK and wait for them to fix it.We could also try hacks like ""if OS == GTK, then wait 10ms after opening thewindow and then try to move it again""... but that's really ugly. Does anyoneknow if this has already been reported to the GTK developers? If so, it would beuseful to attach a link here so that we can follow its progress. Or you could make line 51 of DetachedWindow (org.eclipse.ui.workbench)          super((""gtk"".equals(SWT.getPlatform())) ? null : workbenchPage.getWorkbenchWindow().getShell());  A better fix would be possible if SWT provided window manager detection.  To be clear, this bug is KDE specific.  Guillaume, are you using KDE?  If not,please open a new bug.The policy in KDE is to open dialogs always in the center of their parentwindow.  There are two open KDE bugs which relate to this:  1: http://bugs.kde.org/show_bug.cgi?id=78082     - This complains about KDE's policy, and it may be changed in the future.  2: http://bugs.kde.org/show_bug.cgi?id=59572     - If a dialog is hidden and re-shown, KDE acts as if it is a new window       and re-centers it again.  This may also be affecting us here.If either of these were changed I think we would benefit.  There's anothersolution: detached views aren't really ""dialogs"".  Modern window managers have amore expressive notion of window types, and so arguably we should be settingdetached views as ""utility windows"", which would have the nice side-effect ofmaking KDE not enforce its dialog policy on them.  However, this would requirenew API from SWT. Billy, I agree with the idea of using window types -- this would let us describewhat we want in a high level, and SWT could give us the correctplatform-specific behavior. I'm not sure if we'd even need new API -- SWT.TOOL |SWT.NO_TRIM seems to describe what we want, even though it doesn't currentlyhave the desired behavior. I'm sure it can be fixed with some elaborate SWT fix, but wouldn't the fix I suggest under work as well. I know its hacky, but it fixes the Linux/KDE issue. After I put it in, the location is remembered perfectly. Just in case I guess there could be a ""only if gtk"" check in there as well..   Only thing it does is to check whether open() changes the set bounds and then redo it if it happens.  DetachedWindow.java:  /*       * Fixes a problem with Linux GTK when KDE is used as window manager.      * It repositions the detached window to center on top of the parent       * application window.      *  	 * @see org.eclipse.jface.window.Window#open() 	 */ 	public int open() { 		 		if (getShell() == null) 			create(); 		 		Rectangle bounds = getShell().getBounds(); 		int ret = super.open(); 		 		if (!bounds.equals(getShell().getBounds())) { 			getShell().setBounds(bounds); 		} 		 		return ret; 	}  Morten's patch looks good as a short-term fix. I think Billy has the right ideafor the long-term solution.I have committed Morten's patch to HEAD (without modification) and filed bug79462 and bug 79461 requesting SWT support for Billy's suggestions.Thanks for the help, Morten. Since I can't reproduce this I'd be grateful if youcould add a note here once you see this fixed in a build. Sorry I'm late in responding. yes, this works satisfactory in recent Milestones.This issue can be closed in my oppinion. 52587	[KeyBindings] Delete key does not work in compare editor	"build I20040219While doing a sync, I opened a compare editor on a file with conflicts.Tried deleting some text using the Delete key, but it had no effect. What side of the compare editor did you try and delete stuff from? I have M7 andcan't dupe this. Left side.  I didn't notice it in M7 either.  Try the I build. I've noticed a few other places in the I build from Tuesday where the delete key doesn't work. For example, I can't delete a breakpoint from he Breakpoints view. Could this be a more general problem? This is caused by the binding of ""DEL"" in the default key binding set.  I  think I'm going to have to reconsider this.   This is a problem with some work that I've done.  I've removed the ""DEL"" binding from all key configurations.  Markus pointed out something that I hadn't found before.  The reason I was having problems getting this to work properly was that ""org.eclipse.ui.edit.delete"" wasn't registered as a global handler.  I have bound ""org.eclipse.ui.edit.delete"" to ""DEL"" in the default key configuration, added ""DEL"" as a special key (i.e., the widget with focus gets it first), and registered ""org.eclipse.ui.delete"" as global handler.  I'd encourage you to migrate key listeners to using handlers (as described).  (However, it is not necessary for your part to keep working.)  Verified with build 200403240800 "	2012-02-02 20:00:01	1328230000.0	resolved fixed	49a52cb	1328470000.0	java/org/apache/catalina/core/StandardEngine.java
52444	OSGI os alias returned instead of name.	"org.osgi.framework.BundleContext.getProperty( org.osgi.framework.Constants.FRAMEWORK_OS_NAME )should return canonical OS name rather than alias.So on Windows XP it should return ""WindowsXP"" rather than ""Windows XP"".Am using M7 btw. According to the OSGi R3 spec, the value for org.osgi.framework.Constants.FRAMEWORK_OS_NAME is not specifically specified to be the canonical OS name.  The value of ""Windows XP"" conforms to the OSGi R3 spec. The spec says this should be the canonical name and an OSGI framework thatdoesn't use the canonical name is pretty useless.  That is to say that ifthis isn't a canonical name then clients have to use heuristics to determinewhat the OS is. ( e.g. indexOf( ""win"" ) != -1 ).  This slop is no better thanif the client uses Sun's property ""os.name"" directly and therefore the frameworkisn't adding any value.As for where the spec says it should be canonical, section 4.9.3 ( page 77 )ends with ""Frameworks should try to convert these aliases to the canonical OS or  processor name. The bundle developer should use the canonical name in the  Bundle-NativeCode manifest header."" I like the phrase ""pretty useless"" :)Note that the spec has a ""SHOULD"" in it.  That is unfortunate since it leaves it open to OSGi framework developers to decide whether to implement it or not and will lead to these types of discrepancies.With that said I think we are well motivated to implement this ""SHOULD"" clause in the spec because of the issues outlined in this bug.I'm still not sure how this will fix your problem if you want to run on all Windows platforms.  Wont you still need to have indexOf( ""Win"" ) != -1 code to detect that you are on a Windows system? ""Note that the spec has a ""SHOULD"" in it.  That is unfortunate since it leaves it open to OSGi framework developers to decide whether to implement it or not and will lead to these types of discrepancies.""One of the things I have learned after a decade of software dev is that the usage of the word 'should' in specs is most often like the usage found in the sentence 'One should check both directions for oncoming traffic before crossing the street.'  ""Wont you still need to have indexOf( ""Win"" ) != -1 code to detect that you are on a Windows system?""Guess some people don't look both ways before crossing the street. ;)  Firstof all I don't just want to know if it is Windows as there are differencessignificant differences between the various windows operating systems.  Secondlyif I did want a course grained 'isWindows' check it would look like thecode below because the above check be incorrect on a platform that has ""Win""in the name but is not in fact a Microsoft Windows variant.  It would alsobe incorrect should MS follow Intel's lead and try to change the name to something more trade markable. ( Recall the whole 586/Pentium saga...)In fact I believe they have been trying to get everyone to switch from""Windows CE"" to ""Pocket PC""// example code    public boolean isWindowsOS()    {        final String os = context.getProperty( Constants.FRAMEWORK_OS_NAME );        boolean ret = false;        // See OSGI spec at www.osgi.org for list of Windows names.        final String[] winNames = new String[]        {            ""Windows95"", ""Windows98"", ""WindowsNT"", ""WindowsCE"", ""Windows2000"",             ""WindowsXP"",        };        for ( int i = 0; !ret && i < winNames.length; i++ )        {            ret = winNames[ i ].equalsIgnoreCase( os );        }        return ret;    } This fix has been checked into CVS. "	2012-01-09 17:11:12	1326150000.0	resolved fixed	f4896de	1327920000.0	java/org/apache/catalina/startup/ContextConfig.java java/org/apache/tomcat/util/bcel/classfile/JavaClass.java test/org/apache/catalina/startup/TestContextConfigAnnotation.java

52474	UI Blocked when opening Java Perspective during CVS check out	"build I20040218- start eclipse with a new workspace - switch to CVS Repository Exploring perspective- check out a number of projects ( i checkout Platform UI module)- now attempt to switch to the Java PerspectiveNOTE that at this point the ""UI is blocked"" dialog is opened.  Probably due to the fact that starting the Java Perspective requires the workbench lock?The point here is that this will be a common pattern and it would be nice if we could investigate makeing this scenario work more smoothly. Move to JDT/UI. This is the same issue Chris reported. I suspect plug-in activiation of the javaplug-ins is stuck because it needs to lock resources during initialization. Weeither need to avoid acquiring the lock in question, or attempt to solve thegeneral problem of part initialization being blocked by a background operation. John, at the Eclipsecon talk you had a plugin where you could start jobs thatblock the workspace. That would be really helpful for that kind of problems. Isthis plugin available? <Pyinson Data Over Head> Yes, the job examples plugin is very useful for finding and testing things likethis.  It is available at:http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/index.cgi/%7Echeckout%7E/platform-core-home/plan_concurrency.html Moving to debug for investigation. *** Bug 52441 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** <Pyinson Data Over Head> Also note that removing the JavaCore.run(...) function could re-break bug 34919. We intentionally added the batching to fix this bug.  We will soon provide a JavaCore.run() allowing to specify a scheduling rule, and batching behavior (if rule is null, no locking, but still batching). Great - could you add the related bug number to this bug - i.e. ""depends on""? Thanks. New JDT Core API got added. See bug 51045.Internals of JDT Core no longer lock when updating cp containers/variables, they still do the batching. <Pyinson Data Over Head> <Pyinson Data Over Head> Philippe, I'm not sure what scheduling rule to pass in. I'm just calling JCORE API to update classpaths, but I do not know what resources that may need to change. Can you suggest what rule I should use? No locking is what you should use. We are investigating on our end. It appears that the implementation of our classpath update mechanism (triggered through container update) is still causing some underlying locking.Will acquire. We cannot take less than a lock on the .classpath file. Made the change in HEAD and moving back to JDT UI to see if the Package Explorer can avoid asking the project for its children when it is checked out.Another possiblity would be for the CVS operation to not take a lock on the project during the whole operation. If there is a way to check for locks, then UI could draw each projects individually (with 'pending' for busy projects). This would avoid blocking the entire view while waiting on one project. The Package explorer content provider asks the JavaProject whether it has children to determine whether the ""+"" should be shown for the Java project.This is the calling sequence: 	JavaProject(JavaElement).getChildren() line: 221	JavaProject(Openable).hasChildren() line: 272	PackageExplorerContentProvider.hasChildren(Object)	PackageExplorerPart$6(AbstractTreeViewer).isExpandable(Object)Since we know that Java projects are never empty, i.e., they have a default package or a JRE container, JavaProject should provide a ""cheating"" implementation of hasChildren() (same as is done for class files):  public boolean hasChildren() throws JavaModelException {	if (isOpen()) {		return getChildren().length > 0;	} else {		return true;	}}Notice, that this would be useful optimization in general. moving to JDT Core It the raw classpath is empty, and .files are filtered out (default), then a project will be empty after being expanded. Just to correct myself in comment #17: I meant ""we cannot take less than a lock on the project"". Removing changes. Since the set classpath operation may need to update the .project file, we cannot take less than the workspace lock. >It the raw classpath is empty, and .files are filtered out (default), >then a project will be empty after being expanded.this is correct but the only consequence is that the ""+"" will show up. Once the user presses ""+"" then getChildren() is called and if there are no children then plus disappears.This means the consequence of the cheating hasChildren() implementation is some user frustration in some rare situation. So it is a classical trade-off. Given that the initial problem is really annoying we should consider making this trade-off. Notice, that the JavaModel is doing the same trick for JarPackageFragmentRoots. This is right. We will implement this. I was just observing that technically a project may end up being empty (but scenario is so rare that the optimistic approach is the best take). Made change suggested by Erich. Verified that the ""UI is blocked"" dialog is not opened in the original scenario. <Pyinson Data Over Head> The changes we made so far reduced the chances of the UI blockage, but when we restore the expansion state of a project it can still happen. The last resort is not restore the expansion state, which would make the start-up faster in general. It is tempting... Moving to JDT/UI to investigate ""not restoring the expansion state"" This would not be for M8, but it seems like the root of the problem is the eagerclasspath computation the first time a JavaProject is opened. This means that atheoretically ""read only"" query on the Java model results in acquiring writelocks on the workspace root. The entire stack trace above is triggered by asingle call in JDT UI to IJavaProject.exists().  It feels like clients of theJava model should be able to perform read-only queries such as exists() on themodel without fear of locking (and possible contention).It looks like this is caused by dynamic classpath containers, which causedownstream plug-ins to be loaded in order to obtain dynamic container contents.Would it be possible for JDT core to instead persist dynamic classpath containervalues across sessions (in metadata area), so it does not need to load containerinitializers at the start of each session? This is the approach taken inplatform core with the new dynamic project references.  Platform core persiststhe dynamic references so it does not need to keep asking for them. Clients areresponsible for setting dynamic references only when the values change. For M8 we will not store/restore the expansion state Verified that 200403260800 doesn't restore expansion state. FYI, in today's integration build JavaProject.exists() no longer populates the Java model. Thus it won't try to initialize classpath containers. *** Bug 56300 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Created attachment 10858stackReading through all the comments here I'm not sure how fixed this problemshould now be, but I hit this several times this morning during testing,whereas I've never seen this before with the exact same steps:- launch a brand new eclipse- open a CVS Repositories view in the main Resource perspective- in this view create a connection to dev.eclipse.org- begin retrieving the following projects from HEAD: org.eclipse.swt,org.eclipse.swt.examples, org.eclipse.swt.tests, org.eclipse.swt.win32- once this begins press the Run in Background button- switch back to the Navigator view- select .classpath_win32 file, right-click -> Copy- select the partially-retrieved org.eclipse.swt project, right-click -> Paste- it will eventually allow you to specify a new name for your pasted file, makeit "".classpath"" (no quotes), OK- change to the java perspective, becomes permanently busymy trace (taken from my self-hosted environment) is attached *** Bug 63281 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** The launching plugin synchronization is causing a deadlock here when initializing installed JREs and the JRE container. Fixed. Changes in JavaRuntime and LaunchingMessages.properties. We (Kevin & I) chose to fix this by performing the preference save (which eventually triggers a job to update the java model) in a job. Thus, the synchronized code in JavaRuntime never enters a job itself (and does not need the workspace lock), as the update is performed asynchrnously, in a job, by a different thread.We verified that we could reproduce the problem as shown in comment#34 without the fix, and the problem did not occurr with the fix. 52354	[KeyBindings] Shift+Suppr shortcut does no longer work	"I've just installed latest integration build I200402170800 and when I press on Shift+Suppr shortcut key, selected text is well removed but when I press on Shift+Inser, then this is an old content of clipboard which is pasted.Ctrl+X is still working.It sounds that the clipboard is not refreshed with the removed selected text... This problem is caused by a recent binding of ""org.eclipse.ui.edit.delete"" to ""Delete"".  The key binding architecture recognizes ""Shift+Delete"" as potentially an attempt to press ""Delete"" (i.e., ""Shift+1"" might really mean ""!"").  This can be fixed by making ""Delete"" a special case for this resolution process.  Fix in CVS.  Moving duplicate resolved (but not fixed) bugs to verified for M8. Reminder: be sure to tag all new API elements introduced in 3.0 with ""@since 3.0"". For new classes or interfaces, tagging the class or interface is sufficient. Created attachment 8364new patch with @since tags addedchanges from comment#12 Comment on attachment 8361defines two new interfaces to hold the constantsnew patch attached Having the optoin for someone else to contribute branding is intersting.  IProductProvider gives one that ability.  So i don't think we need any additional ability to programatically spec products or product values.  The workbench should be free to fetch these values however they like but keep in mind that we are putting forward this notion of ""product"" and people might use -product etc on the command line.  To then get the branding from somewhere else might be confusing. Regarding IBundleGroup.getName(), is this translated?  I assume so since the bundle group provider is a regular extension and can translate strings.If not, this is a difference from what we had before. I expect it to be translated. Previous comment should have read ""Re comment #18"".Note that TIPS_AND_TRICKS_URL has been renamed to TIPS_AND_TRICKS_HREF (same as about.ini) and is already resolved. Patch applied with some minor changes, which I'll go over with Andrew. The url format should be done either as absolute paths or as platform specific urls such asplatform:/base/plugins/some_plugin_id/windowImage.gifin which case you won't have to worry about primary plugin id being different than primary feature id.For example, the update bundle group provider will read the about.ini and return append it to platform:/base/plugins/primary_plugin_id/. Will you also resolve the $nl$ variable and friends?The constant definitions have been released to head in org.eclipse.ui.branding.IProductConstants and IBundleGroupConstants (in the org.eclipse.ui.workbench plugin).  They did not make it into our integration build submission today, however since you're not going to be referencing them directly anyway, I guess it doesn't matter.Can you have a look over these and let us know if anything is unclear?  Please check out what's in head rather than in the patches above. Dorian, please let us know when Update starts providing the values so that we can make progress on bug 54547 (name, appName, windowImage, windowImages needed for M8) and bug 54548 (the remaining IProduct and IBundleGroup values needed for M9).  The former is also blocking us from getting off the runtime compatibility plugin which we want to do for M8.Thanks,Nick Nick, I will try to do it tomorrow so we have it done by next integration build. I figured the simplest implementation is to take the existing AboutInfo class and modify it.As alluded to in an earlier comment, the return values for windowImage/featureImage would be URL's (unless you want String values), and Images must be created by the UI component. The reason is that the code that returns the values runs in non-ui plugins. The getProperty methods on IProduct and IBundleGroup only return Strings, so you'll have to return the (qualified, not partial) URLs in string form.  We'll create the images from those. Mea culpa...Once I started implementing it, I realized getProperty() returns String, not Object. I will probably have something for tonight's build, but I'll let you know. Closing, since the constants have been defined, and Update is now generating them (bug 54574).  Further changes to use IProduct are blocked by bug 54790. This is a reminder/placeholder for work that has been ongoing/pending but I can't find a matching report.Runtime has added IProduct to model the default primary feature and IBundleGroup to model features.  The UI gets various bits of information from the original entities and needs to adapt to the new structures.  After consulting with Nick, both IProduct and IBundleGroup were left open ended and UI ignorant.  Rather they provide a general getProperty() method.  The valid key value pairs are to be defined by the consumers/users of the objects.  So the UI should define the form of the information it needs for the product branding (e.g., windowImage, ...) and the about dialog.I don't know where this should be specified but the update team for example will need to know how to map the about.ini information onto IProducts and similarly, how to populate IBundleGroups. For IProduct, the properties include:- app name (a tag for the SWT Display, used on X systems)- product name    - shown in the window title in the SDK, e.g. ""Eclipse SDK""   - also on some actions (e.g. About)- about text and about image  - shown in the about dialog (which currently is in the IDE layer)- window image  - shown in the top left corner of workbench windowsFor IBundleGroup, we'll have:- image  - shown in the row below the about image in the about dialog- tip and tricks href (IDE layer)- welcome page URL (IDE layer)- welcome perspective id (IDE layer)We have discussed removing dependencies on IProduct and IBundleGroup from the Workbench proper, and obtaining the generic properties (e.g. product name, window image) from the WorkbenchAdvisor (or allowing it to configure these on the IWorkbenchConfigurer).  However, I'm having second thoughts about this now.  We should probably have a single story for how these properties are obtained, common across all RCP apps. Not quite sure what you mean about removing the dependency on IProduct and IBundleGroup.  These interfaces are there exclusively for the UI.  If you are not going to use them then we will delete them.  Not sure how the about dialog will get populated.  Assuming I got it wrong and you are going to use these at some level, teams like update need the exact keys they should have in the getProperty() collection when they produce an IProduct and IBundleGroup.   Need to define constant pools IProductConstants and IBundleGroupConstants in new package org.eclipse.ui.branding, with definitions for the existing properties used from about.ini.Should also define a windowImages property for bug 53172. Re comment #2, the about dialog will be changed to use IProduct and IBundleGroup as soon as we can get the properties we need from here.I assume Dorian is waiting on us for the constant defs.  Dorian, do you know when the change on your side will be made assuming we can get you the defs by Monday?We'll also change to get the product name and icon from IProduct.  But what I was debating here is whether this should be done by the Workbench proper or by the application.  That is, should the Workbench always just go to IProduct for these, or should it be the application's responsibility to configure the Workbench with these (it would be free to use IProduct or set them directly).Jeff, do you see any problem with giving the app flexibility here?  It would allow simple RCP apps to be able to configure the Workbench without requiring a product provider or bundle group provider. Nick, I see a problem with locating constants in org.eclipse.ui.branding, because the IProduct/IBundleGroup implementations are currently in update.configurator which has no ui dependencies.I have no problem moving them up to update.ui, but that is only easy to do for IProduct because it is contributed via an extension, but the IBundleGroup is done via registration and update.ui may not be running when you need it.I am on a course next week, but will be working evenings, and should be able to get this done by the end of the week. I think there needs to be a ""gentleman's agreement"" between UI and Update on these properties.  By putting these in a public UI interface, we are spelling out what the UI expects.  Update and other product/bundleGroup providers will need to supply these, but probably won't have UI as a prerequisite. *handshake* :-)Jeff, currently, there is no relationship between IProduct and IBundleGroup, and while IProduct is contributed as an extension, the IBundleGroup is registered with the platform (so the assumption is that the class that registers had been active before the UI asks for bundle groups).Will this change by end of 3.0 or will it stay as is? 50570	CatchClauseSignature has broken operation	"It looks like the getParameterName() operation on org.aspectj.lang.reflect.CatchClauseSignature is not working. Instead of returning the name of the exception as declared in the matched handler, returns the string value ""<missing>"".Here is a test case that shows the problem :-------START OF TEST CASE CODE-----------public class MyApp {    public void doSomething() {        // Get around ""unreachable code error...        if (true)        {            throw new BusinessException(""Surprise!!"");        }        System.out.println(""Busy doing something."");    }    public static void main(String[] args) {        try {            MyApp m = new MyApp();            m.doSomething();        } catch (BusinessException be) {            System.out.println(""Exception caught : "" + be.getMessage());         }    }}class BusinessException extends RuntimeException {    BusinessException(String message) {        super(message);    }}aspect AppMonitor {    pointcut problemHandling() : handler(Throwable+);    before() : problemHandling() {        CatchClauseSignature cSig =            (CatchClauseSignature) thisJoinPointStaticPart.getSignature();        System.out.println(            ""MONITOR::\tCaught a ""                + cSig.getParameterType().getName()                + "" called ""                + cSig.getParameterName());    }}------END OF TEST CASE CODE-----------The output from running the above was ...MONITOR::	Caught a BusinessException called <missing>Exception caught : Surprise !!!!Operating system : Windows XPAspectJ : 1.1.1 final and also on latest from CVS HEAD This is fixed in the tree for simple cases.  The parameter name will be correct when a store instruction is the first bytecode of the handler.  This appears to always be true for javac and the eclipse compiler.  Other compilers have not been tested.  Also, the code must have been compiled with -g mode for this parameter name to be visible in the bytecode.  If -g is not used or the handler doesn't match the typical pattern, then this name will revert to <missing> as before. 52051	[FloatingWindows] Floating Progress Window	"Several issues:1. The floating window should disappear if another view or editor gets focus2. The flowating window should disappear if the Progress Monitor view is openedIMHO the floating progress window is a big UI break. Some people prefer the ""old style"" progress report by text in the status line. The flowating view is unessary and adds unwanted UI clutter. If a user wants to see enhanced or detailed progress indication he can double click on the progress bar icon and the Progress view is opened. That is ok.You might consider changing this from a floating window into a tool tip like yellow bubble that informs the user about new progress but this should only stay visible for a few secondes (like the yellow bubbles used by Windows tray notifications). Currently you can still get the progress view by clicking the maximize button. Likewise clicking the minimize will remove it. That's not what people want. I don't want to see this ugly yellow window when working in Eclipse. There has to be an option to turn it of.IMHO this adds unwanted UI clutter to the workbench. The previouse solution without the extra popup window was preferable fine.Note, a UI has to be as smart as possible. This is not achieved by popping up windows everywhere somebody has something to tell. There is an option to turn it off. You you click the minimize button it will not open again unless you double click on the progress indicator. 51910	two session headers for the same log	"i20040212If something bad happens during startup, that may cause entries to be written tothe log. Since there are situations were the Eclipse Starter may throw anexception to the launcher (org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main), that exception willbe logged as well, causing a new SESSION header to be written to the log. Thatmay cause a lot of confusion. The session header should be written once (obviously) and by the log object itself. That object should remember that it wrote the session info and not do it again.  This may need to be protected from concurrent execution.Note that if logging happens while the log is in the config area and then happens again after the instance area is set, depending on the code (ie. ,if we create a new log object) there may be confusion between the SESSION entry in the copied config log and a SESSION entry written into the instance log. I see cases where the SESSION header is missing some elements, like the date.  This would be impossible from the FrameworkLog implementation.  Also the FrameworkLog implementation is synchronized so it should not be possible to get two SESSIONS written for the same running instance, we do not create a new log instance either when the instance area is set.  Is there some other code that does logging?  maybe from eclipse.exe or are these kinds of logs being written by org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main? My original description was not clear: the framework log will write a sessionheader only once. The problem is that if we end up throwing an exception fromthe EclipseStarter to org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main, that exception will belogged again by Main, which has its own logic for logging (does not rely on theFrameworkLog), and *always* write a session header before logging.This didn't happen in the past because Eclipse Boot/Runtime didn't log anythingduring startup, just threw an exception so Main would do it.Since we don't have as much control of when logging is done (for instance, anyFrameworkEvent.ERRORs will cause log entries to be written), I believe we shouldrethink the role of Main and stop relying on it for logging, maybe by capturingany exceptions in the EclipseStarter and exitting (with System.exit) from therein all cases (we currently exit from there only if everything goes fine). Correction for comment 3 above: where I said, ""that exception will be loggedagain by Main"", please read ""that exception will be logged by Main"". Code released in HEAD.
