50927	Difficulties with hidden files and folders	"I have difficulties understanding the policies for hiding files and directories on different platforms.On Unix and MacOS X the .metadata (and now the .config folders) are hidden.I have no problem with that.But I don't understand why most (but not all) files within these hidden directories are itself hidden too.On Unix and Mac OS X it is really a pain for ordinary users to find these hidden files (especially the .log file and now the .keyring files) within their hidden folders.And if a user has decided to look into a hidden folder .metadata, why can't she see the log file without further hassles?The additional odd thing here is that on Windows all this '.' business seems to have no effect at all, so ordinary users have access to everything in .metadata and .config without any hurdles.What am I missing here? This exact point was raised years ago. It is a valid argument, but questionablewhether it's worth the backwards compatibility pain that comes with renaming allour metadata files. I think this just became a convention without too muchthought going into it... as you said it never bothered anyone on Windows, andLinux command shell users just use ""ls -a"" to see them. I did notice that it wasparticulary hard to see these files on Mac, but interestingly my reaction was toblame the Mac UI for making the assumption that users will never want to seethese files. Even Windows lets me see hidden files if I want to :) I was raising this issue because we've just started to introduce another hidden folder "".config"" with a new set of hidden files and we do not seem to care a lot  about backward compatibility (e.g. .keyring :-) *** Bug 56988 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** You can do an ls -a in Mac OS X, too. However, there isn't an easy way to show them in the browser window (Mac's version of explorer) which makes it a real nightmare if you want to upload a copy of a log in a bug report.I think the same would also be true on Unix systems as well; I reported bug 56988 and had it set to 'Unix All' because you'd get the same problems on Linux/AIX/Solaris ...In fact, the only platorm that doesn't have this problem is Windows, and since Windows users can browse through these directories, they don't notice it's a problem.Andre, can you mark this bug as OS: Unix All and not be Mac-Platform dependent? Then I can verify my dup. [changed OS to ""Unix All"" per Alex's request]However, I'm glad that the (hidden) .config directory has been renamed to ""configuration"" *** Bug 79928 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Changing OS to ""all"", since this is even an issue for Windows users (see bug 79928). *** Bug 104640 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** I just started developing with eclipse on mac osx and copying eclipse projectswith the finder is a real pain."".something"" files are implizitly hidden and can only made visible by bogushacking of the macosX system. But what is much more annyoing - they are notcopied when contained in a folder that is copied.And sorry, telling users ""use the command line"" can't be nothing more than a badjoke. Backwordcompatibility shouldn't be much of a problem when renaming thesemetadata files. The import wizard could easily rename the files in ""old"" projects.It should prompt the user for permission to avoid unneccessary compatibilityproblems for users who need to be able to switch back to older versions. Andre, can you confirm whether copying a directory with Finder containing hiddenfiles will not copy the hidden files? I find this hard to believe... No, I cannot confirm this: I created a directory containg a file "".foo"", copied it in the Finder with Copy/Paste and the resulting duplicated folder still had the "".foo"".In addition, I don't understand why ""starting developing with eclipse on mac osx"" requires to copy invisible files...Even as a fulltime Eclipse developer, I only see a need for dealing with invisible files when debugging persistency stuff in .metadata (which was the original motivation why I've filed this bug).The .log file lives there too, but on Mac all log output is sent to the Console application by default, so there is no need to find the .metadata/.log I'm doing nothing special. I just copied projects from my windows pc to thenetwork (everything ok) then from the network share to the mac (lost the.projects files). Importing the projects into eclipse then obviously didn't work.The only workaround was to zip the projects first and then copy it to the mac. What network share are you exporting from the Mac? NFS, AFP or SMB?It might also be a problem with the Windows box in selecting the files,depending on the version of Windows that you've got installed. There's a viewoption that you can configure from an Explorer window (Tools -> Folder Options-> View -> Hidden Folders and Files -> Show hidden folders and files). If youdon't have this selected, then the Windows box may not upload dot files it toany remote box.This isn't anything to do with Eclipse per se; it's a combination of Windowscopying files to a remote share that's at fault. As already mentioned, the problem is not with windows but with the macos. Copying files from the windows pc to the network is no problem. The projectfolders on the network drive are ok, complete with project files and everything.But trying to copy the project folders to the local mac the finder always omitsthe (hidden) project files. The copy action is initiated by  dropping the rootfolder containing my projects folders (drag and drop).The result:pc: everything completenetwork drive: everything completemac: hidden project files missingMacosx 10.3.8network drive connected with appletalk (afp ?) PS: I have verified this with the shell (ls -a). You need to find out what the network drive is doing, and how you're mounting itor making it available on the mac. I've been able to do this with SMB(samba/windows file sharing), NFS and also AFP (the Apple Filing Protocol that'sused for sharing Mac-Mac shares) and all copy across the .project file fine.If your network drive is a standalone product (like a Lacie drive) then amake/model might be useful to know what server OS it's running to make themavailable. Chances are, it could be that the network drive is using an oldversion of Linux with an appletalk protocol that is automatically hiding the .files when the apple server asks for it ...Can you try the following mounts -- from Finder, Command+K to bring up aconnection window, and then try the following URLs:afp://mynetworkdrive/smb://mynetworkdrive/nfs://mynetworkdrive/and do the copies from each? You might find that the choice of network protocolmakes a difference; Mac can speak them all, but the network drive might have abroken AFP driver (the Linux 2.2 kernels were notoriously bad for such things).Windows should share it over SMB, so I'd expect to see that working exactly thesame way as the Windows box sees it. With smb it works so it must be a driver problem and I'll tell our sysadmins.But apart from that it is still problematic to use hidden files. The logfile problematic (see comment 4) is just one example of this. Moving to runtime.  The main issue seems to be with the .log file, which users often legitimately need to access.  The metadata files maintained by the resources plugin generally don't need to be seen by end users (with the exception of .project) Interestingly enough, among all the files that are hidden the one that matters the most is the one that is probably the most risky to change as it is tooled and expected to be in a welknown location. That said we can still investigate what it means to provide an option to rename it. Doesn't the workbench pick the name of the file by calling FrameworkLog#setFile when the workspace is choosen?  Looking at the EclipseLog code it seems that we do depend on a file name that ends in '.log' but other than that the framework does not care what the name is.As Pascal points out changing the file name will impact many others that depend on the file being just '.log'.  Also is changing the file name good enough?  Would we not also need to change the parent directory name (it is .metadata now when set by the workbench). *** Bug 134902 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 154230 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** We have no plans to make this change. I'm reopening this bug because it is still an issue that needs to be considered(at least newly introduced files and folders should *never* start with a '.')In addition I'm changing the summary (title) back to my original title:    ""Difficulties with hidden files and folders""I was never asking for ""Make the name of the log file parametrizable""so Thomas' resolution ""We have no plans to make this change""does not apply. Have you considered using visible symbolic links to the univisible files and folders?   Moving out of the Framework.  We have no plans to do anything about this issue in the framework. I'm not sure what is concretely being asked for us to do?  that is, what would we need to do to get this bug closed? - add an entry to http://wiki.eclipse.org/index.php/User_Interface_Guidelines that explains the issue (and provides a recommendation)- add a visible alias (link) for "".log"" (and may be "".metadata"") *** Bug 283406 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 283406 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** in the windows explorer you cannot name files or directories that start with a '.'. If you want to rename .metadata to .metadate.bak, the windows explorer does not allow you to do so. You could call it bak.metadata, but then there is no way in the windows explorer to rename it back to .metadata... So Architecture Council... this  was thrown at us two years ago. What are we going to do about it? Sounds like a best practice to me. Thoughts? I believe we did actually agree on a resolution to this:http://wiki.eclipse.org/Architecture_Council/Meetings/August_13_2009#bug_50927_-_JohnA_-_Convention_for_projects_to_use.2Fnot_use_hidden_foldersIn short the recommendation is:- Put metadata under "".settings"" when stored under a project in user's workspace- Put non-shared metadata under workspace "".metadata"" folder- Any metadata files and folders below those two locations should *not* start with a dot. 50929	Provide UI for showing call graph affected by flow advice	The effects of cflow advice can be challenging to infer and currently get no help from the tool support.  Now the at the IDEs are starting to show static call graphs, we can use this information to give the programmer an idea of the execution that will be affected by a cflow advice.  The attached mock-up shows a first pass at how this could look in AJDT. Created attachment 7639mockup of cflow advice showing up in the outline view That looks good for a first approch, I think. However I see two general problems: Firstly as you know a static cflow analysis is impossible. That in mind, one can easily see that the call hierarchy search that Eclipse uses at the moment is very rudimentary sinc eit just works on declared types and does not even try to approximate the runtime type. So I don't really know how useful such information could be, if one in a lot of cases must fear the information to be wrong.However I tried to integrate some more sophisticated analysis for Elipse last summer but did not finish them due to lack of time.Secondly: Usually we always have a correspondency between advice and adviced methods. One can always go back and forth using the annotations. However for a cflow I guess nobody would really want to annotate all the methods that could possibly be in a specific control flow. That would lead to some kind of inconsistency, though not a big one I have to admit. 	2011-03-14 11:08:56	1300120000.0	resolved fixed	0c96676	1300230000.0	java/javax/servlet/http/HttpUtils.java java/org/apache/catalina/connector/CoyoteInputStream.java java/org/apache/catalina/realm/JDBCRealm.java java/org/apache/catalina/valves/JDBCAccessLogValve.java java/org/apache/naming/resources/WARDirContext.java java/org/apache/tomcat/util/digester/NodeCreateRule.java

As well, the mouse scroll wheel does not scroll the outline when moved while on top of the member list. I see the request for size persistence is a duplicate of 37513. The lack of mouse wheel scrolling is still an issue though.  For me mouse wheel scrolling works. Can you explain what you mean with""the mouse scroll wheel does not scroll the outline when moved while on top ofthe member list."" First I want to make sure we're both talking about the popup outline window and not the dockable one (mouse wheel works in that one). With the popup outline, as I move the mouse over the window, focus (and highlight) follows the mouse position, but the mouse wheel has no effect. Mouse wheel scrolling works in other parts of the UI (e.g. editor, navigator views, etc.).I tried to ensure the popup has focus, by clicking either in the text entry area at the top or the ""footer"" (non-list) part, but still can't scroll the list when cursor is positioned above it.Also, although the sizing persistence issue for this outline window is reported in other bugs, I didn't see any kind of resolution. Any reason why? On further playing around with the popup outline view, I got the mouse wheel to scroll the list by initiating scrolling through click-and-drag on a member and holding the cursor at the top or bottom list edge and then releasing outside the list borders. I can't always get this to happen - mostly it doesn't, but I did get it 2-3 times. >First I want to make sure we're both talking about the popup outline window and >not the dockable one (mouse wheel works in that one)I think Navigate > Show Outline from comment 0 says it already ;-)The reason why it is not working is because you probably set your mouse to onlytrack active windows, however the fast popup is not a full fledged window. Ifyou want your mouse to be able to scroll then enable it to also scrollnon-active windows, this will do the trick.BTW: clicking into entry field or footer cannot work: those widgets have noscroll bars - the scroll bars belong to the tree widget. I'm using Windows 2000 with a generic mouse driver (MS PS/2 compatible) and I don't see any option in the control panel applet to set any properties for the scroll wheel. The reason I was clicking on the entry field or footer was just to make sure that the popup the list was a child of _was_ the active window - I only attempted to scroll the list while the cursor was positioned above it. I'm at a loss then as to what to do since, as I mentioned before, scrolling with the wheel works fine with any other scrollable window/view.Also, could you say anything about the size persistence issue? Did you install the driver that comes with your mouse? This should offer toconfigure you this. No, it's just a cheapo MS compatible mouse - I suspect that the majority of people don't install a driver for their mouse and just use the default. This is my work machine, but I can say that even for my computer at home where I have a pretty good mouse, I didn't install the specific driver since, alongside, it installs some bloatware with features that are non-essential.  My standard WindowsXP mouse driver allows to set this - so maybe this isn'tavailable under Windows2000. Try a Win2k forum. Can confirm bug using a standard PS/2 on WinXP. Not even TweakUI offers toscroll non-active windows and even if I choose to activate the window over whichthe mouse is (again via TweakUI) scrolling does not work for the Quick Outline.Moving to SWT for comments.Note: we use the following flags:int shellStyle= SWT.RESIZE;int treeStyle= SWT.V_SCROLL | SWT.H_SCROLL; Mousewheel scrolling of non-active windows has been requested in the past, but swt is not going to get in the way of the platform to make it happen in places where it's not configured to.  While there are some applications like IE that do this, this is a feature of the application and not of the underlying widgets.*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 49816 *** All I can say is that without mouse wheel scrolling, the original summary of this bug - usability of the quick outline - is seriously affected since the other issue I brought up, the persistence of the popup window's size, doesn't look like it will be addressed. I mean if it is going against the platform behaviour to have scrolling in this case, the size of of the popup should be persisted so that the need for scrolling is be reduced. As it is, almost every time I use the quick outline, I have to resize it, and possibly drag the scroll bar button. Not too nice. Adrian, SWT will not override the default platform behavior.  If you think that the problem can be addressed somehow in Platform/UI (ie. ""... size of popup should be persisted ...""), reopen the bug there.  Thanks. 50855	Opening a very large sequence diagram hangs the UI	The vast majority of the time is spent loading the model, not drawing the diagram. There is a progress monitor dialog, but it is frozen and the user cannot cancel, even though the cancel button is enabled. All the work is still being done in the UI thread.The solution involves forking a new thread to perform all the work except UI work. As far as displaying progress, displaying a dialog may be too intrusive. I will consider alternatives. Solution:The EMF model and UI model will both be loaded in a background thread. While the diagram is loading, a loading page is displayed. As soon as the thread completes, it signals the UI thread to display the diagram.This allows the user to perform other tasks while waiting (it is not a blocking operation). If the user closes the view, the thread is signalled to stop, and will halt at the next appropriate time. It is the thread's responsibility to poll for this, otherwise the task will run to completion. If a new diagram is requested while loading, the current diagram is cancelled and a request is made to start on the new diagram. There is at most one thread loading diagrams at any time, and it will terminate itself when no longer needed.If the user refreshes, a notification is placed in the title of the sequence diagram view (Refreshing... for english). Again, the user is free to do other things while it is refreshing. As soon as the diagram is ready, it is displayed, and the notification is removed from the view title. Fixed in 1.3 and HEAD Closing bug. house keeping 	2011-03-02 11:19:27	1299080000.0	resolved fixed	b24b0c0	1299400000.0	java/org/apache/catalina/authenticator/AuthenticatorBase.java

The following works for me:public static void main (String [] args) {	Display display = new Display ();	Shell shell = new Shell (display);	shell.setBounds(10,10,350,300);	Table table = new Table (shell, SWT.MULTI | SWT.BORDER | SWT.FULL_SELECTION);	table.setBounds(10,10,330,150);	table.setLinesVisible (true);	table.setHeaderVisible (true);	String[] titles = {""title1"", ""title2"", ""title3""};	for (int i=0; i<titles.length; i++) {		TableColumn column = new TableColumn (table, SWT.RIGHT);		column.setText (titles [i]);		column.setWidth(100);	}		int count = 5;	for (int i=0; i<count; i++) {		TableItem item = new TableItem (table, SWT.NULL);		item.setText (0, ""x"");		item.setText (1, ""y"");		item.setText (2, ""!"");	}	shell.open ();	while (!shell.isDisposed ()) {		if (!display.readAndDispatch ()) display.sleep ();	}	display.dispose ();} Hi,It took me quite a while, but I figured out that it has to do with the table being within a SashForm. Your code works, unless you put it in a sashForm (all my tables seem to be within sashForms). You will (hopefully) see that some right aligned column's header text doesn't show up:public class TV {  public static void main(String[] argv) {    Display display = new Display ();    Shell shell = new Shell (display);    shell.setLayout(new GridLayout());       SashForm sashForm = new SashForm(shell, SWT.NONE);        createTable(sashForm);    createTable(sashForm);        shell.open ();    while (!shell.isDisposed ()) {      if (!display.readAndDispatch ()) display.sleep ();    }    display.dispose ();  }    public static void createTable(SashForm parent) {        Table table = new Table (parent, SWT.MULTI | SWT.BORDER | SWT.FULL_SELECTION);    table.setBounds(10,10,330,150);    table.setLinesVisible (true);    table.setHeaderVisible (true);     for (int i=0; i<8; i++) {      TableColumn column = new TableColumn (table, SWT.RIGHT);      column.setText (""title"");      column.setWidth(100);    }     int count = 5;    for (int i=0; i<count; i++) {      TableItem item = new TableItem (table, SWT.NULL);      item.setText (0, ""x"");      item.setText (1, ""y"");      item.setText (2, ""!"");    }      }  } I see it with your snippet. 50631	Hook for resource scheduling rule factory	I20040121I have released new API that allows clients to ask for the scheduling rule forvarious operations (copy, move, delete, validateEdit, setContents, etc).  Manyof these rule requirements actually vary based on the repository provider (forexample CVS needs to lock the parent folder for most operations).  Core needs toexpose something in the TeamHook to allow repository providers to provide a rulefactory. See bug 46753 for more detailed discussion. Increasing priority. This must happen for 3.0 or all non-CVS team providers willbe stuck with the hard-coded rules we are specifying for validateEdit, etc. I suspect bug 57668 occurred because a 2.1 provider (ClearCase) obtained the workspace lock in the vaidate Edit callback. It's unfortunate but I think we need to make the default rule for validate edit the workspace to ensure that 2.1 pessimistic providers still work in 3.0. We would also need to make sure that 3.0 providers override the rule with a rule of lower granularity. I agree that workspace root will have to be the default rule when a non-3.0provider is installed on a project. I am worried now that people upstream may bemaking hard-coded assumptions about what locks are acquired in core methods.  Ineed to get this done soon so we can iron out the bugs. <Pyinson Data Over Head> Yes, this will be fixed in a way that allows for backward compatibility forolder team providers.  Priority P1 means we won't ship Eclipse 3.0 without it. I have released new methods on TeamHook to allow repository providers to changethe scheduling rules used for all workspace modifying operations.  The TeamHookthen needs to delegate this down to the RepositoryProvider API.Moving to Team component for remaining implementation work. *** Bug 57675 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 58593 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** I have released the changes for Team and CVS. Leaving open as a reminder to test the effects of the pessimistic rule factory on Eclipse in general (i.e. is everyone a good citizen?) *** Bug 57668 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** It would be nice to mark this as fixed. Having open P1 bugs this close to therelease does not look good. If the remaining issue is testing, we can open aseparate bug report for writing tests. GOod enough. Closing *** Bug 62589 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** 	2011-01-21 13:23:52	1295630000.0	resolved fixed	0084470	1296550000.0	java/org/apache/coyote/http11/InternalNioInputBuffer.java

Sure, but org.eclipse.draw2d and gef arn't pre M6 plug-ins any more (current CVS HEAD).However, I don't see a relation of adding plugin ""org.eclipse.core.runtime.compatibility"" to the dependency list and solving missing ""org.eclipse.swt*"" classes which are neither exported by the binary swt plugin nor by the binary swt.win32 fragment.""org.eclipse.draw2d"" and ""org.eclipse.gef"" can only depend on ""org.eclipse.swt"". I had very similar problems with source projects --possibly the cause was the same -- in my case theyturned out to be caused by an incomplete .classpathin org.eclipse.swt, which listed only two of the manysource folders. It happened after I had deleted.classpath and then used PDE Tools:Update Classpath,but I may have done something else as well; now if Idelete, then update, I get the correct .classpath back. Using M7, I did all the steps in the original bug report epilogue and all the steps in comment #5, and everything worked like a charm.By the way, classpath containers are the only way to compute a classpath by PDE as of M7, and have absolutely nothing to do with how you import.As for comment #6, it is unrelated to this bug report.  But it seems that org.eclipse.swt was checked out from CVS.  The swt team has a special setup for this project, the project comes with many .classpath_* files, one per platform.  After checking out, you need to rename the .classpath_* file that is suitable to your environment to "".classpath"".  This is a must if you check out swt from cvs.  If you import swt using PDE's external plug-ins wizard, PDE will then set up your classpath correctly. 50683	Improve DOM/AST support for doc comments	The current API for doc comments has a flat text string.This is not helpful for clients that want to analyze or change the structure of doc comments. For M7, we have made the following changes to the DOM/AST API:- added Javadoc.tags() to represent structure of the doc comments- deprecated Javadoc.get/setComment- added 5 new node types that occur only within doc comments:    TagElement, TextElement, MemberRef, MethodRef, MethodRefParameter- tag elements like MemberRef, MethodRef, and Name can carry binding information (must be requested like elsewhere)- added ASTVisitor(boolean) for controlling whether Javadoc.tags() are visited by default- added ASTMatcher(boolean) for controlling whether Javadoc.tags() are compared vs. only Javadoc.getComment()- AST.parse*(...) now returns structured doc comments (for compatibility, Javadoc.getComment() is also set as before) Reopen to assign it to me Test cases need to be completed... *** Bug 46126 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Verified for 3.0M7 *** Bug 25316 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** 	2011-01-28 18:36:29	1296260000.0	resolved fixed	d21437e	1296260000.0	java/org/apache/naming/resources/WARDirContext.java

50679	NPE in DefaultClassLoader.findClass()	Eclipse 3.0 M6 - WindowsI've been using M6 for a while with no problems but this morning I tried to debug a runtime-workbench and the debug display view was not instantiated. Will attach the .log file. Created attachment 7587.log After reseting the perspective, the view was instantiated. I have seen this problem before and I thought a bug was already open but I cannot seem to find one.It looks like the process to create the classloader has a hole that will allow another thread to try and load a class on the classloader before it is fully initialized. *** Bug 50620 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** This seems to be the same as bug 48763. According to Pascal, it is believed tobe fixed after M6. *** Bug 50510 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** I do not think this problem has been fixed.  There is potential for the classloader slot of a BundleLoader to get set before the classloader has been initialized.  This would allow another Thread to call loadClass on it which would cause a NPE in findClass().I will check in a fix for this, but this area of the code also has the Double-Checked Locking Problem (see defect 50679) which could cause other problems if two threads try to create the classloader at the same time. A fix has been checked into HEAD. 	2011-01-28 03:22:33	1296200000.0	resolved fixed	2377f51	1296250000.0	java/org/apache/catalina/ha/ClusterDeployer.java java/org/apache/catalina/ha/deploy/FarmWarDeployer.java java/org/apache/catalina/ha/deploy/FileMessage.java java/org/apache/catalina/ha/deploy/FileMessageFactory.java java/org/apache/catalina/ha/deploy/UndeployMessage.java

50606	workspace location is not always fully qualified	"Quoting John:The recently released changes in runtime are causing many resources plugin tests to fail.  There were two lines in the old code (InternalPlatform.setupMetaArea) that did this://try infer the device if there isn't one (windows)if (location.getDevice()==null)	location = new Path(location.toFile().getAbsolutePath());It looks like this code was lost in the refactoring to support platforms without a data area.  If you don't do this, and you specify a ""-data"" area without a device, then there are many places where location comparisons fail to match because sometimes there is a device and sometimes there isn't. This sequence needs to be added back, in some central place when the location is being initialized, to be sure that it always has a device. Fixed in HEAD. 50597	Enhancement request: need drawGlyph API in draw2d.Graphics	"Now we are requesting SWT team to expose drawGlyph() API to the public.When it is available, could you add an API wrapping it to draw2d.Graphics? Absolutely.  Please mark this bugzilla as depending on the SWT feature request and we'll get notified when it is available. Thank you very much.  This is necessary for bidirectional language support. Saitoh-san,I didn't understand the entire discussions in bug 6782 and the newer bidi layout bug.  But, it looks like the work is still in progress, even though your bug is ""resolved"".We will definitely add the glyph support immediately when SWT exposes it.  Of course I may not realize when they expose it, so feel free to update this bugzilla.Also, GEF definitely needs to support WYSIWYG text editing similar to page designer.  We should work together after 3.0/6.0 to understand BiDi, since that is the main reason GEF has not tried to support text editing.Thanks! Each Arabic character has four possible glyphs depending on the context.For drawString() API, only the text being drawn can be the context.  However there are cases we can not pass the appropriate text as the context.  For examaple, if we draw 'he' in blue and draw 'llo' in red, we will call drawString() twice, one for 'he' in blue and another for 'llo' in red.  While we should pass the whole word 'hello' as the context, we can not do it.  As the result, we will have the wrong glyphs for 'e' and 'l.'To avoid this, we want to separate retrieving glyphs from drawing them.  SWT's BidiUtil has APIs for them though it is in an internal package.  This is why we have requested them to expose BidiUtil to the public via Bug6782. But they may implement similar APIs in TextLayout class, which is a public class they are still working on, instead of exposing the BidiUtil.  Either way is okay for us as long as the APIs are public.  Anyway, I will inform you if they finish their work.I am very happy to work with you to understand Bidi. > For examaple, if we draw 'he' in blue and draw 'llo' in red, we will calldrawString() twice, one for 'he' in blue and another for 'llo' in red.  While weshould pass the whole word 'hello' as the context, we can not do it.  As theresult, we will have the wrong glyphs for 'e' and 'l.'What you could probably do is paint the entire ""hello"" twice - once in blue,then in red, and just *clip* the 'he' area for the first paint, and the 'llo'area for the second. Thank you very much for your suggestion.  I agree that it works fine for the example I wrote but I have other motivations to request drawGlyph().While drawString() reorders the characters automatically but it must not be done in some cases.We will already have the glyph information when drawing the text because the information is needed for the calculation of caret postion and layout. Cannot implement this until the fonts and colors are exposed in TextStyle. fixed in M9 > 0526This does not work well at all for TextLayouts which have a width and wrap. 18797	Evaluation that hits breakpoint confuses debugging	"Jdk1.4.1_b11Source will be attachedSet breakpoints on lines 21 and 39Debug to a breakpoint at line 21From the editor, display, ""this.hitBreakpoint()""you hit the breakpoint at line 39, but the thread still claims to be evaluating, no indication of the breakpointHit Run to ReturnYou are back at line 21, but the thread still claims to be stepping, and the stepping actions are not enabled.Click resume and things are back to normal. Created attachment 1184Sample.java source Reproduced with simpler test case.When we hit a breakpoint while evaluating, the thread shows as ""Evaluating"" because the thread still knows that it's in an evaluation. I'm not sure this is really a problem, as this feedback (""You're suspended inside an evaluation"") may be more useful than the standard breakpoint feedback.The broken state after the Step Return appears to be a timing problem, as the bug goes away when debugging. When I hit a breakpoint during an eval, and press resume, things work as expected. However, when I do a step over at the breakpoint in the evaluation, things work badly - the UI hangs for about 20 seconds, and the thread state is confused. Marking as F4 candidate I have debugged it a little, using the following test case (using JUnit):(1) Place a breakpoint on the first line of VectorTest.testCapacity() [line 32](2) Place a breakpoint in TestCase.toString() [line 193](3) Launch VectorTest(4) Hit first breakpoint in ""testCapacity()"".(5) In the display view, evaluate ""this.toString()""(6) hit second breakpoint (druing evaluation)(7) Press step overAt this point the evaluation completes. The evaluation has the correct result, but the UI blocks for 20 seconds waiting for the details to be computed (which fails). However, the problem is that when I press ""step over"" in the middle of an evaluation, the evaluation should not complete - it should step. ARCH team approval: The consequence of not fixing this is that the debugger behaves poorly when a breakpoint is hit during a user evaluation, and a user performs stepping at that breakpoint. The UI can hang for 20 seconds, and a debug session can become corrupt (the debug model state is no longer in synch with the running target). There are two problem in this case. First, the call of the toString() method on the result of the evaluation is donealmost synchronously in the UI thread. If this method takes time to be evaluateor if there is a probleme during the evaluation, the UI blocks until the end ofthe evaluation or the timeout. The asyncexec call should be delayed until thestring result is computed.The second problem looks like a Sun VM problem. After the step over, the valueof the toString() call is returned, as if the evaluation was completed. But thestop stack frame is not correct, the thread seems to be stop in theString.toString() method. And the VM does not answer when we try to evaluate toString() on the result of the evaluation.The problem occurs with Sun VM 1.3.1 and 1.4.1 b02 b10 b11.The same test case has the right behaviour with the J9 VM.I cannot reproduce the problem with jdb.Need more investigation on this problem. Needs more investigation. Removing as F4 candidate until we have complete fix. Comment from JaredB:This is a total mess. We should disable breakpoints during all evaluations for 2.0. We've observed that the following series of events is occurring:VM            Debugger  --BP event-->  <--invoke start--  --BP event-->  <--step start--  --invoke end-->  <--invoke start-- (eval toString())  --step end--> (stop in toString()) This appears to be a VM problem, but our code isn't helping the situation - there's a VM bug here, but we can avoid it.The fix is for JDIThread#invokeComplete() to call JDIThread#abortStep(). This way we delete the pending step request when an invoke completes, thus avoiding the Sun VM bug.This also fixes our problem with J9 in this scenario, since J9 doesn't send us a StepEnd notification when a step results in an invoke completion. Previously, if you stepped out of a suspended evaluation on J9, our stepping buttons never reenabled because we never got the StepEnd we were waiting for. Aborting the step solves this problem. ARCH approval: The consequence of not fixing this is that our debug model can be come ""out of synch"" with its corresponding target. A user may end up killing a debug session becuase of this. The fix is straight forward, but the frequency of a user running into this problem is not known. The problem only occurrs when you step out of an evaluation. Stepping within an evalution and resuming to complete the evalaution works as is. Note: with this fix, the ""UI hang"" does not occurr. The hang was occuring, because the ""step end"" event received after the evaluation completed caused the target VM to suspend, thus preventing the ""toString"" evaluation to complete. Released fix to HEAD. Waiting for F4 approval. Verified. "	2003-04-08 06:33:14	1049800000.0	resolved fixed	51650a1	1294940000.0	java/org/apache/catalina/users/MemoryUserDatabase.java

49543	"Ole: Invoke should fill in the ""out"" parameters on return"	Currently, any VT_BYREF values returned when calling OleAutomation.invoke(...) are cleared and discarded before the invoke method returns.  Values should be copied into the provided Variant objects. 50547	MessageBox locks out application	"The following scenario causes SWT to lock under SWT for windows. A parent shellX is created and opened. Then, a text entry dialog Y (a child of the X) isopened titled ""X"". In this scenario, given the nature of the dialog, it is ofstyle APPLICATION_MODAL. At some point while Y is open, the application mustpresent an important error message. So, a MessageBox Z, also a child of X (or Y,same effect) is created and opened titled ""Z"". MessageBox Z will of course stayon top within the application which is intended. However, the taskbar at thebottom (under win2k) will list windows ""X"" and ""Z"". If you select ""X"" at thebottom, it will put windows X and Y on top and beep at any mouse or key click.Clicking ""Z"" at the bottom does not redraw Z back on top and the screen remainswith X and Z displayed. Because the user must click okay in the message box (andis prevented from doing so, this effectively locks out the application forcing amanual termination to exit the program. Based on my testing this seems to bebecause the SWT thread is locked in a wait until the MessageBox (Z) is exited,so any redraw or other SWT requests are postponed indefinitely. As a side note, this assumes that shell X is larger and entirely overlaps Z asif it does not, the user can still activate Z by seleting the titlebar via themouse.  Regardless, trying to switch it via taskbar (which is the only option ifX overlaps Z) fails. It seems strange that clicking Z in the taskbar does not bring it back on top of X.  Snippet:public static void main (String [] args) {	Display display = new Display ();	final Shell x = new Shell (display);	x.setBounds(10,10,800,800);	x.setText(""X"");	Shell y = new Shell (x, SWT.APPLICATION_MODAL | SWT.DIALOG_TRIM);	y.setText(""Y"");	y.setBounds(200,200,200,200);	Text text = new Text (y, SWT.SINGLE);	text.setBounds(10,10,50,30);	text.addListener(SWT.KeyDown,new Listener() {		public void handleEvent(Event event) {			MessageBox z = new MessageBox(x);			z.setText(""Z"");			z.setMessage(""you typed something"");			z.open();		}	});	x.open ();	y.open ();	while (!x.isDisposed ()) {		if (!display.readAndDispatch ()) display.sleep ();	}	display.dispose ();} This seems to work better on XP.  You can eventually get the MessageBox back.  The problem is that there is no standard for modal behavior on Windows.  SWT disables shells and this seems to interfere with the MessageBox's idea of modal.The problem doesn't seem to happen when SWT shells are used:public class PR_50547 {public static void main (String [] args) {		 final Display display = new Display ();		 final Shell x = new Shell (display);		 x.setBounds(10,10,800,800);		 x.setText(""X"");		 Shell y = new Shell (x, SWT.APPLICATION_MODAL | SWT.DIALOG_TRIM);		 y.setText(""Y"");		 y.setBounds(200,200,200,200);		 Text text = new Text (y, SWT.SINGLE);		 text.setBounds(10,10,50,30);		 text.addListener(SWT.KeyDown,new Listener() {		 		 public void handleEvent(Event event) {//		 		 		 MessageBox z = new MessageBox(x);		 		 		 Shell z = new Shell(x, SWT.SHELL_TRIM | SWT.APPLICATION_MODAL);		 		 		 z.setText(""Z"");		 		 		 z.pack();//		 		 		 z.setMessage(""you typed something"");		 		 		 z.open();						 while (!z.isDisposed ()) {						 		 if (!display.readAndDispatch ()) display.sleep ();						 }		 		 }		 });		 x.open ();		 y.open ();		 while (!x.isDisposed ()) {		 		 if (!display.readAndDispatch ()) display.sleep ();		 }		 display.dispose ();}} Fixed > 20040130NOTE: It is not possible to get the MessageBox to come to the front. 10526	[Decorators] Decorator mechanism does not allow for optimizations	At present our decorators show up piecemeal because we do them in a background thread and thus the order they appear is 'random'.The way we decorator mechanism works does not allow us to optimize in some areas.  Specificly:1. The icon and text are asked for separately. This requires us to go to our sync info twice, which is on disk and expensive to get.2. The decorators are asked individually.  In the case of CVS, all the sync info for sibling resources is in the same file, so its faster for us to determine all their decorators at once.3. In order to avoid doing work in the UI thread, we create a background thread to generate the decorators.  When then need to tell the UI via an event that we now have decorators, and then they ask us for them.  It would be better if we could just give the UI the decorators we know about all at once.Note: to be a good citizen we should be computing the decorators in a thread different than the UI context.The combination of #2 and #3 could result in the decorators appearing in parent child ordering, with all siblings appearing at once. Investigate for M5. We are investigating a solution for 1.For 2, we discussed this yesterday and it seems like this is no longer problematic for VCM.For 3, as mentioned yesterday, we need to come back and ask for the decoration again in order to apply decorations in the correct order.As for the order of appearance, I will be looking a TreeViewer update and may change it to process items in pre-order rather than top-down There is a solution for 1 in build 20020402. We now also allow for a LabelProviderChangedEvent to take multiple items so the number of requests for decoration will now be reduced dramtically. Reopening and assigning to NE as he is investigating the TreeViewer optimizations. CVS decorator is now performant enough.Need to reconsider decorators post 2.0. Reopen to investigate Significant performance work was done in 3.0 and 3.1. You are now passed andIDecoration and can do everything with that. 	2002-07-06 13:11:40	1025980000.0	resolved fixed	ca34a30	1292430000.0	java/org/apache/catalina/authenticator/AuthenticatorBase.java

As soon as you choose to use a custom doclet, the standard doclet options don't apply anymore. Each doclet can define it's own set of arguments (of course your doclet could decide to use the standard options) so we can't add them.An improvement of the wizard would be to allow you to specify that your doclets uses the standard options so the pages are still visible.I'm afraid we won't have time to improve the Javadoc wizard in regard to custom doclets. 50448	Unable to load class (exception in Bundle.loadBundleActivator)	"<Pyinson Data Over Head> This bug was also reported on the mailing list by two other people:http://dev.eclipse.org/newslists/news.eclipse.platform/msg12130.htmlhttp://dev.eclipse.org/newslists/news.eclipse.platform/msg12208.html Here is another message in the mailing list about this problem:  http://dev.eclipse.org/newslists/news.eclipse.platform/msg11621.htmlFrom this posting:  The problem I guess was that I did not had default empty  constructor. When extending my plugin from AbstractUIPlugin  I had to provide one. But this create incompatability with  AbstractUIPlugin (it has only one implicit constructor  AbstractUIPlugin(IPluginDescriptor descriptor)). It is not  possible just set it to ""null"" in super() call because  you'll fail on assertion. I guess it is possible to mock it,  but I didn't go further. Instead I just extended my plugin  from Plugin class.  If I derrive my Plugin from org.eclipse.core.runtime.Plugin instead of org.eclipse.ui.plugin.AbstractUIPlugin, and add an empty constructor!!, I have no problem.I tryed to remove the dependency on org.eclipse.osgi from the plugin.xml, but (for some reasons, I don't understand), I cannot. If I do so, I the the following error:   The project was not built since its build path is incomplete.   Cannot find the class file for org.osgi.framework.BundleActivator.   Fix the build path then try rebuilding this project.I have no idea what generates this dependeny.... As a point of interest, are you writing your own manifest.mf or are you putting the runtime related mark up in the plugin.xml?  The question I really want to ask is ""what is you bundle activator class"" OK, all I do is to try to port some 2.1.2 plugins to 3.0. Therefore I use theplugin.xml. I have no knowledge of OSGI (except I know in principle what it is)and I am not using it currently (so, no manifest.mf). I was surprized thateclipse forces me to depend on the osgi plugin. I thought that osgi would beinvisible to me.... Can you outline the steps you took to ""port"" your plugin?  That is, what tools if any did you use, etc.I ask because all of Eclipse and other products run with no changes and no knowledge of OSGi.  I suspect that something has been upset during your porting process.  either that or you have a usecase that is new to us and is not correctly handled.You certainly should not not have to know about OSGi unless you want to. The same happens to me when I deploy our plugins targetted originally at Eclipse2.1.2 into the 3.0M6 version. The upper part of the stacktrace is exactly thesame, although in our case, the exception gets thrown during adding a nature toproject's description.I have done no porting as far as I can tell.I have two dependent plugins: ...schema.core and ...schema.ui (ui depends oncore). The UI plugin activates fine, and can show a Wizard. When the Wizardattempts to add nature ID to the project description (nature is registered bythe core plugin), this exception is thrown.The ui plugin declares proper dependency on core (and works fine on Eclipse 2.1.2) I just got the same error when I tried to execute an action from the relengplug-in using I20040203. Adding      <import plugin=""org.eclipse.core.runtime.compatibility"" optional=""true""/>to the required plug-ins section fixed the problem. Here is what it seems to be happening: plug-ins not having a <?eclipseversion=""3.0""?> tag or requiring org.eclipse.core.runtime.compatibility areconsidered old-style plugins, that need more complete support for backwardscompatibility. The plugin class for new plugins must have a no-arg constructor(as BundleActivators do). The plugin class for old plugins must have aconstructor taking a IPluginDescriptor.It also happens that currently PDE generates plugin manifests that are tagged as3.0 but have an old style plug-in class (which inherits from AbstractUIPlugin) -I just opened a PR to handle this issue: bug 51206. For completeness: the instantiation exception happens because (as pointed out incomnment 3) the plugin class constructor does not match its plugin style. >the plugin class constructor does not match its plugin style.Can you comment a bit more on that. The plug-in has:	/**	 * The constructor.	 */	public RelEngPlugin(IPluginDescriptor descriptor) {What's wrong with that? Most Eclipse plug-ins have this and only this constructor.Note: The plug-in has <?eclipse version=""3.0""?> tag Also note: there must be some changes in recent builds (meaning in the last 1 or2 weeks) which changed in that area since we could use the releng plug-in beforewithout problems. A 3.0 plug-in that is not in backward compatibility mode (from the viewpoint ofruntime/OSGi) has a plugin class whose constructor takes no arguments (yours isan example of one that requires 2.1 style support from runtime). Currently, a plugin is consided ""new style"" if it has the <?eclipseversion=""3.0""?> processing instruction *and* does not requireorg.eclipse.core.runtime.compatibility.Your problem is that your original manifest was for a ""new style"" plugin,although your plugin class has a 2.1 style constructor (expectingIPluginDescriptor). Requiring org.eclipse.core.runtime.compatibility tellsruntime that your plug-in is a 2.1 style plug-in (again, from the runtime pointof view - the ""eclipse"" processing instruction has a broader meaning).Pascal, Jeff, comments? Thanks for the info. I filed bug 51239 against Platform Releng which own thetool. It surprised my because it did not strike me when OSGi came into life butwith a recent build. Keeping the PR open so Jeff/Pascal can confirm the observed behavior is what isexpected (I don't think this is documented anywhere yet). the Plugin class has to have the default constructor IF it is used as the Bundle-Activator.  The default transformation of the plugin.xml to manifest.mf puts a standard backward compatibility bundle activator in the manifest.mf as the activator and lists the Plugin class in another header.  when the compatibility activator is run, it looks at this other header and creates/invokes the plugin class as normal.Pascal put in some code recently which was supposed to make this more backward compatible but we may have gotten it wrong.  I;ll try to find pascal and ask about it.  Marking as M7 P1 Hmmm... so it seems bug 51206 is invalid... Please advise as to whether it makes sense to provide a 0-arg constructor in AbstractUIPlugin. AbstractUIPlugin must provide a 0-arg constructor to allow real bundles to inherits from AbstractUIPlugin.I think this fixis already in. Just for clarity, let's summarize the different behavior that are / should be supported.1 - Unconverted 2.1 plugin. The bundle activator will be the default activator provided by runtime (PluginActivator) and the plugin-class specified in the plugin.xml will be used.2 - Plugin.xml containing eclipse 3.0 tag, and requirements containing org.eclipse.core.runtime.compatibility. The bundle activator will be the default activator provided by runtime (PluginActivator) and the plugin-class specified in the plugin.xml will be used.2 - Plugin.xml containing eclipse 3.0 tag, the requires DO NOT contain a reference to org.eclipse.core.runtime.compatibility. The plugin-class specified in the plugin.xml will be used as a BundleActivator which requires the plugin-class to have a 0-arg constructor, as well as all the classes in its hierarchy.This last use case depicts a situation where people really want to take advantage of the new OSGi runtime. Decreasing priority since the issue is understood. Michael, could you try if you can still reproduce the problem with one of today's I-Build? I still have the same problem :-( Could you provide the plugin.xml and your plugin class (or at least all the signatures) Created attachment 8001Simple plugin that demonstrates the problemHi...I just hit this. Comment 19 describes exactly what is going on.  The first thing to note is that 2.1 plugins continue to work unchanged.Next, plugins marked as <?eclipse version=3.0?> and requiring runtime.compatibility also continue to work unchanged.It is only if you are wanting to get off the compatibility layer (why?) that you actually need to change your plugin class to have the zero arg constructor.Note that if your plugin class is exposed as API for others to subclass then they cannot get off compatibility until you do as there has to be a zero arg constructor all the way up the hierarchy.Closing. I didn't do anything as malicious as removing the compatibility from the classpath when I first hit this (that was only to reproduce the problem).  I believe that all I did was open my 2.1 plugin in the PDE, and hit PDE Tools -> Migrate to 3.0 and then my plugin wouldn't load when I tried to run it.  If the Migrate to 3.0 Tool does add the compatibility to the classpath, then I suppose it's possible I had some other errors in my workspace that prevented my manifest from being properly updated. I can't judge in how far this is relevant, but I can give a counter-example of the statement ""The first thing to note is that 2.1 plugins continue to work unchanged."" in comment #26. I didn't delete any files outside of eclipse but i did do a refresh.  My process was:have a project with 40700 files in 9000 directories in cvs.team->disconnect and then refresh and then team->share.I think the performance problems have been reduced in e3m7,  I'll give it a tryand see how long it takes. Still appears to be just as slow on the 1500 xml files in the one directory. When I look at the progress I can see each file name go by.  Is it doing a diff of each one versus the repository?  Or is it doing a checksum.  Seems like it is taking too long to be a checksum.Could it not just check the cvs metadata that already exists for those files andsee if the size of the file has changed?  Granted that isn't going to give you100% confidence that the file didn't change but it should give you at least 99%.And the changes that you would miss would typically be a 1 character change.Maybe default to the pessimistic diff decorator behavior but have a setting toenable the above?  I know I'd use it.Sometimes I have to disconnect because directories have been deleted from theserver and the amount of time this takes is enormous.  So far I have been waiting 21 minutes for this process to complete. Final time was 24 minutes.  Project stats are now 55,000 files in 9900directories.  From watching the process though it seems to spend the majority ofthe time on the 3000 xml files, taking about 1 second per file.  Perhaps thereis just a problem with xml file comparison? There are only a few things that happen during decoration. One is the loading of the sync info from disk. We have fixed some bugs post-M7 that caused us to load the sync info each time a file was decorated instead of loading it once for the folder (this is why I asked about the external deletions). The other is the loading and comparison of the timestamp of the file to the one in the sync info which should be fairly fast. Also, once resources are decorated once, we cache a bit of info to improve deep decoration. You could try one of the latst integration builds to see if the latest integration builds have improved anything. We'll be makign a perfomance pass at some point and will be sure to test a similar scenario. Will verify for M8. I didn't get to this in M8, but marking as high priority for M9. If we are doing something stupid we should figure it out now. WE are running with YourKit now so taking a perf snapshot is a piece of cake. *** Bug 44025 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** I've tested again and profiled. I can't see any slowness on our part. We'vefixed some decorator performance issues pre-M8 regarding how the packages viewcan apply quikc label updates and this may of helped. Again, if you see thishappening please grab a stack trace, or a couple, when you think it is takingtoo long decorating. This will help debug any other problems. PS: you can grab a stack trace on windows by running with -consoleLog and thenCTRL+BREAK in the console to get the trace. 	2010-02-07 02:41:33	1265530000.0	resolved fixed	e34b164	1291390000.0	java/org/apache/catalina/connector/Connector.java java/org/apache/catalina/connector/Request.java test/org/apache/catalina/connector/TestRequest.java
50358	Requesting change to AbstractGraphicalEditPart#reorderChild(...)	"We've introduced the following changes to our editpart hierarchy/** support multiple content panes per editpart. */IFigure getContentPaneFor( Object key ) {  return contentPaneMap.contains(key)    ? (IFigure)contentPaneMap.get(key)    : getContentPane()}addChildVisual( EditPart child, int index ) {  getContentPaneFor(child).add(...);}removeChildVisual( EditPart child, int index ) {  getContentPaneFor(child).remove(...);}However, we are running into problems withAbstractGraphicalEditPart#reorderChild(...) since it sets constaints bydirectly calling getContentPane().setConstraint(...).  We get an IllergalArgumentException getContentPane() is returning the wrong content pane.I'd like the following change :AbstractGraphicalEditPart#reorderChild(...)  {   ...   getContentPane().setConstraint(childFigure, constraint)}toAbstractGraphicalEditPart#reorderChild(...)  {   ...   setLayoutConstraint(child, childFigure, constraint)}Thanks, To clarify, there is an existing workaround which is simply to overide that method, correct? By the way, if you are placing children each in a special content pane, then why don't you implement reorder children to do ""nothing""?  The figure's don't even have the same parent, so their order doesn't mean anything.So, your implementation should be just fix the list of children:  children.remove(editpart);  children.add(index, editpart); 1. ""By the way, if you are placing children each in a special content pane"" - No, we can have multiple figures in each content pane.2. My work around is simply to catch the exception:protected void reorderChild(EditPart child, int index) {  try {    super.reorderChild(child, index);  }  catch (IllegalArgumentException iae) {    IFigure childFigure = cep.getFigure();    LayoutManager layout = getContentPane().getLayoutManager();    Object constraint = layout == null	? null	: layout.getConstraint(childFigure);    getContentPaneFor(child).setConstraint(childFigure,constraint);  }} There are possible other places where a single content pane is assumed. Are you unioning together multiple relationships in your model?  The preferred way to support two sets of children, like methods and attributes, is to either:a) implement another ""children"" collection in your editpart.  For example, add ""children2"", contentPane2, etc.b) insert grouping editparts.  For example:ClassEditPart  AttributesEditPart(group)    AttributePart    AttributePart  MethodsEditPArt(group)    MethodPart    MethodPArtThe user cannot select the grouping editpart and in fact does not know they exist.We will make the change in 3.0. Fixed.I have also ensured that we don't do this anywhere else. "	2010-11-28 18:13:10	1290990000.0	resolved fixed	07b72f1	1291040000.0	java/org/apache/catalina/startup/Embedded.java

We are looking at this for inclusion in M7 This support is included in the runtime now.  The runtime supports1) plugins in dirs iwth code in jars or in dirs2) plugins in jars with code at root of jar3) plugins in jars with code in dirs in the jar4) plugins in jars with code in nested jarsNote however that various plugins and the tooling support only options 1 and 2.  The other options may cause confusion can cannot be used as as base against which to compile.PDE build has a separate bug to track the building of option 2 structures.Closing. 48837	[workspace] Fails building plugin JARs with multiple source folders	We have several plugin projects where we use source folders to organize our code.  It is not uncommon to have a plugin with five source folders each of which is built into a seperate runtime JAR.  This setup compiles fine and runs just fine but the PDE build is failing.  It fails because our source folders depend upon each other and PDE requires that a dependent JAR be built first.  The problem is that since they depend on each other, it doesn't matter which order we put the JARs in the build.properties file, it will always fail.An example is a plugin with three runtime libraries mapped to three source folders A, B, and C where A depends on B and C and C depends on A. Looking into the problem more I see that the output folder for the project (bin) is added to the javac classpath for all runtime libraries except for the first one.  So, only the first runtime library cannot have references to the others.  The first library should also have the bin folder on its classpath. This is being supported by the property jars.compile.order.Take a look at org.eclipse.osgi for an example I looked at org.eclipse.osgi and I don't see how this solves the problem.  This plugin just provides a compile order.  In our plugin, the libraries have cyclical loops among them.  So there is not an order that would compile.My example has a plugin with libraries a.jar, b.jar and c.jar and a.jar depends on both b.jar and c.jar.  Also, b.jar depends on a.jar and c.jar depends on a.jar.If you saw my last post you would see that the first library is not getting the output folder added to the classpath.  This is incorrect.  All libraries should have the output folder on their classpath. I missed the circular dependency.This is not supported and there is no plan to support it in an immediate future.This makes the creation of the jars more complicated because all the classesmust be compiled at once and therefore all the .class files will be produced inthe same result folder.The compilation done, the script would have to find all the files that were in agiven source folder, find all the resulting .class files and put them into a jar.If you have such a dependency, which benefits does the multiple jar brings you?Can't you factorize the circularity into one folder? This won't be fix for 3.0. Marking as enhancement. Later As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported.Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you. 	2010-03-01 18:51:11	1267490000.0	resolved fixed	ddbbfc1	1290630000.0	java/org/apache/catalina/loader/WebappClassLoader.java

50310	BiDi bug: SWT controls flip the alignment if SWT.RIGHT_TO_LEFT style is set.	"If SWT.RIGHT_TO_LEFT style is set, some SWT contols also change the alignment direction. If the alignment is right, then set SWT.RIGHT_TO_LEFT style, we see the alignment becomes left, and vice versa.This never happen on J2SE Swing. Swing does not change the alignment, even if the component orientation is RTL or LTR.Steps to reproduce:1. Download the following files on http://www.eclipse.org/downloads/index.php and install them:    eclipse-SDK-3.0M6-win32.zip    eclipse-examples-3.0M6-win32.zip 2. In the example, set RTL_SUPPORT_ENABLE = true in org.eclipse.swt.examples.controlexample.Tab.java in org.eclipse.swt.example plugin.3. Rebuild org.eclipse.swt.example plugin.4. Launch ""SWT Examples\SWT controls"" view 5. Click ""Button"" tab on the SWT controls view6. Change ""Size"" to ""100x100""7. Change ""Alignment"" to Left.8. Change ""Orientation"" to SWT.RIGHT_TO_LEFT and SWT.LEFT_TO_RIGHT.9. You can see the visual alignment is also flipped.The alignment should not be changed, whatever the orientation setting is.In addition, I see the same problem in the following cases:""SWT Example\SWT controls"" view:   Button, Label, ""SWT Examples\SWT Custom controls"" view: CLabel Test OS: Windows2000 SP3Test Java platform: Sun Java2 SDK 1.4.1_06 SWT has the right behavior.The application code should use SWT.TRAIL instead of SWT.RIGHT, and SWT.LEAD instead of SWT.LEFT, so the code is more readable when on a bidi context. See MSDN recomendation.""RemarksThe layout specifies the order in which text and graphics are revealed in a window or a device context. The default is left to right. The SetLayout function changes this to be right to left, which is the standard in Arabic and Hebrew cultures. Once the LAYOUT_RTL flag is selected, flags normally specifying right or left are reversed. To avoid confusion, consider defining alternate words for standard flags, such as those in the following table.Standard flag Suggested alternate name WS_EX_RIGHT WS_EX_TRAILING WS_EX_RTLREADING WS_EX_REVERSEREADING WS_EX_LEFTSCROLLBAR WS_EX_LEADSCROLLBAR ES_LEFT ES_LEAD ES_RIGHT ES_TRAIL EC_LEFTMARGIN EC_LEADMARGIN EC_RIGHTMARGIN EC_TRAILMARGIN""http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/default.asp?url=/library/en-us/gdi/devcons_5upg.aspThere is no concept of absolute RIGHT or absolute LEFT.Closing pr as Invalid.Semion, would you have something to add in here ? To have a absolute alignment is the native wish of bidi developer. I once was a fierce supported of the position of this bug's owner. But I also understand your point of view. SWT doesn't include possibilities, which aren't released in the OS.    "	2010-11-21 21:08:35	1290390000.0	resolved fixed	ade20d2	1290430000.0	java/org/apache/catalina/core/StandardWrapper.java

If this context has a parent, it will borrow all key bindings from its parent, in addition to the key bindings defined in its own context. parentId is correct. parent is deprecated. i'll fix this up. 50184	Reworking of Error Log Properties Dialog	  The current dialog is not as user-centric for navigating through a set of log events as it can be. It is currently modal and specific to the selected event.  This means the user has to dbl-click on the desired event, it opens, the user closes it and moves on to the next event.  There is nothing wrong with this functionally but it means we can't keep error details up while flipping through the code to find out where we went wrong since we can't click anywhere else on the screen whilst the dialog is up.  It also means there is a great deal of opening and closing of the dialog since we have to dbl-click on the error to view its properties.Thus, the proposal is on the table for the following improvements:User Interface --------------1. have navigation buttons for scrolling through events2. have a function button to copy the properties of the selected event3. rework UI so that session data, stack trace, and other event details can be seen on one page rather than having to flip to another property pageUsability & Functionality --------------1. make the dialog modeless2. when the dialog is up, we should be able to click on any other event and the dialog will be repopulated (otherwise, a dbl-click summons the dialog)3. when the dialog is up, we should still be able to reorder columns at which the navigation buttons will adjust accordingly4. navigation is between siblings (i.e. if we open the dialog to a subentry, the Next button will go to the following subentry under the same parent or go to the following parent if it is the last subentry under its parent.  If we open the dialog to a parent entry, the Next button will go to the following subentry regardless of if it has children or not.)5. Copy function will put error type, date/time, message, and stack trace into clipboard as usual. Done. :) 	2010-10-29 17:12:34	1288390000.0	resolved fixed	afdc055	1289320000.0	java/org/apache/catalina/tribes/group/RpcChannel.java

For each bundle added and not successfully resolved, if debug isenabled (-debug), a corresponding message (""Bundle XXX could not be resolved"")will be printed to the error stream. A more complete message can be produced ifthe following debug option is enabled:org.eclipse.osgi/eclipseadaptor/debug/platformadmin/resolver *** Bug 49505 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Real fix should be: print error messages to the console when in debug mode, butalways log it. The reason why the message appears in your case is because, temporarily, thoseplug-ins could not be resolved (but later they are). 50127	[KeyBindings][MenuMgmt] Quick fix (Command+Q) quits Eclipse immediately on Mac	"The keyboard shortcut for Quick Fix is Command-E Command-Q, command q is the quit command so trying to invoke quick fix causes the app to quit. I tried to reassign the key but the UI for the keyboard shortcuts in preferences is messed up on the mac (filed under another bug #50126).Version - 3.0M6There is nothing in my .log file. doug, while this is mac specific - i can't fix - it is purely something for you to sort out with SWT.the mac has an application menu which binds command+Q, command+H, etc. before we get them. coincidentally, this is also a menu management bug - we need a mechanism from SWT to hook some of these menu items (preferences, about box, quit, etc). we definitely need to hook quit, the user needs the opportunity to save their files.not only do we need to be able to hook the menu items, it would be nice if we got these keypresses first as well (and could draw in the accelerator area of this menu).i think the hook (for the quit case) is critical for 3.0 (if the mac was an official platform, i'd even say blocker) andre probably knows some duplicates of this bug.. Yes, Command-Q is hooked by Carbon before we get it. But I think this is true for certain shortcuts on all platforms and we cannot (and shouldn't) work around it.So using Command-Q as a default key binding for something not related to Quit is a problem on Mac (but easy to fix).However, Command-Q is handled correctly by SWT and Eclipse. It generates a Quit Application Event that is translated into firing an SWT.Close event from the Display. The workbench hooks this event and shuts down Eclipse gracefully. Try yourself: press Command-Q if you have a dirty editor. You will be asked and you are able to veto. The only problem we have is that SWT disposes the Display after sending out the SWT.Close event. And this is too early for some code in the workbench. But this problem is not Mac specific and happens on other platforms too: try to log out on window if Eclipse is open.BTW, the Mac is an official platform, but we don't have a ""blocking"" problem with a Quit-hook.We should only get rid of the Command-Q for Quick Fix. The new key configuration has been removed, so this bug isn't as important right now.  Unless this is bound in the default key configuration, but on Mac only?  The problem goes through normal shutdown, and so is not ""critical"", per se.  As Andre mentions, this is the same as ""Alt+F4"" on Windows or GNOME.  I also agree with Andre that it is not wise to override this behaviour.  On GNOME and Windows at least, ""Alt+F4"" starts a timer -- if the application doesn't respond in timer, then the user is given the opportunity to kill the application.  Overriding this behaviour could conceivably nix a useful window manager function.  The problem is really a conflict in the new key configuration.  It was a mistake to bind ""Command+Q"" in a multiple-stroke key binding.  As much as it would have been a mistake to bind ""Alt+F4"" in multiple-stroke key binding on another system.  Since this is a problem with the new key configuration -- which may or may not ever come to fruitition -- I'm moving this bug to LATER.   Moving duplicate resolved (but not fixed) bugs to verified for M8.  As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported.Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you. 50105	The code formatter should be enhanced to handle XDoclet tags better.
