49426	Layouts should support laying out only a subset of a composite's children	"Currently all standard SWT layout managers always lay out all children of thecomposite they are managing. This includes children which are not visible. Whilethis may be desired in some cases, it makes it difficult to manage dynamiclayouts where the layout should change when a control is made visible or invisible.The SWT layout managers should allow the programmer to specify a subset of themanaged controls for which a layout will be computed. I initially thought ofhaving a ""hideInvisibleControls"" flag on all layout managers but that would notbe sufficient. When hiding a control you could redo the layout and get theexpected results but when showing a control, you first need to recompute thelayout to make room for the control and then make the control visible after thelayout has changed. If you were restricted to computing a layout for visiblecontrols, you would first have to make the control visible, thus showing it witha wrong position and size, and then recompute the layout.So instead of such a flag I am proposing a ""public Control[] controls"" field forall layout managers where you can explicitly set the controls which will beconsidered for computing the layout. If this field is set to null (which shouldbe the default), the composite will be queried for all children (the currentbehaviour). Simply replacing all calls to ""composite.getChildren()"" by ""controls== null ? composite.getChildren() : controls"" in all layout managers should dothe trick.I have done these modifications to my own copies of the SWT layout managers(where I simply copied the original code; this cannot be done throughinheritance because the calls to composite.getChildren() are not encapsulated ina protected method of the Layout class). So far I have tested the modifiedversions of FillLayout and FormLayout and they worked as expected. I have been thinking about this problem as well.  Off the top of my head, the *right* SWT way to do it would be for the layout data of every layout to have an ""ignore"" flag to filter children from the list.  This would mean that when application code called setVisible(), it would need to update the ""ignore"" flag and then call layout().The ""public Control [] controls"" field is an interesting possibility as well and would require fewer code changes.Neither seems very good.  Have you considered either disposing and recreating your controls or using FormLayout?  Using FormLayout, it should be possible to hide a control and make sure that no other controls are attached to it and the layout().Seems to me we need some simple example code that we can experiment with to capture the kinds of things that applications are trying to do. Another possibility is to open up Layout by removing the ""finals"" and making all of our Layout classess go through something like ""protected Control [] getChildren (Composite composite)"".  This would allow you to subclass and filter the list of Controls before they were passed to the layout algorithm.  This kind of solution opens things up a bit but means that every application must subclass and filter which is bad. Created attachment 7337My modified versions of the standard SWT layout classes I've also thought about a protected getChildren() method. It's actually part ofmy current implementation. I've inserted an abstract class DynamicLayout betweenLayout and the concrete *Layout classes. DynamicLayout provides getChildren()(or getComponents(), as I named it) which is used by the subclasses. From mypoint of view, it doesn't matter much if the layouts provide getChildren() or apublic field to set the children. I suppose I could make use of a ""ignore""property in the layout data in a similar way.What does make my work easier is a common interface for these features (providedby the DynamicLayout class in my implementation), but not having one wouldn't bea big problem either. I need separate factories for each layout anyway if I wantto support them in my XML GUI framework. They could use anonymous subclasses ofthe respective *Layout class. (I've come across several other cases of identicalfeatures with identical methods in classes without a common interface in SWT,but that would be a different bug report. :-)I've created an attachment with my modified layout classes. Here's some XMLmarkup (slightly modified and abbreviated from one of my working examples) whichshows the kind of layout I'm using. You should have no trouble reading it sincethe component and layout names and features translate almost 1:1 to SWT features:<Window>  <layout type=""form"" margin=""0.7em"" spacing=""0.7em"" hide-invisible=""true"" />  <TextBox id=""c2"">    <layout-data t.pos=""0%"" l.pos=""0%"" r.pos=""100%"" width=""25em"" />  </TextBox>  <ToggleButton text=""Show details"" id=""c6"">    <layout-data t.id=""c2"" r.pos=""100%"" />  </ToggleButton>  <Composite>    <layout-data t.id=""c6"" l.pos=""0%"" r.pos=""100%"" b.pos=""100%"" />    <layout type=""form"" spacing=""0.7em"" />    <Separator id=""sep"" orientation=""horizontal"">      <layout-data t.pos=""0%"" l.pos=""0%"" r.pos=""100%"" />    </Separator>    <Label id=""p"" text=""Select a previous class name:"">      <layout-data t.id=""sep"" l.pos=""0%"" r.pos=""100%"" />    </Label>    <List>      <layout-data height=""8em"" t.id=""p"" l.pos=""0%"" r.pos=""100%"" b.pos=""100%"" />    </List>  </Composite>	</Window>In this example, the underlying models toggle the visibility of the Compositewidget when the state of the ToggleButton changes.I'll try to come up with a snippet to demonstrate this. So far, all my GUIs arein XML which makes converting them to snippets a lengthy process :-/I thought about disposing and creating the widgets as needed, but this couldpossibly be a complex and lengthy operation. The GUI shown in the XML code aboveis quite simple with only one widget to be hidden (though it's a Composite, soyou'd need to dispose and create the children as well) and that widget is thelast child of its parent. If I wanted to support that in XML, I'd either have topresent this feature in a more complex and limited way (with a differentnotation) or use the above notation and possibly need to dispose and recreatethe entire contents of a shell when the first widget (instead of the last one)is shown or hidden. I really don't like either of these two variants, especiallysince it is so much easier to do with layout managers. When faced with thesealternatives only, I'd rather keep my current implementation.I have not yet thought about allowing dynamic layouts for FormLayout only. If Iunderstand you corrently, I'd have to modify the FormData and/or FormAttachmentobjects when I show or hide a control, so that controls would only haveconnections to other controls when they are shown. Is that correct?What happens to the unconnected controls? Are they simply ignored or put intothe top left corner (or somewhere else)? If they end up in a default locationthey could still influence (read: ""destroy"") the layout if they are too big.I'll try this and see how it works. FormLayout is easy to use for dynamic layout. Here is one little simple example, but there are many ways you could do it. Using FormLayout in this way works fine, and when a control is not visible, it does not take up space in the parent.import org.eclipse.swt.*;import org.eclipse.swt.widgets.*;import org.eclipse.swt.layout.*;import org.eclipse.swt.events.*;public class Main {	static Display display;	static Shell shell;	static Button button;	static Text text;	static FormData showText, hideText;		public static void main (String [] args) {		display = new Display ();		shell = new Shell (display);		shell.setLayout (new FormLayout ());		button = new Button (shell, SWT.PUSH);		button.setText (""Details >>"");		button.setLayoutData (new FormData ());		button.addSelectionListener(new SelectionAdapter() {			public void widgetSelected(SelectionEvent e) {				if (text.getLayoutData() == hideText)					text.setLayoutData (showText);				else					text.setLayoutData (hideText);				shell.pack ();			}		});		text = new Text (shell, SWT.BORDER);		text.setText (""Hello, details!"");		showText = new FormData ();		showText.width = 200;		showText.height = 100;		showText.top = new FormAttachment (button, 0, SWT.DEFAULT);		hideText = new FormData ();		hideText.left = new FormAttachment (0, 0);		hideText.right = new FormAttachment (0, 0);		hideText.top = new FormAttachment (0, 0);		hideText.bottom = new FormAttachment (0, 0);		text.setLayoutData (hideText);		shell.pack ();		shell.open ();		while (!shell.isDisposed ()) {			if (!display.readAndDispatch ())				display.sleep ();		}		display.dispose ();	}} Carolyn, thanks for the snippet. This certainly looks like a good alternative tomy layout modifications, at least for FormLayout (which is the most importantlayout manager, anyway). Unless a new method is introduced which can be usedwith all layouts, I'll modify my framework to use this method for FormLayout.Here's a modified version of the snippet which uses my layout classes (containedin the attachment I posted yesterday):import org.eclipse.swt.*;import org.eclipse.swt.widgets.*;import com.novocode.naf.swt.layout.*;import org.eclipse.swt.events.*;public class DynamicLayout2 {  static Text text;    public static void main (String [] args) {    final Display display = new Display ();    final Shell shell = new Shell (display);    final DynamicFormLayout layout = new DynamicFormLayout ();    shell.setLayout (layout);    Button button = new Button (shell, SWT.PUSH);    button.setText (""Details >>"");    button.setLayoutData (new DynamicFormData ());    button.addSelectionListener(new SelectionAdapter() {      public void widgetSelected(SelectionEvent e) {        if (text.getVisible()) {          text.setVisible(false);          layout.controls = DynamicLayout.getVisibleChildren(shell);        }        else {          layout.controls = DynamicLayout.getVisibleChildrenPlusOne(shell, text);          text.setVisible(true);        }        shell.pack ();      }    });    text = new Text (shell, SWT.BORDER);    text.setText (""Hello, details!"");    text.setVisible(false);    DynamicFormData textData = new DynamicFormData ();    textData.width = 200;    textData.height = 100;    textData.top = new DynamicFormAttachment (button, 0, SWT.DEFAULT);    text.setLayoutData (textData);        layout.controls = DynamicFormLayout.getVisibleChildren(shell);        shell.pack ();    shell.open ();    while (!shell.isDisposed ()) {      if (!display.readAndDispatch ())        display.sleep ();    }    display.dispose ();  }} For now, the answer is to just use FormLayout.  This is still a problem for the other layouts but I'm not really happy with any of the proposed solutions so far. Subclassing just for this feature sounds like overkill.  Filtering the controls might prevent a layout from working.  For example, if a hidden control is connected to some of the visible controls in FormLayout, then that layout might need access to even hidden children.I favor adding:setObserveVisiblity(boolean)boolean getObservingVisibility()to LayoutJavaDoc would indicate that this is a hint to the layout manager. Actually we were going to add a field to the layout data.  Although it would be possible to put it in Layout, subclasses would suddenly get new ""free"" API that offered services that they wouldn't know they needed to implement (and thus wouldn't). It seems like all that would be needed is a single boolean value per composite. Using layout data requires more work, and I don't know of another use case for ""don't layout this child"".  Some layout don't require layout data at all currently. Added the field ""exclude"" to RowData and GridData.  Ido not currently see how it would make sense for FormData so I have not added it.After changing the layout data field to true, you must set the visibility of the associated widget and cause the layout to be invoked.e.g.GridData data = (GridData)control.getLayoutData();data.exclude = true;control.setVisible(false);shell.layout(false); (In reply to comment #11)I know this is an old bug, but to me the recommendation> Added the field ""exclude"" to RowData and GridData.> GridData data = (GridData)control.getLayoutData();> data.exclude = true;> control.setVisible(false);> shell.layout(false);seems to be a workaround and not a satisfying solution.Would it be an option to add a new property to GridLayout like preserveHiddenElements(boolean) that is set to true by default. When set to false we could omit getting the GridData of each child, setting the exclude flag and so on. I guess this would not break compatibility but make life easier for developers. What is it that you are trying to do? If you send me a screen snapshot and a description of what you need to do, then we can try to write a snippet to do it using the current API.And please open a new bug for this, and reference this old bug. Feel free to cc me. Adding new work to an already-fixed bug is problematic, because it can be forgotten. 50066	GLA does not generate error messages for missing/invalid/empty log files.	GLA does not generate error messages for missing/invalid/empty log files. if the log file is empty it shouldn't generate an error message.  It just won't give any output, or will continue to monitor the file when it is in continuous mode.  As for the missing/invalid file, isn't this something you added just recently Paul? Based on Richard's comments, the use cases where the log file is empty or missing are currently covered.  The final use case to be handles by this defect is when the log file is an invalid log file.  Invalid log files may include incorrect types (e.g. attempting to parse an access log using the error log adapter rules), incorrect log record(s) and/or corrupted text in the log file. The third use case will be handled in the UI when importing log files. 49987	"[EditorMgmt] Typo in IPageLayout.ID_EDITOR_AREA = ""org.eclipse.ui.editorss"""	"Someone asked me if they could add a few to a perspective relative to the editor area instead of another view. I believe the answer should be yes, they just have to refer to the area by name in their plugin.xml. However, looking at the source code, the editor area name is defined by the constant IPageLayout.ID_EDITOR_AREA which has the value ""org.eclipse.ui.editorss"". This looks like a typo so it probably shouldn't be documented this way and it should be changed. Changing it would probably break binary compatibility but I think you can just add a check to test for both the right and wrong values in IPageLayout.addView() and any similar functions to support plug-ins using the old value. Created attachment 110331FixKim, please do not kill me :-)Considering that ID_EDITOR_AREA is not final (although outline marks it as final, see bug 244529) I feel free to correct the typo.Moreover, ID_EDITOR_AREA specifies that this field ""may only be used as a reference part for view addition."" it is quite easy to keep contract compatibility - there is only one place where we should check for old version... Comment on attachment 110331FixForget the patch. The static field inside the interface is considered to be final, so we cannot change the value of the field and we should introduce new one. Having all this in mind I would close this bug as wontfix because fixing this bug would introduce more mess than order... 49667	[TableEdtior] Several wierd behaviors in TableEditor	"Given the following snippet, I've noticed the following unwelcome behaviors:import org.eclipse.swt.SWT;import org.eclipse.swt.custom.CCombo;import org.eclipse.swt.custom.TableEditor;import org.eclipse.swt.events.SelectionEvent;import org.eclipse.swt.events.SelectionListener;import org.eclipse.swt.layout.FillLayout;import org.eclipse.swt.layout.RowLayout;import org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Button;import org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Composite;import org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display;import org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Shell;import org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Table;import org.eclipse.swt.widgets.TableColumn;import org.eclipse.swt.widgets.TableItem;import org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Text;public class StockTestTable {    public static void main(String[] args) {        Display display = new Display ();        Shell shell = new Shell (display);        shell.setLayout (new FillLayout());        final Table table = new Table (shell, SWT.BORDER | SWT.MULTI);        table.setLinesVisible (true);        table.setHeaderVisible(true);        for (int i=0; i<3; i++) {            TableColumn column = new TableColumn(table, SWT.NONE);            column.setWidth (100);        }        for (int i=0; i<95; i++) {            TableItem item = new TableItem (table, SWT.NONE);        }        TableItem [] items = table.getItems ();        for (int i=0; i<items.length; i++) {            TableEditor editor = new TableEditor (table);            CCombo combo = new CCombo (table, SWT.NONE);            editor.grabHorizontal = true;            editor.setEditor(combo, items[i], 0);            editor = new TableEditor (table);            Text text = new Text (table, SWT.NONE);            if (i == 25) text25a = text;            editor.grabHorizontal = true;            editor.setEditor(text, items[i], 1);            editor = new TableEditor (table);            Button button = new Button (table, SWT.CHECK);            button.setText(""text"");            button.pack ();            editor.minimumWidth = button.getSize ().x;            editor.horizontalAlignment = SWT.LEFT;            editor.setEditor (button, items[i], 2);        }        Composite buttonHolder = new Composite(shell, SWT.NULL);        buttonHolder.setLayout(new RowLayout());        Button early = new Button(buttonHolder, SWT.NULL);        early.setText(""3"");        early.addSelectionListener(new SelectionListener() {            public void widgetSelected(SelectionEvent e) {                table.setTopIndex(3);            }            public void widgetDefaultSelected(SelectionEvent e) {            }        });        Button late = new Button (buttonHolder, SWT.NULL);        late.setText(""50"");        late.addSelectionListener(new SelectionListener() {            public void widgetSelected(SelectionEvent e) {                table.setTopIndex(50);            }            public void widgetDefaultSelected(SelectionEvent e) {            }        });        shell.setSize(600,600);        shell.open ();        while (!shell.isDisposed ()) {            if (!display.readAndDispatch ()) display.sleep ();        }        display.dispose ();    }}1) Clicking on the ""3"" or ""50"" should scroll the top index to the 3rd or 50thline respectively.  On my machine, the scroll bar moves, but the controls in theTable do not.2) Tabbing all the way to the end of the visible table and beyond does notscroll the table as expected.  Instead, the cursor goes off into la la land. Pressing shift-tab repeatedly brings it back eventually.  However, the cursornever should disappear when it is being manipulated through the keyboard. - To run the snippet I removed the ""if (i == 25) text25a = text;"" line.- 1) This seems wrong.- 2) After tabbing off the end of the table, focus goes to the ""3"" and ""50"" buttons, then back to the top of the table.  The first step of its re-entry to the Table looks very strange though (will attach picture next).  What is this? Created attachment 7364is this the dottie? Here is the example code ""fixed"":import org.eclipse.swt.*;import org.eclipse.swt.events.*;import org.eclipse.swt.layout.*;import org.eclipse.swt.widgets.*;import org.eclipse.swt.custom.*;public class PR_49667 {    public static void main(String[] args) {        Display display = new Display ();        Shell shell = new Shell (display);        shell.setLayout (new FillLayout());        final Table table = new Table (shell, SWT.BORDER | SWT.MULTI);		table.addListener(SWT.FocusIn, new Listener () {			public void handleEvent (Event event) {				table.traverse(SWT.TRAVERSE_TAB_NEXT);			}		});        table.setLinesVisible (true);        table.setHeaderVisible(true);        for (int i=0; i<3; i++) {            TableColumn column = new TableColumn(table, SWT.NONE);            column.setWidth (100);        }        for (int i=0; i<95; i++) {            TableItem item = new TableItem (table, SWT.NONE);        }        TableItem [] items = table.getItems ();        int index = 0;        final TableEditor [] editors = new TableEditor [items.length * 3];        for (int i=0; i<items.length; i++) {            TableEditor editor = new TableEditor (table);			editors [index++] = editor;            CCombo combo = new CCombo (table, SWT.NONE);            editor.grabHorizontal = true;            editor.setEditor(combo, items[i], 0);            editor = new TableEditor (table);			editors [index++] = editor;            Text text = new Text (table, SWT.NONE);//            if (i == 25) text25a = text;            editor.grabHorizontal = true;            editor.setEditor(text, items[i], 1);            editor = new TableEditor (table);			editors [index++] = editor;            Button button = new Button (table, SWT.CHECK);            button.setText(""text"");            button.pack ();            editor.minimumWidth = button.getSize ().x;            editor.horizontalAlignment = SWT.LEFT;            editor.setEditor (button, items[i], 2);        }        Composite buttonHolder = new Composite(shell, SWT.NULL);        buttonHolder.setLayout(new RowLayout());        Button early = new Button(buttonHolder, SWT.NULL);        early.setText(""3"");        early.addSelectionListener(new SelectionListener() {            public void widgetSelected(SelectionEvent e) {                table.setTopIndex(3);				for (int i=0; i<editors.length; i++) {					editors [i].layout ();				}            }            public void widgetDefaultSelected(SelectionEvent e) {            }        });        Button late = new Button (buttonHolder, SWT.NULL);        late.setText(""50"");        late.addSelectionListener(new SelectionListener() {            public void widgetSelected(SelectionEvent e) {                table.setTopIndex(50);				for (int i=0; i<editors.length; i++) {					editors [i].layout ();				}            }            public void widgetDefaultSelected(SelectionEvent e) {            }        });        shell.setSize(600,600);        shell.open ();        while (!shell.isDisposed ()) {            if (!display.readAndDispatch ()) display.sleep ();        }        display.dispose ();    }} Both problems are caused by the factnat TableEditor is a ""decoration"" on a table.  This means that the underlying table has no idea that it contains TableEditors.When you call setTopIndex(), this eventually causes the scroll bar to scroll by making some interal operating system call that does not invoke listeners.  This is the correct SWT behavior but means that the TableEditors don't move.I hacked the example to move them.When you tab to a Table, the table has no idea that you don't mean focus to go to it but would perfer focus to go to a child. There are situations where you might want this behavior but it looks funny in the example.  I hacked the example to assign focus.I'm not going to close this PR because these are valid problems in the design of TableEditor, but not strictly bugs.  I'm going to assign it to Veronika who owns the class. *** Bug 46210 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Duong, there are many problems that are encountered in TableEditor because it is a decoration.  Please be on the lookout for them and mark them as duplicates. This bug hasn't had any activity in quite some time. Maybe the problem got resolved, was a duplicate of something else, or became less pressing for some reason - or maybe it's still relevant but just hasn't been looked at yet.If you have further information on the current state of the bug, please add it. The information can be, for example, that the problem still occurs, that you still want the feature, that more information is needed, or that the bug is (for whatever reason) no longer relevant. This bug hasn't had any activity in quite some time. Maybe the problem got resolved, was a duplicate of something else, or became less pressing for some reason - or maybe it's still relevant but just hasn't been looked at yet. The information can be, for example, that the problem still occurs, that you still want the feature, that more information is needed, or that the bug is (for whatever reason) no longer relevant.--The automated Eclipse Genie. 50018	update class path  should prompt to save the plugin.xml	"If you edit build.xml and then do update class path you are not prompted to save the build.xml file. This can make things very confusing (and anything which improves the comprehension of plugin classpath juggling is a good thing)Ideally this classpath update should happen automatically of course I meant plugin.xml not build.xml Not sure what build you are using, but the classpath will update automatically upon saving the manifest file if you are using PDE's dynamic classpath.If you are using <= 3.0M6, then when you update the classpath, check the 'Use dynamic classpath' option.If you are using > 3.0M6, dynamic classpaths is the only way, so all you need to do is update it once, and it will reupdate your classpaths whenever the plugin.xml changes. the point i was making was that IF you change and  DONT save the plugin.xml file (and I have the habit if never saving anything since the platform will do it for me all the time) then the PDE tools > Update classpath MUST prompt you to save the manifest. If that menu option is going away then this bug can be ignored The menu option is not going away.You say that the ""update classpath"" should happen automatically.  PDE does it upon resource modification (e.g. saving).  Anything more ""automatic"" than that would be undesirable and would result in an influx of bug reports complaining that PDE should just back off.Prompting the user to save when updating the classpath is something to consider though. Janek, this is an easy polish defect.Make sure we prompt to save dirty files when the user selects PDE Tools > Update classpath via the context menu of a plugin project or a manifest file. 49749	eclipse won't start under Solaris using eclipse 2.1.2.1.	"After installing on Solaris 8 eclipse does not run.I believe the problem is because the java command in jre/bin is just a scriptcontaining the line:.java_wrapper.java_wrapper looks parses $0 and uses it for progname:progname=`/usr/bin/basename $0`On our system progname was set to .java_wrapper and eclipse failed to runbecause:prog=""$APPHOME/bin/${proc}/${ttype}/${progname}""# Run.if [[ -x ""$prog"" ]]then     # Calling: exec $DEBUG_PROG ""$prog"" ""$@""     exec $DEBUG_PROG ""$prog"" ""$@""else    echo >&2 ""$progname was not found in ${prog}""    exit 1fiChanging java to be a hard link to .java_wrapper solved this problem. This also seems to be a problem on Linux and Linux-Motif.It seems to be caused by using pkzip or other zip tool to create the archive,causing links to be destroyed. Chris is this still a problem with the latest builds?Moving to Platform/Releng for comment. I don't understanding what is happening here since eclipse does not ship with a vm.   the last comment is correct.  That is  the problem.  The java command just calls .java_wrapper and .java_wrapper looks at $0 to decide what command to look for in /usr/bin. I could not reproduce this problem on a Solaris 8 machine with java 1.4.2.This isn't an issue with Eclipse itself, but the operating system configuration. 49726	[Workbench] Weird Java perspective icon in action bar	"See attachment.Version: 3.0.0 Build id: 200401070010 GTK buildSteps to reproduce:New workspace.Clicking on the ""Open a Perspective"" button will show the regular icon.Once I've opened the perspective the checkmark icon will be shown after clickingon the ""Open a Perspective"" button again. Created attachment 7379showing the checkmark icon This one also affects the Java Browsing Perspective icon.I think it has something to do with the way the drop down is populated.Only the Java Perspective and Java Browsing Perspective icons will be replacedw/ the checkmark icon though. Created attachment 7386this is how it looks on windows - everything okThe difference is that the Java/Java Browsing Perspectives uses a context menuwith checkboxes. This menu is controlled by Platform/UI. Asking for comments. BTW, which GTK are you running?Is it also a problem in the Window > Open Perspective menu?The reason the menu works differently in the different perspectives is due to bug 49857.  The current perspective should always be included in the list, with an accompanying bullet.  I don't think this is JDT-specific.  They just happen to add shortcuts to their own perspectives.I suspect the problem here is due to a GTK bug which uses the regular image area to show the bullet for a selected radio item.  A second problem is that it's showing a check mark instead of a bullet for SWT.RADIO style.This may be caused by the fact that the Workbench is using a mix of push items(SWT.PUSH) and radio items (SWT.RADIO) in this menu.  It should probably always use SWT.RADIO style and just set the selection appropriately.  See PerspectiveMenu.createMenuItem. Looks like a GTK bug.  Felipe to look at it quickly, see if we are doing something silly or we can work around it. On gtk, radio and check menu items do not support images, that is why you don'tsee the icon in the pop-up menu. The 'weird icon' you see is the check mark ofthe checked menu item. This is a platform limitation. Closing this bug as WONT FIX  Checked it out myself :{ For SWT.RADIO style, is there any way to get a bullet icon rather than a checkmark? How important it is ?Here the reason we use check instead of radio:case SWT.RADIO:	/*	* This code is intentionally commented.  Because GTK	* enforces radio behavior in a button group a radio group	* is not created for each set of contiguous buttons, each	* radio button will not draw unpressed.  The fix is to use	* toggle buttons instead.	*///	handle = OS.gtk_radio_menu_item_new_with_label (0, buffer);//	break;case SWT.CHECK:	handle = OS.gtk_check_menu_item_new_with_label (buffer);	break; From and end-user point of view, it's pretty bogus to be using checkmarks instead of bullets.  It's an important cue to indicate that the choice is 1 of N rather N independent yes/no choices. Fixed in HEAD > 20040902I couldn't fix the original problem report cause it is a platform limitation butinstead I fixed Nick's request in comment#9. 49613	[JUnit] JUnit - Run Test for Class	"If I just want to test a single unit of the application, I do not want to lookfor the corresponding test case. I thought that selecting the class in thepackage explorer should bring up the option ""Run JUnit Test for Class"". Thecorresponding test is then looked up and run automatically.The same could be implemented for a set of classes or a package. The interesting question here is: how do you find the corresponding test class. This needs some meta information. You are right, there has to be some meta-information. If there is no suchinformation, assumptions could be made:By default the test class should reside in the same package and have a similar name.  com.xyz.Class => com.xyz.ClassTest (for the test class)  com.xyz.*     => com.xyz.TestSuite (for the package) ... sorry no better ideaThe pattern may be configurable like the prefix and suffix list on the codegeneration preferences (Prefs > Java > Code Generation > Names) in order to suitproject standards and requirements.For the lookup to work, a separate source folder for tests (see bug 49611) wouldbe quite convenient. That would impede looking up non-test classes in the firstplace. This request is quite complicated to implement. We put a lot of effort to not show the 'Run as JUnit' launch shortcut until we know it's a test. Computing this is not cheap, but has to be performant as it happens while opening the run/debug submenu.Setting to LATER As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported.Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you. 49550	[CellEditors] Need StyledTextCellEditor	"GEF needs to support editing of word-wrapped strings using CellEditors.  We tried using TextCellEditor with MULTI | WRAP style bits.  It is problematic due to its limitations on win32.Our workaround is to use StyledText. Therefore, we need a StyledTextCellEditor.We can provide the test case and implementation if needed. Could you summarize the problem with Text using MULTI | WRAP on win32, or point to an existing PR for the problem?If going with StyledText is the only answer, then having you contribute a StyledTextCellEditor would be good. We are trying to grow a Text as you type into it.  The use case is editing a ""sticky"" note.  The sticky note has a fixed width determined by the user, and its height is automatically adjusted to fit the string.The problem with Text is that it prohibits text entry once the text completely occupies the widget.  We tried enabling scrollbars, but the behavior was still not correct, and the scrollbars would always be disabled so they were just ugly. The operating system must be doing something similar somewhere.  Can you point to a place?  Thanks. For example, on the windows desktop, when you edit the filename for a file.  Whatever control is used there, it will grow when the text flows over to a new line.  Text(MULTI | WRAP) doesn't do that because it prevents the user from typing the overflowed character. 49522	Source control folders should not be visible in package view	When using folder based source control e.g. CVS and Subversion, the CVS folders appear in the package view of the application. I'll try and do a simple ACSII drawing of thisAssuming your source is in src you get + src  + CVS                - empty  + foo.CVS            - empty  + foo.myPackage      - has content  + foo.myPackage.CVS  - emptyAll the CVS entries should not be present, they should be ignored as they're not valid packages. Same applies to .SVN folders if your using subversion. You probably should be able to configure eclipse to tell it what files to ignore. The CVS folders are hidden but there are some known problems. How did you populate your workspace from CVS? Did you use an external tool to checkout the CVS projects and them import them? This is currently the only known case that postentially results in visible CVS folders. Could you provide us with the steps you took to get the failure so we can determine if yours differs? source populated using standalone CVS client (Tortoise CVS) connecting to my CVS server which is CVSNT. Platform is Windows XP. Any further questions?  This is a known issue. The work around is to ensure that the CVS plugin is loaded before importing a project into Eclipse. You can do this but opening the CVS Repositories view or any other CVS view.*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 21128 *** 	2010-06-29 10:41:51	1277820000.0	resolved fixed	3c88f07	1278010000.0	java/org/apache/catalina/core/StandardContext.java
49476	AspectJ weaver API is not threadsafe	I am using the weaver API (mostly BcelWorld and BcelWeaer) in a multithreadedenvironment and ran into problems. I tracked them down to some static variablesin the BCEL library implementation that can cause exceptions in the weaver(signatures are not parsed correctly) when executed via mulitiple threads. Maybethe weaver implementation can use the BCEL library in a threadsafe way to allowmultiple threads working with the weaver API. This would be a great contribution. Contributing a simple solution seems to be somewhat difficult in this situation.I solved this problem in my usecase by creating a lock on my transformer object(that uses the AspectJ weaver API). This might not be a suitable solution forthe AspectJ code. Therefore I am not sure how to solve this problem in anelegant way.Let me describe the problem in more detail. Maybe someone else has an idea howto solve it for the AspectJ code base itself.The problem is the BCEL class org.apache.bcel.classfile.Utility. It uses astatic field named consumed_chars in several methods. This static field ischanged as a side effect by some methods and causes therefore trouble if morethan one thread is using this class. Therefore the best way to solve thisproblem is to patch this class, I think. But maybe we do not want to change anexternal library.I tried to find out what code of the AspectJ weaver implementation accesses(indirectly) the Utility class. This seems to be a quite complicated task. I wasnot able to solve this within an adequate time.In my use case (the multithreaded problems) the Utility class of the BCELlibrary is used as a result of org.aspectj.weaver.bcel.LazyMethodGen.pack().Therefore it would be possible to create a static lock in this class to avoidmultithreaded usage of the BCEL library. But I am not sure whether this is theonly point where this problems can occur. The same problem occurs in the BCEL class org.apache.bcel.generic.Type, whensomeone calls getType (same static field consumed_chars). Created attachment 8380patch of Utility and Type classI changed the implementation of the BCEL classes Utility and Type so that theyno longer use the static field consumed_chars. The modified versions of bothclasses are inside the attached zip.I tried the BcelWeaverModuleTests suite with this (runs fine). I also triedthis patch with my load-time weaving implementation for the new osgi runtime ofEclipse (where I observed the multithreading problems) and that code runs fine,too. It seems to me that the multithreading problems are solved. Created attachment 8381simple test cases for Utility and TypeI wrote some very simple test cases for both classes to get a feeling if theystill behave as before my patch. They don't yet test multithreading problems,because I have no clear idea how to test this stuff in a predictable way. I just recognized that the next version of BCEL will also fix this issue. Thecurrent CVS head stream of BCEL does include a patch for the multithreadingissues. So you can take the current BCEL cvs version of both classes or my patchto fix this bug. Does that help ?In old AW, we were using Bcel and had to fix it that way:http://blogs.codehaus.org/people/avasseur/archives/000101_bcel_internal.htmlhttp://blogs.codehaus.org/people/avasseur/archives/000106_bcel_patch_submitted.htmlI don't know if it ended up in a bcel release or the one embedded in AJ sincethat time but might be worth looking at ? The current CVS head version of BCEL does include your patch (or at leastsomething similar). I am using the HEAD version of both source codes in myload-time weaving runtime to enable multithreading and it works fine. Thereforeseems to be a good thing to integrate these patches into the BCEL version AJ isusing from my point of view. Created attachment 18398Patch to make BCEL threadsafeI adapted the fixes that are in the current BCEL cvs head for the BCEL versionthat is currently used for AspectJ. The changed files are attached to this bug.This makes my old self-implemented fixes for older version obsolete. I have modified BCEL to remove the reliance on static info in those offendingclasses.  I didn't use the patch directly as I wasn't sure about the use ofthreadlocal so I rewrote the offending methods (the methods really just wantedto return multiple values, so I used a holder object and return that instead). I've added a few tests to the bcel-builder project to test I didn't regress thefunctionality but they don't verify the weaver is now threadsafe.  However,Martin has tried my changes and confirmed it works in his environment.  I'llclose the bug when a build is available. marked as AJ5 M2... 49443	[External Tools] Add the ability to associate an external tool with an extension	"It would be nice to allow one to run an external tool whenever a file with acertain extension, or pattern, is modified.  This is useful when it's not reallyworth writing an editor for some particular type of file, but it must still becompiled or processed in some manner.  I would imagine the UI to be similar tothat of the ""File Associations"" preferences page, except that multiple externaltools could be specified, with order being significant.The particular use case that I have is developing applications for the Hiptopplatform (http://www.danger.com/).  The Hiptop folks have defined a file of type.rsrc (resource), which is a fairly simple text file.  I would like the abilityto launch the Danger Resource Compiler external tool that I have definedwhenever I save the file in the default text editor.  Currently I must do itmanually, which is a little clunky and error-prone.  I could (and perhaps Iwill) make a plugin that is specifically meant to edit that type of file, but inthe meantime, it would be nice to have the aforementioned tool-launching ability.It may be that this functionality already exists somewhere; but I cannot find itif it does. :) Is this really a Contributions issue? this is external tools request.. nick, do you know where this belongs? External Tools requests should go in the Platform-Ant component for now.You can configure an external tool builder on the project properties page.I don't believe you can currently get it to only activate for specific file types though.  You would need to filter it down yourself, e.g. with an Ant script. The closest functionality we have currently is to create an External tool builder that would be triggered on modification of a working set of your .rsrc files. See the Build Options tab for the builder to specify the working set it is triggered on. Deferred to post 3.0 The functionality that is described in comment #4 is all that is planned. As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported.Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you. 49445	outline and ant runner views should  include imported targets	"In handling an imported file (using the <import> task), the outline and antrunner views should behave similarly as when entity includeds are used. The difficulty in implementing this, I am guessing, is that imports are probablyresolved at runtime rather than at parse time. A build file author might,perhaps, use a property dereference to in the <import file=""""/> declaration. Toaccomediate this an action in the views could prompt the user with a dialogallowing him to associate the import with a specific file in the file system.This configuration detail could be saved in a comment in the build file itselfor else in some other configuration store.Of course, we could handle direct file references now and code for propertydereferences in the import's file attribute later. I am having trouble visualizing how this would show in the outline (I can see it in the Ant View).The outline represents the structure of the Ant build file. Would we still show the import task? Would the targets be children of the import task? Would the targets have a label indicating that they came from an import? Imported targets and macrodefs could be decorated with a label decorator. The tool tip could indicate from which file the target was imported. The import task should still be shown in the outline. We'd want a filter button in the view toolbar to turn this off--in fact it should probably not be the default.Note that while it is not particularly good practice to do so, one may import a build file which has top-level tasks. I believe that these tasks are also imported along with targets and macrodefs. (Macrodef is actually implemented as a task).See http://ant.apache.org/manual/CoreTasks/import.html for additional information regarding what happens during an import. Particularly of interest are the 'Target overriding' and 'Special properties' sections. I have released a first pass at this for the outline.I need to do more testing and possibly some polish but feedback is appreciated.Changes to AntEditor, AntElementNode, AntImportNode, AntModelMessages, AntPropertyNode, AntTaskNode, IAntModelConstants, AntModel and ProjectHelper. This appears to work very well. I tested a number of bizarre senarios and couldn't break it. The outline even reflects recursive imports. Furthermore, both the outline and code assist works as expected renaming targets in overrides, adding the extra property so that the path to each imported file is available, etc.IMHO only two issues need work:#1. Add icon label decorators for imported targets (I can look at this if you'd like.)#2. Reconciliation needs to take into account that I may have made changes to an imported file. Currently I have to cut and paste import statements for the new targets to appear in the outline view. Note that support for this should be recursive as well.I am surprised at how well this functionality appears to perform. Admittedly My tests are with small build files, but the performance impact was imperceptible. If performance continues to be good on with 100k files, I'd recommend this should be the default functionality. A tool bar option could turn it off. To be very friendly to large build file authors one could even check file size before opening it and if it is above a threshold, we could turn it off automatically. (If this last suggestion has merit and more general applicability I could open a bug: 'optimize for very large build files'.) Created attachment 8232added overlay decorator imported elements Created attachment 8233overlay image for import elementsPlace this icon at: \org.eclipse.ant.ui\icons\full\ovr16\import_co.gif I was wrong about #2. As soon as any change is made to the buildfile all of theimports are re-reconciled and changes to the imported file are reflected in thebuildfile's outline. While changes to the outline view in the imported file are reflected immediatelyafter the change is made, it is only upon *saving* the imported file and makinga subsequent change to the main buildfile, that the main buildfile's outlineview is updated.This is a little confusing, but fixing it might be tough to do. We don't reallyhave an incremental ant compiler :). Patch applied and released. Thanks John-Mason.I will look into the reconciliation problem but likely will log it as an enhancement.I think we should see the ""big build file problem"" in the wild before spending more time on it. Logged bug 53655 for the reconcile problem when ""related"" buildfiles change.See comment #3 for changes Please verify Kevin. Added overlay image for nodes flagged as external in AntElementNode.getImage via a patch from John-Mason. Both buttons should have the same size.This is how you do it:import org.eclipse.swt.SWT;import org.eclipse.swt.layout.*;import org.eclipse.swt.widgets.*;public class Main {    public static void main(String[] args) {        Display display = new Display();        Shell shell = new Shell(display);        GridLayout gridLayout = new GridLayout(3, false);        shell.setLayout(gridLayout);        new Label(shell, SWT.NONE).setText(""Label:"");        Text t = new Text(shell, SWT.SINGLE | SWT.BORDER);        t.setLayoutData(new GridData(GridData.FILL_HORIZONTAL));        Button b = new Button(shell, SWT.PUSH);        b.setText(""Button"");        b.setLayoutData(new GridData(GridData.HORIZONTAL_ALIGN_FILL));        new Label(shell, SWT.NONE).setText(""Longer label:"");        t = new Text(shell, SWT.SINGLE | SWT.BORDER);        t.setLayoutData(new GridData(GridData.FILL_HORIZONTAL));        b = new Button(shell, SWT.PUSH);        b.setText(""Longer Button"");        b.setLayoutData(new GridData(GridData.HORIZONTAL_ALIGN_FILL));        shell.pack();        shell.open();        while (!shell.isDisposed()) {            if (!display.readAndDispatch()) display.sleep();        }        display.dispose();    }}b.setLayoutData(new GridData(GridData.HORIZONTAL_ALIGN_FILL)); Ooops, the last line b.setLayoutData(new GridData(GridData.HORIZONTAL_ALIGN_FILL));is a cut'n'paste error. 49269	The CopyCommand does not preserve order for bi-directional references	The problem is that when copying an EObject that has bi-directional referencesto other EObject instances the order of the referenced objects is notmaintained in the copy.  The problem is described in more detail in an eclipse.tools.emf posting dated 12/19/03.  The response by Frank Budinsky was:The copy command, which is a fairly old piece of code, should be handlingbidirectional references the way EcoreUtil.copy() does it. Notice that theEcoreUtil.Copier.copyReference() method calls addUnique() or move() to make sure everything is added at the right position. The InitializeCopyCommand.copyReferences() method should be doing the same thing,instead of its current incorrect implementation of just callingcopyList.add(target).Following Frank's suggestion a patch was created for the InitializeCopyCommand.copyReferences().  The patch has been JUnit tested through a number of usage scenarios and works as expected.  The modified code is included below.  /**   * This method will iterate over the references of the owner object and sets them.   * accordingly in the copy.   */  protected void copyReferences()  {      for (Iterator j = owner.eClass().getEAllReferences().iterator(); j.hasNext(); )      {        EReference eReference = (EReference)j.next();        if (eReference.isChangeable() && !eReference.isContainment())        {          copyReference(eReference, owner, copy);        }      }  }  /**   * Called to handle the copying of a cross reference;   * this adds values or sets a single value as appropriate for the multiplicity   * while omitting any bidirectional reference that isn't in the copy map.   * @param eReference the reference to copy.   * @param eObject the object from which to copy.   * @param copiedEObject the object to copy to.   */  protected void copyReference(EReference eReference, EObject eObject, EObject copiedEObject)  {          EReference reverseReference = eReference.getEOpposite();    boolean copiedTargetRequired = reverseReference != null || eReference.isContainment();        boolean isBidirectional = eReference.getEOpposite() != null;    if (eReference.isMany())    {      InternalEList value = (InternalEList)copiedEObject.eGet(eReference);      int index = 0;      for (Iterator k = ((List)eObject.eGet(eReference)).iterator(); k.hasNext(); )      {        Object referencedEObject = k.next();        Object copiedReferencedEObject = copyHelper.getCopyTarget((EObject) referencedEObject, copiedTargetRequired);         if (copiedReferencedEObject == null)        {          if (!isBidirectional)          {            value.addUnique(index, referencedEObject);            ++index;          }        }        else         {          if (isBidirectional)          {            int position = value.indexOf(copiedReferencedEObject);            if (position == -1)            {              value.addUnique(index, copiedReferencedEObject);            }            else if (index != position)            {              value.move(index, copiedReferencedEObject);            }          }          else          {            value.addUnique(index, copiedReferencedEObject);          }          ++index;        }      }    }    else    {      Object referencedEObject = eObject.eGet(eReference);      if (referencedEObject != null)      {        Object copiedReferencedEObject = copyHelper.getCopyTarget((EObject) referencedEObject, copiedTargetRequired);        if (copiedReferencedEObject == null)        {          if (!isBidirectional)          {            copiedEObject.eSet(eReference, referencedEObject);          }        }        else        {          copiedEObject.eSet(eReference, copiedReferencedEObject);        }      }    }  } Dennis,I'm making these changes to the code:> etools-diff InitializeCopyCommand.java28a29,30> import org.eclipse.emf.common.util.EList;>191,192c193,195<           List copyList = (List) copy.eGet(reference);<           for (Iterator valueIter = valueList.iterator(); valueIter.hasNext(); )--->           EList copyList = (EList) copy.eGet(reference);>           int index = 0;>           for (Iterator valueIter = valueList.iterator(); valueIter.hasNext(); ++index)195a199,212>             if (reverseReference != null)>             {>               int position = copyList.indexOf(target);>               if (position == -1)>               {>                 copyList.add(index, target);>               }>               else>               {>                 copyList.move(index, target);>               }>             }>             else>             {196a214>             }I'll attach the whole file as well.  I'd appreciate if you could verify that this fixes the problem when you remove your override to fix it locally. Created attachment 7659The changed command to fix the problem This should be fixed in the 20040225_1234SL drop. Resolve as fixed. Move to verified as per bug 206558. 	2010-05-10 14:32:07	1273520000.0	resolved fixed	27a3909	1273560000.0	modules/jdbc-pool/java/org/apache/tomcat/jdbc/pool/PoolProperties.java

49184	Cumulative time for main() is much less than expected on iSeries	On the iSeries, the cumulative time for the main() method is too small. For our InOut test case, the cumulative time for main() is 0.062582 sec but the actual elapsed time is 8.788 sec.This is an iSeries JVMPI specific bug. To obtain proper method timings on AS/400 the java application needs to be runin either interpreted mode (VM argument '-interpret') or pure jit mode (VMarguments '-Dos400.enbpfrcol=1 -Djava.compiler=jitc'). Running with DE (DirectExecution) enabled -- which is the default mode -- causes the sequence of methodentry/exits that we receive from the java application to be incorrect. Seedocumentation bug 59831 for details. (I was able to reproduce this bug whenrunning in the default mode with DE enabled, but the problem disappeared when Iswitched to pure-jit mode.) (Note, if running in one of these modes, you still may end up seeing anunacceptably large overhead from the profiler -- e.g., the cumulative timereported by the profiler for the main method may be larger than the timereported by the program itself. There is a bug already open for this issue --bug 54381) As of TPTP 4.6.0, TPTP is in maintenance mode and focusing on improving quality by resolving relevant enhancements/defects and increasing test coverage through test creation, automation, Build Verification Tests (BVTs), and expanded run-time execution. 49141	command line processing needs improvements	"Previously there was some amount of command line consumption caused by code from update.   Things like -noupdate, -feature, etc were consumed by the main() or Platform.startup().  As a result, they were not passed on to applications (like AntRunner).With the extraction of the update (and other) code from the startup sequence, the consumption of these args has stopped.  As a result, the args are showing up on the app command line.  Apps like AntRunner are somewhat confused.There are other args we are consuming that we probably should stop.  This iwll make the problem worse.  Unfortunately, there are parts of the system which need configuration but are neither part of the runtime or part of the appliation (e.g., update).  How do we pass args to them?Certainly the system property approach is workable but it is less than optimal for the userAnother option is to allow arg consumers to signal the runtime that they have consumed the argument.  This works as well but a) requires extra api/structure b) is prone to error on the part of the consumers c) does not solve the problem of arg collisions (e.g., what if AntRunner had a -application switch?)d) has a race condition in that the args must be setup before the app is runThoughts and comments welcome. In the new re-work of the startup code, Update Manager will not need command line arguments (other than the -force/freeze argument we discussed to lock a configuration). I will update the bug once I get back from vacation and get some work done. Great.  When you get back, we should consider if the force/freeze function should be controlled by a command line arg or if it is essentially a utility that someone runs on a config to freeze it.  I.e, would you expect people to be running with -freeze all the time or just one time?  Thanks Can we pick this up and decide what we need? Here is my proposal:a). do not support any command line arg for controlling ""freeze""/""cascade""b). there are two scenarios    1. shared install with read-only install directory: when a user launches        eclipse in his own account, we automatically create a new configuration       directory.        - if the user configuration directory already exists and populated with        appropriate files, just use it.       - If the shared install directory does not have a configuration       dir, then we create the full content of the configuration dir       (by picking up all the features/plugins available).       - If there is a shared configuration, then the configuration created       for each user will ""cascade"" it, by linking to the shared config info.       So, the user config will initially consist of just one link that will       be processed and the configuration initialized from the shared location       and treated as ""read-only"", i.e. no installs/updates/enable/disable are       allowed on features from the shared config.       The user can still install new features under his own directories, and       this info will be added to the local config.      2. shared or local install, but with -configuration:       Apply the same algorithm as above, where the shared location is considered to be the eclipse installation, and the user location is what -configuration points to. This seems reasonable except it does not allow someone to freeze their configuration and isolate it from updates to the shared install.  I like the idea of NOT using a command line arg but there should be some ability to basically collapse the cascade into the users area. That looks like an advance feature, and the user can simply do it by copying the configuration himself. I am not sure a raw copy of the configuration is going to work - the URLs may be relative to the original location and may need to be expanded/modified.  I think a raw copy of the configuration should work. All sites within an install would have to be saved with platform:/base/some_path/. The other paths will be saved absolutely. The only issues is if some file systems are mounted with different paths in root and user's accounts, but in that case our code won't be able to do a better job either. BTW, we may need to revisit the proposal for variable substitution in site paths (I think it was Mel who was willing to provide the code). Command line processing has been rationalized and cleaned up.  We have not done any variable substitution and likely will not for 3.0. "	2010-04-16 21:21:03	1271470000.0	resolved fixed	7205c74	1271790000.0	java/javax/mail/internet/MimeMessage.java

49075	Coolbars not colapsing rows after a resize.	"Open the workbench and switch to the java perspectivemake the workbench window really small, forcing there to be a four (4) row toolbarthen resize the window large againNote that there still are 4 rows in the toolbar when they could have beencollapsed back to one.  This is painful because moving all the little toolitemgroups back takes timeNote2, this also happens on GTK as well as MOTIF On Linux and MacOS, the cool bar widget in SWT is emmulated as apposed to native in windows. This creates inconsistancies in the two types of widgets. On resize events, the windows native widget maintains state information when items are forced to new lines. When the window is resized back to normal, the cool items flow back to their original order(jump rows). In Linux (GTK and Motif) and MacOS, the cool bar introduces ""hard"" breaks when the cool items are forced to a new row. Becasue of this behaviour it is impossible to distigusish between user breaks and forced wrapping. This bug needs to be fixed at the SWT level, this is related to bug 25336 this is a dup of  Bug19654.*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 19654 *** "	2010-04-08 18:15:55	1270760000.0	resolved fixed	e59ba8f	1270810000.0	java/org/apache/catalina/realm/JNDIRealm.java

48983	Replace With... should not attempt replace with non existing version	Build 2003121620001. Check out version v20031215 of org.eclipse.jdt.ui.tests and org.eclipse.jdt.ui.tests.refactoring2. Select both project3. Replace With...->Another Branch or Version...4. Select version v200312161200Observe: After the replacing has complete, org.eclipse.jdt.ui.tests.refactoring is empty. This is because there is no version v200312161200 for this project. Welcome to CVS. There is no easy to find out if a 'project', and I use the term loosely because CVS has no concept of one, is part of a particular version. Files are tagged and as far as a client knows, anyone of the files in the project could be tagged. However, we may be able to implement the behaviour you expected, and make our client a bit nicer, by checking-out into our remote cache first, then if there are contents swap them with the real project. Of course I don't know anything about the CVS support, but don't you already have the tags cached locally for each project (if the user used 'Refresh from Repository' in the 'Replace with Branch or Version' dialog)? 48729	Support of implicit properties	Right now we have to create a content pane for JFrame.  This requires us constructing it, when we should use the existing one.  This causes problems if people subclass JFrame and put their own. We need to code gen this the call to the owning JavaBean (for implicit properties), e.g.getContentPane(){   if(contentPane == null){      contentPane = getJFrame().getContentPane();      contentPane.setLayout(new GridBagLayout());   }   return contentPane();}Also, for the property sheet if the user expands a property that is not set (i.e. implicit) and sets a sub-property we don't cope with this properly - we null construct the property to be able to apply the subproperty as right now we code generate bad code if there isn't a default constructor available for the intermediate property. *** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 48552 *** M1 released, move all resolved to Verified, as prelude to closing. 48371	$ws$ etc not processed for classpath entries	It appears that the current code does not handle $ws$ entries on the classpath of bundles.  I thought that we did this work.  It works for native libs etc.  This is needed for SWT scenarios.In the SWT case it is possible to have several SWTs installed at the same time.  Of course, when you run, only one should be selected.  The SWT plugin in Eclipse classic has $ws$/swt.jar on the classpath.  The plugin itself never contains that jar, it always comes from fragments by processing the $ws$ directive while searching for the jar.Without this capability the swt.jars from Motif and GTK will both get added to SWT's classpath (or just the first one found).  Both situations are less than optimal. 48647	add an external class path to project	"My runtime system requires some configuration files in the class path.Those paths are not in the project/source-scope/directory.Neither the configuration files nor the project can be moved.I would like to add an extternal class path to my project (not to eclipse),but this is not possible!?best regardsThorsten van Ellen JDT/Debug provides the launch support. YOu can add external folders and archives to the classpath. Use the  ""Advanced"" button on the Classpath tab of a Java Application launch configuration. This will open a dialog, where you can select to add an external folder. Oh, yes, you are right! You'll have to take the command Run... from the Run menu ortake the command Run... from the icon with the running man on the icon bar.Then you'll have to select the tab named Classpath,deselect ""use default classpath"",select the ""advanced"" button,select add external folder andselect your additional classpath.(a bit complicated but perhaps it is the most flexible way at that point.)best regardsThorsten van Ellen "	2010-01-31 16:28:21	1264970000.0	resolved fixed	7aa1206	1265120000.0	java/org/apache/catalina/filters/RemoteIpFilter.java

48421	Need to open-up the plugin converter	"The idea here is something simple.  When calling the converter we would allow people to express, for example, classpath entries contained in host bundles (if generating for a fragment) or jars present in fragments (if generating for a host).  We do not want the converter to get into grovelling over some sort of plugin registry style structure to discover ""the big picture"".  It needs to be told the information and it will use what it is told. It could also be interesting to have a flag saying is we want to generate the legacy flags and things like that.The generated manifests also need to contain information like provider, plugin-name, etc.Depending on the story adopted for the translation of manifests, some extra generation might be required here. This has been fixed. The converter now supports a flag indicating if legacyheaders should be created or not. This seems to suit Wassim's needs. As of today the plugin converter generates manifest one by one ignoring all other bundles. This has a limitation for bundles that do not have their own jars like SWT.The idea in opening the converter is to give capabilities to PDE (who has the global view of the system) to say what to generates for those cases. "	2009-12-20 14:45:51	1261340000.0	resolved fixed	eeb017a	1263320000.0	java/org/apache/juli/ClassLoaderLogManager.java java/org/apache/juli/logging/LogFactory.java

Since bug 47339 fix, compiler does not report missing problems in overriding method which has a @see reference to a superclass or interface corresponding method.Unfortunately test to report problems was misplaced and have this wrong side effect... Remember - our patterns are generic and not bound to plugin/id composition.  Youcan currently use path segments in pattern bindings, although such patterndefinitions would be specific to help applications.  In the UI components we'vetaken the pattern of using the plugin ID followed by a  '/' and then followed bythe local component ID in our matching tests.  You could do the same, replacinglocal component id with the path segment.  Can you give this a try and tell meif this solution is adequate?  If so I'll mark this as WORKSFORME. Since patterns can be regular expressions - no limit on number of ""/""s, and pattern binding allow associating multiple patterns to activity, the functionality is good enough. I ""kill"" all its child-threads by force, but I was not able to kill its mainthread.4. The remote computer done its reboot, and Eclipse threads got killedautomatically.5. I re-open Eclipse and the project,  and I found all my bookmarks and tasksdisappeared...  (All other settings, like short-cut keys, are working fine)this is TOO bad because there were more than 50 of them over there... I'mreading the source code written by another guy, and those bookmarks are reallyimportant to me. Is it possible to restore them?Can anyone help? Big thanks in advance! Bookmarks, tasks and problems are all types of markers. In general markers aresaved at 2 points in time, when the workbench is exited and during a snapshot.Snapshots occur:- after a specified period of time (configured by Window -> Prefrences ->Workbench -> Workspace save interval)- after a specific number of workspace operations (this is internal)- after a particularly ""important"" workspace operation (e.g. when a project isfirst created, etc)When you restarted Eclipse, you should have had the bookmarks from your lastsave/snapshot. Is there any information in your log file(/workspace/.metadata/.log) that would indicate why you don't have any? <Pyinson Data Over Head> Neither of those stack traces are related - one is due to a missing file in thePHP  SQL plug-in. The other is due to open editors whose input has been deletedsince the last session (or input that is not accessible due to an unavailablefile system). Can you zip up your entire log file and attach it (use the ""createnew attachment"" link near the top of the page). Thus, I'm adding it to bugzilla.public void myMethod(){    boolean performOK = false;    [some opertations that never modify performOk (no write access to performOk)]    if(performOK && .....)    {        // this code will be unreachable         // jdt compile can recognize this but doesn't in 2.1.2    }} As per JLS, this code cannot be flagged as unreachable. 48370	fragments not searched for classpath entries	In DefaultClassLoader.getClasspath() we are looking for a file to match a given classpath entry.  Currently we only look in the bundle itself, we never consider fragments of the bundle.  This makes the following interesting usecase impossibleBundle A manifest.mfBundle-Classpath: foo.jarBundle B manifest.mfBundle-Host: BundleAwhere bundle A does NOT contain foo.jar and bundle B DOES contain foo.jar I checked in a fix into HEAD.  The currently attached fragments are searched if the classpath entry can not be found in the host.  If few issues with this approach.1.  Any fragments attached after the fact (after the classloader has been created) will not be searched for host classpath entries.  This would force the host to reload so that the classloader could be flushed and re-created.2.  If the fragment happens to include the foo.jar on its classpath as well then the entry for foo.jar will be included twice in the search list for the host.  Once because of the host's classpath and once because of the fragment's.The first issue is probably just a limitation.  The second issue can be resolved by checking for duplicate entries in the search path. 	2009-12-10 17:24:23	1260480000.0	resolved fixed	9be399f	1260530000.0	modules/bayeux/java/org/apache/tomcat/bayeux/request/PublishRequest.java
48324	Rich client improvement	Hello,I would suggest the following improvement for the rich client feature. The principle could be very similar to a web browser. 48289	Support for multiple JDK levels of BeanInfos	The current level of BeanInfo in the VE is JDK 1.3 and the VE allows other JDK levels in the remote VM (e.g. JDK 1.4) but the property values, events, and layout managers in the IDE are reflective of the JDK 1.3 BeanInfo level only.An example of this is the 'rollover' property on a javax.swing.JToolBar. Olivier, can you comment? just to bring in my suggestion from Bug 48010. The options that state ""blank line before method/variable declaration"" should possibly be changed to ""blank line between method/variable declaration"" because the option ""blank lines before a declaration of some kind"" takes care of the number of spaces at the top of the class. I will investigate how to do this without adding too many options. So basically I should change existing settings to be called ""between"" instead of ""before"" for the field, member and methods.In this case, I should add a new option to insert blank lines at the beginning of the type body.Could this solve your problem? +1 I would agree with comment 6.. although I suspect there may not be a need for the new option as I would imagine everyone would set the number of blank lines at the beginning of the type body to 0. I may be wrong! I prefer to keep some flexibility. In this case, the default value would be 0 and it could be changed if necessary.I am investigating.Silvio, I let you know what the new option name will be. I am not sure the renaming is necessary. We can keep existing name and simplyadd a new option to insert blank lines before the first body declarations. Thereason why I don't like too much the renaming in ""between"" is that it impliesthat new lines are inserted only between body declarations of the same type(between fields means that a new line is inserted only between two fields).Any comment?I am working on adding the new option, but I need some feedback to know the wayI should change the existing options. you can keep the names the same but somehow make it clear that the new option will override any other whitespace at the top of a type + of course make sure that the option does override it! or you can rename the other options to ""blank line before method/variable declaration except if declared at top of a type"" I think this is a little bit too long.Silvio, let me know the way you want to rename options or leave them as is.On my side, I will add the new option and send you a patch to update the UI. 48252	"Difficulty creating ""swt-like"" fragment"	"eclipse-SDK-I20031202-win32I created a fragment in M5 that replaces some functionality in an existing plugin.  I did this by:1. modifying the plugin's plugin.xml to include an additional runtime jar ""replace.jar"" (first in the list of jars)2. creating a fragment that contained:a. replace.jar (this is not window system specific so is just in the root directory of the fragment)b. a fragment.xml that imported the necessary plug-ins to make replace.jar run correctly.  There is no runtime declaration for replace.jarIn M5 (pre-osgi) the previous steps worked successfully.  The plugin is augmented with both replace.jar and the additional imports.In the first osgi build, I appear to be failing.  I say ""appear"" because my pre-osgi debugging steps are not available so I could be making a trivial pilot error.  First failure: check to see if the fragment is installed (not shown in current configuration details - e.g., cannot see swt fragment).  bug 46494 makes me believe that this should work.bug 43658 discusses how swt works, however, I see manifest files in the swt plug-in and fragment so there may be additional steps I need to do (but did not see any requirement for additional steps in the porting guide).Please advise.  We need to be able to do something like this (target: M6).  Given that swt works, I hypothesize that I am either missing some required step or just pilot error. The plugin conversion mechanism is not capable of generating the correct manifest.mf for plugins/fragments which do not contain their own code.  When the converter runs it analyzes the jars and determines what packages would be provided to people via the <library> tags and the export attribute.  In your (and the SWT) case the library statement is in the plugin but the jar is in the fragment.  Since the converter works on a bundle by bundle basis, when converting the plugin.xml it does not have global knowledge of the fragments available and cannot locate the jar in question.  Similarly, when converting the fragment.xml there is no library statement so there is nothing to generate.Net result: the Provide-Package list is likely empty in both cases.The porting guide does not mention this case.  The PDE conversion tool can do a better job of generating the manifests since it does have the global knowledge required to locate the jars etc.  A stub/reminder has been added to the porting guide and will be completed this week.In the meantime the easiest thing to do is to copy the jar from the fragment to the plugin and then generate the manifest using the PDE tool.  This will get you a plugin that says it provides all the relevant packages.  Then delete the jar from the plugin.  I don't think you will have to generate the fragment manifest manually.BTW, the configuration details issue is being worked on. To see what is installed, start with -console and then type ""ss"" in the console.  That will list all the bundles and their state.  You want to see RESOLVED or ACTIVE. This bug has been partially fixed by bug #48370 and bug #48371. Fixes are available in build after I20031209.The manifest generation problem will be fixed with #48421, although the on-the-fly generation is unlikely to be supported due to restriction captured in the PR.Closing.
