48230	pde.core does not compile	"Build: N-20031206Note; This build is unusable for many reasons, but that is not the issue here.1. Use I-20031203 as development platform, and N-20031206 as target platform.2. Launch on a new workspace.3. Check out pde.core from CVS.You will see that pde.core does not compile anymore, even though its manifest does contain the dependency on org.eclipse.core.runtime.compatibility.Not sure if it's a problem with Equinox restructuring or the JDT compiler.cc Philippe.Here is the compilation error, which did not occur when compiling against previous Equinox builds.The type org.eclipse.osgi.service.environment.Constants cannot be resolved. It is indirectly referenced from required .class files.	TargetPlatform.java	org.eclipse.pde.core/src/org/eclipse/pde/internal/core	line 0	December 7, 2003 10:39:31 AM Wassim: does it work better if you manually add org.eclipse.core.runtime.compatibility on the build path ? If I import org.eclipse.core.runtime.compatibility and all its prereqs into my workspace, the classpath container of pde.core adapts and puts the project org.eclipse.core.runtime.compatibility on its classpath.  A rebuild kicks in.  However, the compilation error remains. The problem is definitely in Platform/Core land.org.eclipse.core.boot.BootLoader in the org.eclipse.core.runtime.compatibility plug-in implements the org.eclipse.osgi.service.environment.constants.Constants interface.This interface comes from the org.eclipse.osgi plug-in.  However, it is in the eclipseAdaptor.jar, and this jar is not exported by the org.eclipse.osgi plug-in.  So it was not put on the classpath of pde.core.The reason why this problem probably went unnoticed by the Core team is because they have all their osgi plug-ins as source in their workspace.  Since all source folders of a Java project are exported (i.e. there is no current support for ""not"" exporting a source folder), everything compiled fine.  However, when we are dealing with JARs, the problem was easily exposed. Glad to hear this.  I am suspicious of the repreq computation.  I have all the runtime projects in my workspace (checked out from CVS) and then loaded pde.core from CVS.  I am targetting N1207.I get a similar but different compile error (specifically     The type org.eclipse.update.configurator.IPlatformConfiguration$ISitePolicy cannot be resolved. It is indirectly referenced from required .class files.	TargetPlatform.java	org.eclipse.pde.core/src/org/eclipse/pde/internal/core	line 0The classpath for pde.core has only the JRE and Required plugin containers.  Expanding the required plugin container you see Ant, resources, ... and the only runtime related entry is for the runtime.compatibility project.It should have     org.eclipse.core.runtime.compatibility    org.eclipse.core.runtime    org.eclipse.osgi    org.eclipse.update.configuratorand perhaps even     org.eclipse.osgi.utilHaving said that it is not clear there is enough information for PDE to have figured this out.  Does PDE populate its model based on manifests or plugin.xmls?  The plugin.xml has the above list explicitly.  The manifests are more subtle.The runtime.compatibility manifest includesRequire-Bundle:  org.eclipse.core.runtime; provide-packages=true,so core.runtime should be there.It also includes the entryImport-Package:  org.eclipse.update.configurator,While this does not say that compatibility absolutely requires the update.confgiruator plugin, it does say that it needs a package called org.eclpise.update.configurator.  You and I know that that package is in the similarly named plugin but how does PDE?  There are two ways.  The real way is for PDE to use the same state/resolver objects that the runtime uses to do the dependency computations for the target.  This would allow it to discover all the prereqs for a particuler plugin regardless of whether the prereq came via a Require-Bundle or an Import-Package.  The only flaw in this is that OSGi allows for cirularities and we do not seem to be happy with that.The other, somewhat temporary and much lower tech way is via the build.properties file.  The build.properties for runtime.compatibility lists    extra.prerequisites = org.eclipse.update.configuratorPDE build currently uses this to figure out basically the same thing that PDE core needs.  Ideally both would use the first approach but we have not had time to port.  If cycles become an issue we may well need some sort of side mechanism like this for disambiguating cases.  In PDE core is it not too bad since JDT actually allows cycles.  It gets more difficult with PDE build since building with cycles and Ant will be harder.Note that it looks to me like the build.properties for runtime is missing the line    extra.prerequisites = org.eclipse.osgi,org.eclpise.utilI say ""looks like"" because the manifest has imports a mess of packages from thees two but there is no explicit prereq statement (either in the manifest or in the build.properties).  PDE build is still based on plugin.xmls and the runtime plugin.xml still lists these two as plugin prerequisites.Summary:  There are several problems.  - PDE Core should be seeing compatibility's dependency (and reexporting) of runtime. (check that you are looking for the ""provide-packages"" attribute correctly)- PDE Core needs to use one of the two ways defined above to find Import-Package dependencies (preferrably by using the real dependency computation)- PDE Build needs to get on the real dependency computatoin- We need to delete our plugin.xmls.  They are just confusing things- The use of extra.prerequisites needs to either be consisent and correct or stopped.Re comment #3, what does it mean to export a jar? I'm a little more awake and while the bulk of comment #5 stands, I understand more now what is happening.  org.eclipse.osgi is not really an OSGi bundle.  It IS OSGi so in the same way that org.eclipse.core.boot is not a plugin, org.eclipse.osgi is not a bundle.  In OSGi terms it is ""the system bundle"" or ""bundle 0"".We have put a plugin.xml in there to make it look like a plugin to the tooling.  To make matters a little worse, the manifest for org.eclipse.osgi is not a MANIFEST.MF.  It is actually in a file called SYSTEMBUNDLE.MF in the META-INF dir of the framework/src dir.  To add to that, the framework is open such that implementations can effectively add manifest entries through ADAPTOR.MF files.I know that the ADAPTOR.MF mechanism is not inthe OSGi spec.  It is unclear if the SYSTEMBUNDLE.MF is though.  What we need is a way to describe the contents of the system bundle.  Since there may be different adaptors this is not as easy as putting in a fake MANIFEST.MF (though this would perhaps be an interrim solution) since there is only one of these.I also see what you mean by exporting the jar.  I'll add that to the plugin.xml pending further information.  By the way of explanation, we recently moved the constants class in question in to the eclipseAdaptor.jar so this is why we have not seen this issue before. Jeff, you certainly have a lot to say <g>.  Let me clarify what you saw and why saw it:When you had org.eclipse.core.runtime.compatibility and other core plugins in your workspace, the classpath of pde.core only need to contain a project reference to core.runtime.compatibility.  pde.core's classpath does not need to explicitly have a project reference to the plugin projects that runtime.compatibility, because these plugins are on core.runtime.compatibility's classpath and are reexported, so pde.core's gets visibility to them without explicitly referencing them.When we're dealing with external plug-ins, then all the JARs of core.runtime.compatibility and the imports that it reexports need to be on pde.core's classpath.eclipseAdaptor.jar is not reexported, so org.eclipse.core.runtime.compatibility does not have visibility to the Constants interface, and that is why we have a problem with pde.core not compiling.Reexporting eclipseAdaptor.jar in the plugin.xml of org.eclipse.osgi will certainly me everyone happy. Thanks for the clarification regarding the re-exporting.  That makes sense.  The change to runtime's plugin.xml has been released.It is still unclear though how PDE builds its model in the area of runtime.  Actually, I realize that you use the plugin.xml but what the story be going forward when we don't have a plugin.xml?  The most direct approach would be to spoof a MANIFEST.MF but this has unfortunate side-effects for the OSGi project which can be used in many different ways.Also, what is the PDE current approach and plan for handling Import-Package derived dependencies? To be honest, I haven't looked yet at how classpath is going to be computed in the absence of a plugin.xml.  This is mainly because I haven't heard a definitive decision yet that we are effectively deprecating the plugin.xml.Are you trying to tell me something? No I was not trying to tell you something but yes we are deprecating the plugin.xml and fragment.xml files.  These will be maintained as legacy but 3.0 plugins should use MANIFEST.MF and eclipse.xml (currently called extensions.xml).I'm writing those sections of the porting guide right now... The SYSTEMBUNDLE.MF and ADAPTOR.MF files are not OSGi specified.  They are just an implementation specific way of specifying exported packages for the System Bundle.Do we need to come up with a more general way of specifying the system bundles contents?Currently we define the base System Bundle contents in the /META-INF/SYSTEMBUNDLE.MF file in core.jar and then add to the exported packages and services of the System Bundle by asking the Adaptor with the FrameworkAdaptor.getExportedPackages() and FrameworkAdaptor.getExportedServices() methods.  The default implementation just looks in the file /META-INF/ADAPTOR.MF file to get the values to return for these methods.  This does not help tooling because only the framework can call these methods on the adaptor so you are left with reading the ADAPTOR.MF files yourself.These files are contained with in the jars of the org.eclipse.osgi ""plugin"" so it is not real easy for tools to gain access to them. In I20031209, I tried something.Remove compatibility from pde.core plugin.xmlThen import the plugin with source.The first thing to note is that the build path being used is not a dynamic. The second thing is that this classpath does not contains org.eclipse.core.runtime.compatibility and therefore pde.core does not compile.Then I switched to the ""dynamic classpath"" and everything worked fine: compatibility was added to the classpath.Moving to PDE-UI Pascal, this bug has been resolved at the OSGi end.  I'm not sure what you are observing that is wrong:>The first thing to note is that the build path being used is not a dynamic.I'm assuming that you are talking about the build path of the plug-in you imported.  That is right, by default, dynamic classpaths is not on.  You have to turn it on on the PDE>Java Build path control preference page.  If you had, the classpath of anything you import will be a dynamic classpath. >The second thing is that this classpath does not contains >org.eclipse.core.runtime.compatibility and therefore pde.core does not >compile.You explicitly removed org.eclipse.core.runtime.compatibility from the plugin.xml of pde.core and then you were shocked that this plugin was not added to the classpath of pde.core.  Of course, it is not going to be added.  The classpath does not contain anything for free.  runtime.compatibility has been explicitly declared as a dependency by pde.core in order for it to be added to its classpath.In any event, the bug for which this report was opened was a problem with the reexporting of osgi libraries which has since been fixed by Jeff. 48196	Need to be able to provide an imported package.	Currently the framework does not allow for a bundle to provide a package thatis imported.  This means that a bundle will not be able to provide a package that it also exports if the framework chooses a different package version to make available to the framework from another bundle.The search order for provided packages should be enhanced to include looking in a bundles imports for a package that it provides. 48176	Lock granularity of Team > Actions	While I was commiting a project I wanted to delete another project which was not related with the commit. However I had the windows showing that my workspace was lock.It seems to me that the granularity of the lock is too coarse. Maybe it is the lock on delete, but I just wanted to make sure that you knew about it too. Commit in the sync view uses project level locking but commit run via the context menu in other views uses workspace locking. We haven't converted all of our operations to project locks. This was somewhat intentional. This way we can test the UI responsiveness and backwards compatibility. The fact that you got a dialog was good.Changing the title as a reminder that we may want to convert other operations too. Michael, I think this is fixed? No. Team>Commit and Team>Update still lock the entire workspace. Will address in M9. This was fixed already. 	2009-11-11 08:01:28	1257940000.0	resolved fixed	16c4534	1258500000.0	java/org/apache/catalina/tribes/io/BufferPool.java java/org/apache/jasper/compiler/ServletWriter.java modules/tomcat-lite/java/org/apache/tomcat/util/http/MimeMap.java

48150	Embedding Excel in IEditorPart changes Workbench menus	"Overview/Steps to reproduce :Embed .xls file as OLE document in the IEditorPart. If that editor is opened,the workbench menus are replaced by the .xls menus {Edit, View, Insert, Format,Tools, Data, Help}. Even if the active editor is changed to something else, theoriginal workbench menus do not show up. The only way to get back the workbench menus is to close the editor that has OLEdocument. Expected behavior :When the active editor is say Java Editor, the workbench should show theoriginal set of menus, and not the OLE document specific menus. When the activeeditor is the one embedding the OLE doc, the document specific menus should beshown.Additional Information :	/**	 * @see org.eclipse.ui.IWorkbenchPart#createPartControl(Composite)	 */	public void createPartControl(Composite parent) {		GridLayout layout = new GridLayout();		layout.numColumns = 1;		layout.marginHeight = 0;		layout.marginWidth = 0;		layout.verticalSpacing = 0;		parent.setLayout(layout);		OleFrame oleContainer = new OleFrame(parent, SWT.NONE);		GridData frameGridData = new GridData(GridData.FILL_BOTH);		frameGridData.horizontalAlignment = GridData.FILL;		frameGridData.verticalAlignment = GridData.FILL;		oleContainer.setLayoutData(frameGridData);		oleContainer.setSize(500, 500);		OleClientSite excelSite = new OleClientSite(oleContainer, SWT.BORDER, outputFile);				excelSite.doVerb(OLE.OLEIVERB_PRIMARY);		parent.setSize(parent.getSize());         } VI, not sure if this is OLE or UI. When OleFrame.setFileMenus(new MenuItem[] {fileItem}) is done, the workbenchmenus are not returned even after the Excel editor is closed. There is just the'File' menu and nothing else on the menu bar. Are you really using 2.1.1?  If so, please retry with 2.1.2 - some fixes where made for hangs in Ole in 2.1.2 which may be causing your problem Sorry for the confusion, I am indeed using 2.1.1 with Excel 2002 SP-1, themodified problem statement is explained again here (Note : The followingbehavior is same in SWT 2.1.2 as well) :Case 1:If I open a .csv (comma separated format) file in the Editor along with a texteditor, we can reproduce the problem I have stated in the original bug report.Case 2: If I open a .xls file in the Editor along with a text editor, then the menusfunction properly, though the display process has some flicker.Case 3: (This is a new addition)If I open a .xls, a .csv and a text file, then   (a)  .xls editor has its own Excel specific and Platform menus (appropriate)   (b)  .csv and text editors both have the menus pertaining to text editor.and (c)  the .csv editor becomes uneditable sometimes showing row and columnheaders and sometimes not. How do you open the .csv file - are you writing your own editor or embedding another Ole object?The problem is that you must be very careful about the order in which things become activated.See:https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=17480When an Ole editor is activated or deactivated it changes the menu shown.  Therefore, if you are switching between two Ole editors you must deactivate the one that you are leaving before activating the one you are going to.  The same is true when going between an Ole editor and a non-Ole editor.  You need to deactivate the Ole Editor before you activate the text editor.  The Eclipse Text editor gets it right and the Eclipse OleEditor gets it right - use those as your examples. Got it, thx!I was writing my own editor embedding OleFrame and expected OleFrame to takecare of menus. A gross blunder on my part :(!! But looks like .csv files can be opened in Excel by double clicking inWindowsExplorer, but do not get opened in OleEditor by doubleclicking inResourceNavigator. I can live with that for now... or can open a bug report if you suggest. This will be shorter due to my RSI.Our CVS server is running on an OS X Machine (10.2.6)When checking out a project from CVS on Windows, it is checked out as a Unix project. If you try to perform any CVS actions on the checked out project using Tortoise CVS, you are shown an error message that tells you did. I had typed in the whole message last time but cannot this time (you cannot copy/paste the error message in the dialog -- nice -- they really think of us folk with RSI when designing apps). Problems due to this: Cannot diff (compare) files in Eclipse. Cannot use checked out project with TortoiseCVS.Seen on WinXP and Windows 2000. ""that tells you did"" should be ""that tells you this"" Btw, we are using extssh. Although the problem still appears with open source projects such as Ant and Jetspeed, the compare function in Eclipse works with files in those projects, leading me to believe that the two things are not related. Those projects, when checked out, are also checked out as Unix on Windows.  Update: The issue is *not* with the built-in extssh -- the same thing happens (a Unix checkout is performed on Windows) when using exactly the same ext ssh as TortoiseCVS.When TortoiseCVS is used to checkout the same project, however, it is correctly checked out for Windows. When I check out files on windows, they are checked out in windows format (i.e. CRLF linefeeds). I noticed that the meta files that are saved by Eclispe use Unix line endings (e.g. CVSROOT/Entries). Update: The issue with the diff/compares was completely unrelated. We were running an unsupported version of CVS (1.10). So the problem is the CVS/Entries file. Does this prevent Tortoise from working or does it just give you a warning? I suspect it's the later. Ignoe my last question. I added it after your last post but before I saw it. I suspect you will not have problems as Eclipse will handle either line ending. I suspect Tortoise will as well. Now that we have the compare issue solved, we don't really need to use Tortoise alongside Eclipse. Good to know that it's assigned to be fixed, though. imported: import de.neze.bugreport.eclipse.GeneralConcept.Problem;/** * Feature Missing in Eclispe M5: *  * I like to write code like as noted below, and it seams that eclispe  * handling of ambigouse inner class names is suboptimal during codeassistance. * And the code formater has problems with disambigouated names. * Note: The exampe below is optimzed for shortness and that make it look a  * little bit stupid, but ""real world"" exmples are much longer .. . */public abstract class AssistMyStyle {	public static final class Problem extends Exception {	}	public static final class Item {	}	public static interface Factory {		AssistMyStyle newAssistMyStyle() throws Problem;	}	abstract Item someMethod() throws Problem;}/** * and */interface GeneralConcept {	public static final class Problem extends Exception {	}	public static final class Item {	}	abstract Item anotherMethodWithLongNameToForceCodeformaterToBreakTheLine()		throws Problem;}/** * ... and as a result I have many inner classes with the names * ""Problem"", ""Factory"" or ""Item"". * Now I Use code completation to procduce method stubs and got errors * as note in the method comments below. * I use ""Automatically add import instead of qualified name"" in  * 		Window > Preferences > Java > Editor > Code Assist: */class AssistMyStyleImpl extends AssistMyStyle implements GeneralConcept {	public static final class Factory implements AssistMyStyle.Factory {		public AssistMyStyle newAssistMyStyle() {			return new AssistMyStyleImpl();		}	}	/**	 * <pre>	 * 	Item someMethod() throws Problem {	 *		return null;	 *	}	 * </pre>	 * Implies errors:	 *  [1] The exception type Problem is ambiguous for the method someMethod	 *  [2] The return type Item is ambiguous for the method someMethod	 * I fix this:	 */	AssistMyStyle.Item someMethod() throws AssistMyStyle.Problem {		return null;	}	/**	 * anotherMethodWithLongNameToForceCodeformaterToBreakTheLine()	 * <pre>	 * 	public Item anotherMethodWithLongNameToForceCodeformaterToBreakTheLine()	 *	throws Problem {	 *	// XXX Auto-generated method stub	 *	return null;	 *	}	 * </pre>	 * Implies error:	 * [1] The exception type Problem anotherMethodWithLongNameToForceCodeformaterToBreakTheLine	 * I fix this and used code format (looks ugly!!!!):	 */	public GeneralConcept		.Item anotherMethodWithLongNameToForceCodeformaterToBreakTheLine()		throws GeneralConcept.Problem {		return null;	}}/** * Note: There are more erros not noted here, you have to rewrite this example * to see all my struggles * Suggestion: * [1] In ""Window > Preferences > Java > Editor > Code Assist"" add an *     flag ""Don't import inner classes"" or ""Import only toplevel classes"" *     (and of course implemented it). * [2] Don't break disambigouated names above the line end during code format. * By the way: If you don't like ""my style"" the code generator has still a  * problem becuse it producess buggy code.  * So you may change this feature request to an bug report. *  * Kind regards *  * mle@neze.de **/ Oh - Horror! 48123	Allow apps to specify multiple Shell image icons for different resolutions	"Native windows apps can set both a small and large system icon for their windows (Shells), but SWT (Win32) only allows setting the small icon ""decorations.setImage(Image)"".  The small icon (generally 16x16) is used on the window decoration and the large (generally 32x32) is used for the Alt-Tab task switcher.  Without being able to specify the large icon, the OS is forced to scale the small icon producing a ragged looking image (the Eclipse icon looks fairly rough in the Alt-Tab window).  Other OSs may have similar functionality that this enhancement may benefit, so this is probably not a Win32 specific problem.  SWT developers are currently forced to chose 1 size Shell icon to work for all platform specific purposes.I am recommending the following additions to the Decorations class API.  Included is a potential Win32 implementation.  Implementations of other OSs should be fairly similar and trivial.  This includes the addition of a new ImageProvider interface which allows the application an opportunity to provide the correct size image based on the platform requirements.public class Decorations extends Canvas {    ...    Image lgImage;    static final int DEFAULT_SMALL_ICON_SIZE = 16;    static final int DEFAULT_LARGE_ICON_SIZE = 32;    public void setImages(ImageProvider imageProvider) {        if (imageProvider == null) error(SWT.ERROR_INVALID_ARGUMENT);        // Set the small system icon        int smIconSize = OS.GetSystemMetrics(OS.SM_CXSMICON);        if (smIconSize <= 0) {            smIconSize = DEFAULT_SMALL_ICON_SIZE;        }        Image smIcon = imageProvider.getImage(display, SWT.ICON, smIconSize, smIconSize, -1);        int hSmIcon = 0;        if (smIcon != null) {            if (smIcon.isDisposed() || smIcon.type != SWT.ICON) {                error(SWT.ERROR_INVALID_IMAGE);            }            hSmIcon = smIcon.handle;        }        OS.SendMessage(handle, OS.WM_SETICON, OS.ICON_SMALL, hSmIcon);        this.image = smIcon;        // Set the large system icon        int lgIconSize = OS.GetSystemMetrics(OS.SM_CXICON);        if (lgIconSize <= 0) {            lgIconSize = DEFAULT_LARGE_ICON_SIZE;        }        Image lgIcon = imageProvider.getImage(display, SWT.ICON, lgIconSize, lgIconSize, -1);        int hLgIcon = 0;        if (lgIcon != null) {            if (lgIcon.isDisposed() || lgIcon.type != SWT.ICON) {                error(SWT.ERROR_INVALID_IMAGE);            }            hLgIcon = lgIcon.handle;        }        OS.SendMessage(handle, OS.WM_SETICON, OS.ICON_BIG, hLgIcon);        this.lgImage = lgIcon;    }    public Image[] getImages() {        Image[] images;        if (this.image != null && this.lgImage != null) {            images = new Image[] { this.image, this.lgImage };        } else if (this.image != null) {            images = new Image[] { this.image };        } else if (this.lgImage != null) {            images = new Image[] { this.lgImage };        } else {            images = new Image[0];        }        return images;    }    ...}public interface ImageProvider{    /** This interface should potentially allow a -1 for each of the int    parameters to specify ""any"".  This is probably most useful for the    depth parameter.  */    Image getImage(Device device, int type, int width, int height, int depth);} *** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 22228 *** "	2009-11-04 02:02:40	1257320000.0	resolved fixed	363b79a	1257380000.0	java/org/apache/catalina/startup/WebRuleSet.java
48121	"ZoomManager's ""Page"" settings cause erratic behavior"	"Keep entering 1% in the zoom combo box and you will see that the diagram keeps shrinking a little by little.  This is because the ZoomManager is interpreting that 1% as ""Page,"" and shrinking the diagram accordingly.  And since it's using the Figure's preferred size to calculate the zoom level, and because changing the zoom level changes its preferred size, when you enter 1% the next time, the new minimum zoom is slightly less than earlier. Set a UI multiplier, and you will see a lot more anomalies for this case.  Simply choosing ""Page"" from the drop-down changes the zoom level four times, causing flickers on the screeng. Fixed.  When setting the zoom level to be page, width, or height, the extra space to the right/bottom of the editor is not removed.  Hence, at the ""Page"" setting, you can still have both scrollbars.  We have decided that we are going to leave it like that. Changing status to fixed. "	2009-11-04 01:48:39	1257320000.0	resolved fixed	5d9f68b	1257380000.0	java/org/apache/catalina/startup/TldConfig.java
48120	Zoom Out action is enabled although it doesn't do anything	"1) Make your diagram big enough so that zooming to ""Page"" would require a zoom level that is less than the minimum.  2) Set the zoom level to be the smallest possible from the drop-down combo box.  3) At this point, the zoom out actions will be enabled.4) However, clicking it won't do anything.This is because canZoomOut() -- which invokes getMinZoom() -- takes the ""Page"" zoom setting into account.  However, when getPreviousZoomLevel() is invoked, it just returns the previous setting from the array of zoom levels, and ignores the ""Page"" zoom setting. Fixed.  getMinZoom() does not take the ""Page"" setting into account.  Separated primSetZoom() method -- the range check is done in setZoom(), but not in primSetZoom() -- out of setZoom().  Whenever one of the ""Page"" settings is selected, primSetZoom() is invoked instead of setZoom(). 48104	Expose dialogs for creating classpath entries	This is a request to provide non-internal access to the dialogs used to create classpath entries within the JDT UI. These would be simple dialogs or perhaps even just helper methods (e.g. IClasspathEntry[] showExternalJARDialog(Shell shell)) that could be used to present the user with the same dialogs and return a classpath entry. Specifically, the dialogs that appear by clicking on the following buttons on the Java Build Path properties, Libraries tab:  Add JARs...  Add External JARs...  Add Variable..  Add Library...  Add Class Folder...Exposing these dialogs would allow downstream JDT users to create and edit classpath entries outside of the regular JDT dialogs. For instance, providing a UI to set a server's classpath in an editor.Currently, this is done by duplicating the dialogs. Maintenance of duplicate dialogs is an issue, as well as a usability problem since the dialogs are inevitably different. Martin, can you comment on the impact of making such dialogs API. makes sense to add API here Tim, where do you want to use the dialogs ? 47364	iterator in clone() may provide a copy of arrayList in different order	in org.eclipse.hyades.logging.events:some of the clone() methods uses Iterator to retrieve all the elements. This was OK before since it iterates through a hashMap, which order does not matter. However in CBE 101, it uses ArrayList instead of hashMap. By using a iterator, we have clone a copy of the ArrayList which has elements in different order than the original.This is what stated in the sun javadoc:public Iterator iterator()Returns an iterator over the elements in this collection. There are no guarantees concerning the order in which the elements are returned (unless this collection is an instance of some class that provides a guarantee).Classes affected by this bug:CommonBaseEventImpl.javaExtendedDataElementImpl.java fixes went into hyades cvs streamorg.eclipse.hyades.logging.eventsCommonBaseEventImpl.javaExtendedDataElementImpl.java house keeping As of TPTP 4.6.0, TPTP is in maintenance mode and focusing on improving quality by resolving relevant enhancements/defects and increasing test coverage through test creation, automation, Build Verification Tests (BVTs), and expanded run-time execution. Shouldntthis be done only once per synch run?2) The synchnonization happens from the root - at least the messages indicate assuch. I'm afraid you've posted this bug to the wrong place. This is a bug with theCVS team component, but you've posted it as a bug to Stellation. I'm changingits product classification to platform. In order to implement synchronization with CVS it requires a minimum of two connections to the server. One to get the list of remote files (cvs update) and another to get the revision numbers (cvs status). However there are cases where it may require more connections. The CVS update doesn't go deep on new directories and we may have to discover these.As for the authentication status message, we already have an existing PR about pooling authentication for connections. 47161	NPE occurs sometimes bringing up alignment dialog	<Pyinson Data Over Head> Through debugging this I found that the selection is stale in the AlignmentWindowAction... which sets the selection for all the AlignmentActions when you first bring up the alignment dialog. So let's say you drop 4 components onto the JPanel, bring up the dialog, select 2 of the components (so that one is primary), close the dialog, deselect the 2 components and select the other 2 components, bring up the dialog again (which is now blank), it will try to get the alignment command based on the 2 previous components, which still exist but are no longer selected. Thus it doesn't select an anchor object which later causes a NPE in the policies later on when trying to create an alignment command.The AlignmentWindowAction is listening for selection changes but only updates its selection if the dialog is open. To fix this I changed it update its selection even if the dialog is not open and to update if the selection is an IStructuredSelection and the first element is an EditPart.Rich... please review this to be sure this is correct since this action is always active in the VE. thx... works fine on RC2 0.5.0 is out, so these are now closed. 	2009-05-06 07:20:31	1241610000.0	resolved fixed	aaf7b5d	1253050000.0	java/org/apache/tomcat/util/net/AbstractEndpoint.java java/org/apache/tomcat/util/threads/ResizableExecutor.java

47569	consider listening to start level events to start the application	Currently, we have the application runner as a separate bundle with the higheststart level so when it starts we know that all user bundles are startable beforewe run the application.Another approach would be to use the framework event for start level changes asan indication that it is time to start the application. The benefit of thisapproach is that we could get rid of another bundle/project. it would be great is we could do this.  It feels sort of strange/goofy the way things are now.  Need to verify when the startlevel events are sent out. I have prototyped this and it should work.  Basically the code from ApplicationRunner gets moved to runtime.  The curent runnable gets expanded to include all the code including the lookup and creation of the application extension.  This way the runtime can register the Runnable services immediately (without having to wait for all the configurators to run)EclipseStarter listens for start level events and when the start level reaches the determined point, looks for the Runnable (WITHOUT waiting).  If the service is there then we run it and handle any errors right there.  We wold likely have to throw some unchecked exception out of the runnable since java.lang.Runnable does not have a mechanism for passing back results.  (this could be enhanced by having the framework export some more useful runnable class but not now).If the Runnable service is not registered then we there was some horrible error in the runtime. Sounds like a good idea to me.  I think I have a bug though - according to the spec the Startlevel changed event isn't supposed to be broadcast until all affected bundles have started/stopped.  But that isn't how it's working now - it is setting the startlevel asynchronously so the event can show up before all bundles have started.  I'm working on it now. This has been fixed. The code is now in I20031209. See also bug #43826. 	2009-07-23 13:08:38	1248370000.0	resolved fixed	a9e00d5	1248980000.0	test/org/apache/catalina/connector/TestRequest.java test/org/apache/catalina/startup/TestTomcat.java

Darin, I've implemented a tiny change for XMLElement.getDisplayName().    public String getDisplayName() {		// TODO somehow move into preferences		String DEFAULT_ATTRIBUTES = ""name,"";    	StringBuffer sb = new StringBuffer( getName());    	for( Iterator it = getAttributes().iterator(); it.hasNext(); ) {			XmlAttribute attribute = (XmlAttribute) it.next();			String name = attribute.getName();			if( DEFAULT_ATTRIBUTES.indexOf( name)>-1) {				sb.append( ' ').append( name).append( ""=\"""").append(attribute.getValue()).append( '\""');			}    	}		// return getName();		return sb.toString();    }It does exactly what I wanted but I'd like to hear your comments on this.By the way, I have kind of bad feelings about the current implemntation ofOutlinePreparingHandler and I believe that it can be easily improved. So, generic implementation may take SYSTEMIDfrom xml document, XPath value to match xml element name, list of attributes andformat string. This way it will be much easier to extend and customize Anteditor outline for different XML files (I believe that it should be possible tocreate some generic properties UI for configuring and adding such formatters). 37933	[plan item] Improve file encoding support	"Re: Non-uniform file encodings in the Eclipse PlatformMany worthwhile ideas here. Other comments...1. I assume in the ""basic algorithm"" steps are performed in order listed. Inthat case, steps 2 and 3 must be interchanged. The encoding interpreter mustalways be consulted first. Multiple encodings are possible with the same BOM.The result of (current) step 3 should be final. Otherwise, the BOM test shouldbe ignored unless it is inconsistent with the result of step 4 or 5.2. Encoding must be determined upon save as well as open. This determination mayrequire calling an output encoding interpreter, which you do not have in yourscheme. (Use case: User has an <?xml encoding declaration in an XML file andchanges text of the encoding attribute.) The editor should not be required totrack these changes character-by-character and blast off encoding changenotifications. In fact, the editor may not be aware of encoding at all. (Usecase: Rick Jellife has proposed an encoding declaration that would appear incomments at the beginning of a file.) Instead, an output encoding interpretershould be called at save time. IOW, the ""basic algorithm"" should be applied atsave time, too, using an encoding interpreter that operates on the Unicode textinstead of a byte stream.3. In light of the above, notifying of encoding changes seems of limited value,since may be re-determined at open/save time. Encoding should be discovered whenit is needed. Notification may be counter-productive, leading editors to takeactions they should not be taking, like calling setCharset().4. setEncoding() should be removed and the basic algorithm should be thedescription of how getEncoding() works. setEncoding() is a potential source ofproblems. For example, if setEncoding() is called on an open resource and theresource is then saved and closed, the resource cannot be re-opened successfullyunless the encoding set is remembered. This makes it a resource property, butthere is already a resource property that may contain an encoding and the twomay be in conflict. What is a valid use of setEncoding()?5. It should be possible for an editor to have associated encodinginterpreter(s), so that the user is not forced to set the encoding interpreterand the editor separately. It is highly likely that the user will not be awareof the encoding interpreter feature and will not correctly set it in advance ofhaving encoding problems. In fact, users seem to have problems learning how toset editors associated with extensions, and they already know what an editor is.Likewise, editors should not have to establish their own encoding interpretersprogrammatically.6. What is the use/purpose of isDefaultEncoding()? There may be several""defaults"". If anyone cares that a resource is not using the workspace-levelencoding, they should stop caring.7. Workspace-level, resource-level and interpreter-determined are requirements,but I am not convinced there are use cases to support directory-level encoding,and they do add overhead. If the feature exists, someone may find it useful, ifthat's the threshhold. I'll give a couple high level comments, though not an exhaustive list (just wanted to document some main things first). 1. I agree with Bob's comment that the BOM step should be done first, but my memory of the standards is that step should be final, if there is a BOM. That is, I thought the BOM was definitive. I'm not aware of cases where ""Multiple encodings are possible with the same BOM"". Bob, perhaps you can explain?2. Encoding (interpreters) definitely needs to be associated with content-type, not file extension. That seems to be assumed, understood by everyone, but just wanted to add my voice to the importance of that. 3. While an ""output"" interpreter would also be necessary, I think some token remembering the encoding used during input (or the last output) is required too. For one thing, if a 3 byte BOM (for UTF-8) is detected during read, its only polite to maintain that when written. For a second thing, which does depend on the token being ""kept up to date"" with notifications, it is possible that someone can paste text into a document that ""violates"" the encoding. Some well behaved editors might want to give some warning about that. 4. I might be explicit that the above comment assumes EncodingMemento (my name for the token :) should be associated not only with the IFile/Resouce, but also the IDocument. It is, after all, possible to save/copy a document independently of its original resource. In those cases the encoding token should ride along. 5. Something that seems missing from the spec is the association of IANA encoding names and Java encoding names. I suggest this be provided at a ""base"" level since 1) there's some ambiguities, 2) its dependent on VM and platform, and 3) should be a ""base"" preference that allows users to control that association, when needed. (Most users don't need to do this, but some do, and for those that do, there's no alternative workaround).6. I suspect there's a few well known interpreters that should be included as part of the base support: XML, at least. HTML, JSP, CSS also come to mind. Others?7. The spec also doesn't mention how conflict resolution between interpreters is handled. I suspect that if the ""well known"" ones were included as base support, there'd be little need beyond a warning message in the log file, but if, for example, everyone needs to re-invent an XML interpreter, there'd be plenty of opportunity for conflict and users may desire a choice as to which was used (which would be unfortunate). 8. Also not well covered in the spec is exception handling. From experience, its easy for a file (e.g. an XML file) to specify an encoding but that some character(s) in the file don't actual use that encoding, and a ""MalFormedInput"" exception will be raised. Some mechanism is then needed to allow users and/or client code to ""override"" whatever the ""default"" behavior should be. For example, an editor might want to give the user a choice to ""use default"" or pick another encoding to try. 9. The above point reminds me that in Java 1.4 there's an encoding setting that allows different behavior on encoding errors during input. One option throws an exception, the other substitutes '?' for unreadable characters (well, actually, they say they make an attempt to ""guess"" what the character is, but I'm not sure that's very accurate). The point being that some parallel setting should exist with base Eclipse support, which would then ""pass through"" to the underlying Java support. There's a similar situation with encoding errors on output, but a little worse. Even with 1.3, invalid characters are written as '?' instead of automatically throwing an exception, and some care is needed to handle invalid characters on output. The degree of care, I suggest, should also be ""settable"" by client code.  <Pyinson Data Over Head> Actually, WRT 3b, the determination is trivial enough if you try the translationand it throws. <Pyinson Data Over Head> See bug 3970 for a request to allow configurable line delimeters.If we allow this, it should be supported at the same granularity as the encoding settings (see Kai's comment). A new revision of the improved file encoding proposal has been made availableoff the Platform/Core web page:http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/index.cgi/%7Echeckout%7E/platform-core-home/dev.html#plan_currentComments are welcome and should be made on the Platform/Core development list(platform-core-dev@eclipse.org) or this PR. While I appreciate the desire to simplify usage, I feel the suggested new plan (per-project encodings, with some attempt to discover encodings automatically) is a step backwards from the previous one (per-project, folder, and file encoding settings).First, there are good reasons to have documents with multiple encodings in a single project.  For example, suppose I want to ship a product on Windows, Mac, and UNIX.  I have README or other files with some requirements for non-ASCII characters.  For Windows, I might want to use the Windows variant of Latin-1, CP 1252.  For Mac, I might want to use Mac Roman.  For UNIX, I might use ISO Latin-1.  I might also have Japanese variants in Shift-JIS, Chinese in Big-5, and other Asian variants.  These variants are necessary, because a large number of sites do not have Unicode system locales - many do not even have Unicode locales installed.Second, note that discovering an encoding by reading a file is difficult, and potentially expensive (for files not marked with Unicode BOMs).  How much of a file would one read before deciding one knew the encoding?  What if my README file contained 2K or more of 7-bit ASCII text before a section that contained some symbols, or some accented or Asian characters?Third, the proposal seems to assume that certain file types imply certain encodings - notably, that XML should be in UTF-8.  This is not always the case.  There are times when we want to use Latin-1 or even 7-bit ASCII for XML (using XML character references for all characters outside those ranges), for compatibility with transport mechanisms and older code that cannot handle UTF-8.  As an extreme case, consider sending an XML document through a legacy protocol that is not 8-bit clean. <Pyinson Data Over Head> Created attachment 8384Proposed Contribution to handle encoding based on a file's contentThis zip file contains 7 projects, but only one is the 'primary' one,com.ibm.encoding.resource. I20040304 is the last build I've looked at, so hopeI'm not way behind :) and hope some use can be made of this contribution.Thanks. New file encoding support is now available in the latest builds. This is problematic; for example, when Java source files in the workspace use OS default file encoding while XML files in the workspace use UTF-8 file encoding. The Platform should support non-uniform file encodings. 47389	Use of deprecated API from IActivityManager	IActivityManager.match(String, Set) has been deprecated to be replaced with isMatch(String, Set) Changed all of our calls to IActivityManager.match to IActivityManager.isMatch Please verify. Looks like the UI team has changed their mind on this one if one can tell from the integration build and nightly build compile errors...:-(We will have to adjust (maybe) once the build appears. So now (I20031125) both methods are marked as deprecated.Doug can we please get some direction on this? I have nothing to do with this work -- besides the occasional service as a sounding board.  I committed the fixes yesterday as a favour to Chris McLaren, who was having network difficulties.  I also do the builds now for platform-ui -- which is why my name has been all over this.  However, Chris McLaren and Kim Horne are the ones you want. Chris, Kim: please advise Darin and Jared as to the status of the deprecated API in IActivity and IActivityManager.  Thank you. i beleive kim has already sent information to jared on this. i know she has communicated with konrad already reagarding help's usage.basically, we want clients to be able to get out of the business of worrying about matching patterns and so forth. to find out if an identifier is enabled one uses:getActivityManager().getIdentifier(someidentifier).isEnabled().(ps. the return from getIdentifier is an instance of IIdentifier, a facility which allows you to register for changes against this identifier's enabled state, which is handy..) Fixed up in LaunchConfigurationManager, LaunchConfigurationTreeContentProvider, and BreakpointsViewContentProvider. Please verify, DarinW. Actually... there have been more changes.  Nothing too serious, though.  I'mattaching a patch (to be applied at the top level of org.eclipse.debug.ui) thatshould address it. Created attachment 7035Patch for org.eclipse.debug.ui What plugins do I need from CVS for this patch to compile?Also, what is the reasoning behind the extra level of indirection that's been introduced? Those extra lines of code everywhere we refer to the activity support seem like excessive crud. org.eclipse.ui.workbench should be sufficient.As to the motive...we're trying to keep IWorkbench bloat to a minimum.  Chrismay have further insight... 'excessive crud'.. ahh, i just can't win these days..i agree that getting these support classes is a level of indirection, but in a way its relieving to me in the sense i don't have to battle with anyone on what goes into IWorkbench* etc. (i was told) we want to start using IAdaptable on major workbench interfaces as part of our API evolution strategy. A number of these workbench interfaces, in spite of javadoc recommending otherwise, are implemented by other clients and subsequently adding methods is always a pain. therefore, there two issues contributing to indirection:1. IWorkbenchActivitySupport as the basis to get the activity manager and do other activity related things (which i like)2. the fact that an instance of IWorkbenchActivitySupport is only gained via getAdapter (which i could go either way on) *** Bug 47974 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** (I understand that it's not your call but) I'm inclined to say that if someone implements an interface they're told not to, it's the same as accessing an internal package. They do so at their own risk and should just have to update their code if they get broken. Maybe that's too idealistic. :-)The getAdapter strategy seems wrong to me. It makes the interface smaller at the great expense of API usability. How are clients supposed to know that they can get an IActivityManager from the workbench? Even if it is added to the JavaDoc on the interface (which kind of defeats the purpose of keeping the interface small), a client using code assist will never know that this functionality is available. If everyone followed this practice, code assist would basically be useless. To really find everything that's available on a type, we'd have to open the type in an editor and read the type comments.I've updated our code in the places indicated by Kim's patch. Thanks, Kim. Fixed in LaunchConfigurationManager, LaunchConfigurationTreeContentProvider, BreakpointsViewContentProvider, BreakpointsViewEventHandler, and LaunchAsAction.Please verify, DarinS. You are right in that it is not my call, because if it was I'd change it and break them. (As well as resist all the arguments '..but *I* really need to because blah blah blah..' :)IAdaptable does solve the problem by introducing weak typing, and with it comes some disadvantages like the ones you mentioned. I'm not quite sure how we document what interfaces we support through this mechanism. I'm going to add Nick Edgar to this to throw in his two cents. (IAdaptable is a lot like IUnknown from the COM world. In COM you will often find interfaces simply to enumerate what other interfaces are available. I'm scared at the thought of introducing an IWorkbenchIndex interface to enumerate the interfaces available through IWorkbench.getAdapter) I don't have a problem with adding getActivitySupport() on IWorkbench.When we discussed using IAdaptable, I was really only focussing on the site interfaces (IWorkbenchSite, IWorkbenchPartSite) which tend to grow service interfaces.  The original intent of the site interfaces is that they would allow for an open-ended set of services, but they were never implemented that way (in favour of strong typing).  Unlike IWorkbench, IWorkbenchWindow and IWorkbenchPage, workbench parts (and their sites) tend to get nested.  There are both authorized and unauthorized examples of this in the SDK (e.g. MultiPageEditorSite vs. SearchViewSiteAdapter).  Ideally, this kind of nesting would be supported in an open way.  That is, the multipage editor support could be implemented using public API, and wouldn't require special dispensation to directly implement IEditorPartSite.  But we don't currently have a good story for supporting an open-ended set of services which can be nested. activityManager.isMatch(ext.getId(), disabledActivityIds) is still called in LaunchAsAction in HEAD.  There are also still references to getActivityManager() all over the place...  Nick, What other interfaces are (or are planned) to be available via IWorkbench*Site.getAdapter() for 3.0 (at least from our team..)? I hope I wouldn't be the only 'service interface' using this facility by the time 3.0 ships; it might seem a little out of place.Ideally, for the activities and contexts API I'd like to see this:in IWorkbench:IWorkbenchActivitySupport getWorkbenchActivitySupport();IWorkbenchContextSupport getWorkbenchContextSupport();in IWorkbenchWindow:IWorkbenchWindowContextSupport getWorkbenchWindowContextSupport();in IWorkbenchPage:IWorkbenchPageContextSupport getWorkbenchPageContextSupport();in IWorkbenchPartSite:IWorkbenchPartSiteContextSupport getWorkbenchPartSiteContextSupport();- OR -getAdapter(IWorkbenchPartSiteContextSupport.class) != null;Note that it is the context API's only that appear at the window, page, partsite levels - these provide services for activation of contexts. activity API's only appear at the workbench level (for instance, the method IActivityManager getActivityManager would be in the interface IWorkbenchActivitySupport - something one gets at the workbench level only) Sometimes I forget that updating a Bugzilla report doesn't automatically commit changes to CVS. :-) So with these changes I require HEAD for the ui plugins? Correct. Re comment #21:I don't want to single out activities or contexts as the only service using getAdapter either.  The way I think of it is that the general mechanism is to use getAdapter on the site interfaces, but that we currently provide convenience methods to get our services in a type-safe way.  If the convenience methods could get moved elsewhere, then that would simplify nesting of parts/sites.For the context support methods, is it really necessary to have separate interfaces for each of the different levels?  Could we not have something like:in IWorkbench:IActivitySupport getActivitySupport();IContextSupport getContextSupport();in IWorkbenchWindow:IContextSupport getContextSupport();in IWorkbenchPage:IContextSupport getContextSupport();in IWorkbenchPartSite:IContextSupport getContextSupport();- OR -getAdapter(IContextSupport.class); Verified code changes. 	2009-06-18 03:39:55	1245310000.0	resolved fixed	c768090	1245340000.0	java/org/apache/catalina/ha/session/DeltaManager.java

37929	[Plan Item] Improve UI scalability	"Improve UI scalability. Despite efforts to ensure UI scalability with a large base of available tools, the Eclipse workbench still intimidates many users with long menus, wide toolbars, and lengthy flat lists of preferences. This problem is acute in large Eclipse-based products. The Platform should provide additional ways for controlling workbench clutter, such as further menu and toolbar customizability, distinguishing between novice and advanced functions, supporting different developer roles, and more specific object contributions for particular file types. [Platform UI, Platform Debug, JDT UI] [Theme: User experience] *** Bug 36954 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Hi,   I am glad after reading the Eclipse Project Draft 3.0 plan that in eclipse 3.0 that this bug going to be addressed, but I also want the people who is going to address this bug to provide api's to do the menu and toolbar customization(i.e, allow us to remove unwanted menu items programmatically).If you are just providing the option to customise the menubar,toolbar manually like how you do in customising perspective then it won't be useful because when we want to develop non-ide applications we should not give it to the hand of end user for the customisation rather we should remove the burden of the end user by removing unwanted menu item programmatically.MorPheus MorPheus, a better plan item to track for what you want is: Bug 36967  [RCP] [Plan Item] Enable Eclipse to be used as a rich client platform  I have made some comments on this issue in other bug reports. They focused on specific instances of the scalability/plugin co-existance problem relating to action contributions and help contributions. But the problems are more generic. I mention a possible approach to solving the problem which is based on perspectives that should be able to handle many of the problems. Here are links to the other PRs: bug #36968 and bug #36964. I also commented about how improved action contribution support can help the UIscalability story in bug 36968. Central to the UI scalability problem is that there are various places in the UIwhere too many ""irrelevent"" choices are shown.  Several of these are listed inthe initial comment above:* toolbar / menu actions* preferences pagesPerhaps the ""abstract task"" idea I described in bug 36968 could also be appliedto preferences pages to help group preferences or even to hide them.  One idea:- Suppose we have an option to display preference pages only for abstract tasksthat have been used in a particular session.- Another way would be to have a filtering mechanism that could filter thedefault list of preferences according to the user's preferred set of tasks. Additional issues relevent to UI scalability can be found in bug 36967 (EnableEclipse as a Rich-Client Platform). FYI: A draft proposal for 'Contexts' has been posted to the Platform UI proposals page at:http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/index.cgi/%7Echeckout%7E/platform-ui-home/docs.html.It is expected that contexts will form *part* of the solution to this plan item. Please also look at coolitem ""bloat"".  For example, in 3.0 M3, ""Add CVS Repository"" appears by itself in a coolitem.  that action should have a way of placing itself after the ""New.."" dropdown.  (Or better yet, it should be a new wizard, but that's another topic).In general, toolitems should be grouped by function, not by which plug-in contributed the action. Please consider bug 21652 as a bug this bug depends on because it is also a UI scalability problem. A copy of the posting to platform-ui-dev malinglist to explain why bug 21652 is an UI scalability issue can be found in bug 21652 comment 3:https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=21652#c3 I find the Workbench->Colors, Workbench->Fonts, and Workbench->KeyBindings preference pages lacking in innovation. These pages are not going to scale well for large application.  But, besides scaling, it's unintuitive.If I want to change the colors Internet Explorer uses for web pages, I don't open up the OS control panel and bring up some global list of colors.  I go to the localized preference dialog for that application.  Fonts, colors, and keybindings should be the same way.  Each application (e.g. Java Editor) should show its subset of fonts, colors, and keybindings which apply to it, in the place where the user would most likely expect those settings to be.I am not commenting on the services that are available in the workbench, just on the UI presentation of those services. They should not be directly served up to the user in a single complex UI.The ""Syntax"" tab on the Java Editor preferences page is a great example of what applications should do.  Fonts and keybindings should be done the same way whenever possible. For keybindings, the workbench could provide a reusable preference page which would be scoped to the editor's context.  The other pages would probabaly be up to the client to create so that an editor preview could be shown.thanks. agree - the workbench has added base support for color and font management and overriding and should not force downstream users of this to have to edit their colors in the workbench preferences.this is optional, and you may want to use but it is more likely that you would put your color+font editing in a localized place as mentioned I have to disagree with you Randy.  The initial drive for this color page was infact from our downstream customers who were attempting to reduce the number ofpreference pages they had to ship.  Putting all colour settings in a singleplace seems far more scalable to me than a preference page per app.  And for mepersonally, knowing I can go to one place to change my colors instead ofspelunking through hundreds of preference pages is a relief.Having said this... the place for this page is not under the Workbench page. I'm not sure where the right place is...  Kim, allowing the editor to get rid of its appearance preference page is an unrealistic goal.  How close are you to allowing the Java Editor to delete their appearance preference Tab? <tongue in cheek> Is there to be a global ""Displayed Tab Width"" preference page? print margin column? Show line numbers? </tongue in cheek>The user does not think in terms of ""let me change colors/fonts everywhere"", but instead ""how can I change the Java Editor look&feel""?I actually agree that it is sometimes nice to be able to view all colors in one place.  But, especially with keybindings, there should be a way to filter what I am seeing. Perhaps limit the keybinding to a ""context hierarchy"" (or colors to a specific editor). For example, just show me keybindings for when I am ""Editing Java Source"". Or perhaps even allow plug-ins to *reuse* the entire keybinding preference page under their editor's preferences branch, and have it ""rooted"" at the appropriate context for that editor. You've got a good point - we can't eliminate all of a plugins preference pages. The idea is reduction, not elimination.The colors/fonts page currently can be limited to showing the colors of oneeditor... provided the implementor of that editor puts all of the colors andfonts used by that editor into their own category.  This is the intended use ofcategories.  Carve up the font/color space into reasonable chunks and yet keepthem all in one spot. Categories sound great and they are needed in the keybindings page too.I don't foresee any reductions taking place.  The JDT team would be making a mistake if they removed the color portion of their preference page simply because those settings appear in the global color page. Users will look at the Java Editor page first, especially 2.1 users. See also Bug 58713 (Colors and fonts preferences inconsistent).If you have colors for the Java editor in two places, which takes precedence?Also, if you have 1000 plug-ins installed, each needing their own color settings, putting them all in one big tree or list seems like a very non-scalable solution to me. This will set the newdefault output directory to MyProject/bin. - Create a class, package com.abs.stc, name Hello, in this directory.Now change the source folder to /MyDir/src and the output folder to /MyDir asfollows: - Right click on the project and select Properties->Java Build Path->Source.- click on Allow output folders for source folders. Click on Output folder,(expand the source folder MyProject/MyDir/src if necessary), press Edit, clickon ""Specific Output Folder"" and change it to MyDir. Click OK. - You'll get a message about not being able to nest MyProject/MyDir/src insideMyProject/MyDir. Make this message go away by changing the Default output folderat the bottom of the dialog box from MyProject/bin to MyProject. (This isprobably where this bug should get fixed; it shouldn't let you do this.) - Click OK. You'll get a message box asking if it's OK to remove the oldgenerated sources from the old output folder; click Yes. BOOM! If you're usingEclipse 3.0 or 2.1.1, this will immediately wipe out your source directory.(If you're using 2.1, you get a reprieve; your source directory won't get wipeduntil try to run Hello.java when you get an error about the main class not beingfound.) 46998	Generalize Type: Cancel does not seem to work [refactoring]	200311191. create a selfhosting eclipse workspace that has all plugins as binary except jdt.core from HEAD.2. open CompilationUnitSorter, and select the first parameter from method 'sort'.3. This is consistent with the other wizards/refactorings we have.That the Cancel button doesn't work is my fault. I forgot to tell you that you have to check the progress monitor form time to time if it got canceled. If so the code has to throw an operation cancel exception.So a typical code sequence looks like this.pm.worked('some work');if (pm.isCanceled()) {  // do some clean-up if necessary  throw new OperationCanceledException();}Since your refactoring does some expensive computing outside of searching (searching supports canceling) you should add that code at appropriate places (may be after each CU you processed).If the fix is trivial, please provide a patch for M5 Scanning our code shows that we don't check the pm.isCanceled either. 46991	Failing debug test	I have removed this test from M5, but we need to find out why it fails intermittently.working dir should be the src directory. expected:</buildtest/I-I20031119-200311190010/eclipse-testing/test-eclipse/eclipse/jdt_folder/DebugTests/src> but was:</buildtest/I-I20031119-200311190010/eclipse-testing/test-eclipse/eclipse/jdt_folder/DebugTests> junit.framework.AssertionFailedError: working dir should be the src directory. expected:</buildtest/I-I20031119-200311190010/eclipse-testing/test-eclipse/eclipse/jdt_folder/DebugTests/src> but was:</buildtest/I-I20031119-200311190010/eclipse-testing/test-eclipse/eclipse/jdt_folder/DebugTests>at org.eclipse.jdt.debug.tests.core.WorkingDirectoryTests.testWorkspaceRelativeWorkingDirectory(WorkingDirectoryTests.java:84)at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:39)at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:25)at org.eclipse.jdt.debug.tests.AutomatedSuite$1.run(AutomatedSuite.java:154)at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:534) The next test failed, it didn't fail before. I think it's the same problem, justthat this test is now the first of it's type to be run.working dir should be the src directory.expected:</buildtest/I-I20031119-200311191827/eclipse-testing/test-eclipse/eclipse/jdt_folder/DebugTests/src>butwas:</buildtest/I-I20031119-200311191827/eclipse-testing/test-eclipse/eclipse/jdt_folder/DebugTests>junit.framework.AssertionFailedError: working dir should be the src directory.expected:</buildtest/I-I20031119-200311191827/eclipse-testing/test-eclipse/eclipse/jdt_folder/DebugTests/src>butwas:</buildtest/I-I20031119-200311191827/eclipse-testing/test-eclipse/eclipse/jdt_folder/DebugTests>atorg.eclipse.jdt.debug.tests.core.WorkingDirectoryTests.testAbsoluteWorkingDirectory(WorkingDirectoryTests.java:107)at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:39)atsun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:25)at org.eclipse.jdt.debug.tests.AutomatedSuite$1.run(AutomatedSuite.java:154)at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:534) I tried to debug it, without much luck.My idea was, that may be the new data for the launch configuration is not'really' saved on the file system before the debug target is created from thelaunch configuration.I didn't find anything in the code that can generate this case. But that can bea problem/feature of the filesystem, if there is a delay between when the datais saved and when the data is available to read.We should ask releng. I have removed the working directory tests from M5. The LaunchConfigurationWorkingCopy implementation implements doSave() in arunnable (in this case), which means the saved directory attribute may not bewritten to disk by the time the launch occurs. But, it's not clear that itmatters. Does the working directory for a new launch get initialized from thebits in the configuration file or can it just come from the LaunchConfigurationinstance? The getInfo().getAttribute() calls should get the values from memory(the up-to-date and correct values). If they come from the configuration file ondisk, then we should add synchronization between the doSave0() and the launch()so that we don't launch until the save to disk is finished. Comments? When the launch configuration is written, we clear it from the cache of launch config infos. That means the old info is in the cache until the new one is written. This could be the timing issue.There are two ways for us to remove the info from the cache - see LaunchManager.launchConfigurationChanged(...). This method is called for a local (non-shared) config when the file is written, or when a resource delta indicates a shared config file has changed. The timing on this could be problematic (especically for shared configs).We need to ensure the cache is not accessed while writting a config, to be safe. Perpahs we can synch on it somehow. Darin's comments make sense. Upon further inspection, I see that the runnable doSave() is synchronous, so it's not inherent in our code to cause a timing issue there. I'll look at the cache. Thanks for the comments. I verified that, at least on the Mac platform, the sequence of calls that write the new config and clear the cache are all synchronous. They even occur all in the same thread so there appears no way to request the new config and get it from cache accidently due to any timing issues. The change notification is all occuring after the config has been marked as changed. We could still synch on the cache/file update, but I'm not optimistic that will fix the problem. I still wonder if the file stream is completely written in the underlying system before we read it back in the launch sequence. The input stream stream is closed, but I don't see where the output stream is flushed. That's my next place to poke around. Tracing the doSave() code to the bottom, the platform uses a FileOutputStream towrite the updated launch configuration out to a file. FileOutputStream has noflush() method and the superclass does nothing on flush(). The documentationclaims that all buffered output is written to the file when theFileOutputStream.close() method is called, which is called in the platformimplementation. So, this takes it down a level into the specific JVM platformimplementation. I'll look around a bit, but we may also want to instrument thecode and put the test back in place so that we can verify my theories on thetest machines. For example, I claim that all of the actions and notificationsare synchronous because they happen in the same thread. We could log some outputon a test failure that validates that assumption. Ideas? Deferred Re-opening. All the working directory tests work for me on 3.3Rc4 and should be re-instated in 3.4 Tests pass on XP and Linux. Released old tests. Will watch in the builds... Marking verified. Passing in nightly builds. 	2009-04-08 01:37:54	1239170000.0	resolved fixed	a228c06	1239210000.0	java/org/apache/jk/server/JkCoyoteHandler.java

46986	[ErrorHandling] [RCP] SafeRunnable in JFace opens an error dialog	"The class org.eclipse.jface.util.SafeRunnable opens an error dialog if the runnable it contains throws an exception. There are cases (e.g bug 46960) where an exception in this runnable can happen frequently. I got 137 error dialogs when I was reproducing this problem. Would logging the error be sufficient in this case? Otherwise, some mechanism to avoid poping up multiple dialogs at the same time should be employed. You can suppress this by using ignoreErrors=true in your SafeRunnable. The ""you"" in this case is StructuredViewer/TreeViewer. The SafeRunnable is used by the TreeViewer during label updating (doUpdateItem) and the StructuredViewer (refreshItem). Sorry for not making that clearer in the original description.When an error occurs for a single item, an error dialog is presented. If multiple items have errors, a dialog is presented for each. In the rare case where this happens, you can end up with a lot of dialogs. I don't know if logging is the best alternative since the user would like to know that an error occurred but a single dialog would be sufficient. Would it be possible to accumulate the exceptiuons and prompt the user once. If not, would some other means of error notification be possible. Closing 137 error dialogs takes a while. This is a general problem with SafeRunnables. We have many of them in parts which open dialogs (AbstractPartSelectionTracker, StructuredViewer, etc.). The other option is to write to the log only but this give no user feedback.If we are going to change how this works then we are changing this everywhere.What we might consider (post 3.0) is some sort of error collecting dialog like we currently have for jobs.I am going to mark this asan enhancement and consider it post 3.0 as it would represent a fairly far reaching new feature and we want to minimize functionality changes. Reopening With the change in bug 58845 to not remove failing listeners, this situationcould be made much worse.  I've decided to go ahead and make the default beignoreErrors=true, so we won't get error dialogs for free, but apps can stillreverse this decision if needed.  Core will still log any error in Platform.run. Fixed. We had to back out of this change for 3.0.  See bug 66733 for details.SafeRunnable.ignoreErrors is false by default.Should find some way of routing this to an app-level event handler (somethingakin to WorkbenchAdvisor.eventLoopExeption). Not for 3.1.  Reassigning to Stefan since he has recently become passionateabout this issue <g>. This is not only annoying, it's incorrect. Opening a dialog is part of amethod's contract, and dialogs are not permitted in most places whereSafeRunnable is used. *** Bug 87721 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** See also bug 87721 comment #4:""With the recent changes for bug 49497, the app could configure a different saferunnable runner using SafeRunnable.setRunner(ISafeRunnableRunner).See also JFaceUtil in the workbench.""Susan, is bug 103295 another duplicate of this? (In reply to comment #11)> See also bug 87721 comment #4:> ""With the recent changes for bug 49497, the app could configure a different> safe> runnable runner using SafeRunnable.setRunner(ISafeRunnableRunner).> See also JFaceUtil in the workbench.""Note that by doing this, you can only replace the error dialog with custom behaviour for those cases where SafeRunnable.run() or SafeRunnable.getRunner().run() is used.If subclasses of SafeRunnable are run using other means, e.g. through equinox common's SafeRunner.run() or Platform.run(), the error dialog cannot be replaced.We should fix this for 3.3. >Susan, is bug 103295 another duplicate of this?Not exactly.  The reporter of that bug never responded to the final question, but it would seem that the desire was to be able to set up a SafeRunnable runner that would also work with InternalPlatform.run.  Which I think is what you are saying also in comment #12.  To me, that implies work on the runtime side, to allow a similar way for apps to set up the runnable runners.  JFace can't do this since it is supposed to be independent of the runtime.  I will move bug #103295 to runtime for comment.  I'm not sure what is left ""to-do"" on this bug.  Are we considering setting a different kind of SafeRunnableRunner in the IDE to avoid multiple dialogs? (In reply to comment #13)> To me, that implies work on the runtime side, to allow a similar way for apps> to set up the runnable runners.  JFace can't do this since it is supposed to be> independent of the runtime.  Maybe I'm missing something, but if any runnable runner calls ISafeRunnable.handleException() - btw this is required if you implement ISafeRunnableRunner -, the default implementation in SafeRunnable will open a dialog. To fix this, we need additional API in SafeRunnable so that applications can intercept the exception and do with it what they want. I see...I was distracted by the suggestion to fix the problem by replacing the SafeRunnableRunner.  Using the runner to avoid the problem only works when SafeRunnableRunner is used.Just to make sure I understand the problem.  SafeRunnable is expressly documented as an abstract implementation of ISafeRunnable that opens a message dialog on error.  Implementors have to subclass this to provide the run() behavior, and presumably can implement handleException however they wish.But there are so many built-in uses of SafeRunnable in JFace itself that we need to provide a hook into the handleException behavior that would be set at the SafeRunnable level, ie an exception handler that can be assigned statically to SafeRunnable, and if none is assigned we can revert to the default (message dialog) behavior.  Does that sound about right? Yes this sounds right to me.  Ideally, for RCP applications, there should be just one place e.g. in the WorkbenchAdvisor where they define what happens with unexpected errors.  Remember that the IDE is just another RCP application...This could be another aspect of JFace configured by the Workbench by calling API on Policy.java. Susan, should I just take this bug? sure, it sounds like you have a good grasp from the RCP point of view.I was thinking the new API to set the exception handler would be called in JFaceUtil.initializeJFace(), where the other Policy calls are made.  Note there are calls to SafeRunnable as well (setRunner), so I was leaning toward making the exception handler setter static API on the SafeRunnable class.  The interface itself could be named IExceptionHandler, or perhaps more specifically ISafeRunnableExceptionHandler.  That's where I was headed... SafeRunnable now opens a non-modal dialog, collecting errors if necessary.  This avoids the multiple error dialog case, and will not spin the event loop at inappropriate times.See bug 178906.*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of bug 178906 *** "	2009-04-07 17:14:51	1239140000.0	resolved fixed	f497f12	1239200000.0	java/org/apache/jasper/Constants.java java/org/apache/jasper/compiler/PageInfo.java java/org/apache/jasper/xmlparser/ParserUtils.java
