Created attachment 6034Shows the bogus error requester Øyvind, is it possible for you to provide the source of the method to be inlined. >Øyvind, is it possible for you to provide the source of the method to >be inlined.I managed to create a smaller reproduceable case.Any help?public class Box{	public static void main(String[] args)	{	}	public Object getSerialNumber()	{		return null;	}}import java.util.LinkedList;public class Silly{	private Box[] boxListOrder;	/** load boxlist order if we are an app that saves that sort of thing. */	protected void loadBoxListOrder() 	{		java.util.List list = new LinkedList();			loadIt(list);				}			private void loadIt(java.util.List list) 	{		String[] matches = loadBoxListOrderPrefs();				if (matches!=null)		{			Box[] boxListOrder = new Box[list.size()];					int foundCount = 0;			LoadPrefs : 			for (int m=0; m<matches.length; m++)			{				for (int i = 0; i < list.size(); i++)				{					Box box = ((Box) list.get(i));					if (matches[m].equals(box.getSerialNumber()))					{						boxListOrder[foundCount] = box;						foundCount++;						if (foundCount >= list.size())						{							break LoadPrefs;						}						break;					}				}			}			this.boxListOrder=boxListOrder;		}	}	/**	 * @return	 */	private String[] loadBoxListOrderPrefs()	{		// TODO Auto-generated method stub		return null;	}} Created attachment 6300patch and unit testThe problem was with the LoadPrefs label. Labels are represented in AST asinstances of SimpleName class and there are no bindings associated with labels.Class SourceAnalyzer verifies that method being inlined has no compilationerrors. This verification checked that every SimpleName object has a binding.The patch is attached along with unit test. Fixed released for M4. Thanks Dmitry ! 42643	[Editor Mgmt] Need extension to intercept editor opening	"So far we're committing to addressing the team operations, and issues aroundmaintaining workspace consistency (e.g. if I try to delete the template file fora Tapestry page from the Navigator, Spindle should have the chance to warn methat this may corrupt the page).This issue about editor opening and other editor lifecycle only came up againrecently (this PR notwithstanding) and I'm still working on defining therequirements.  Any input you can give to make the requirements more concretewould be helpful.Here are my current requirements for editor opening.  These are backed up byconcrete scenarios from some of the IBM products (not included here).If you can elaborate on these items based on Spindle scenarios, or if you thinkthere are missing requirements, please comment.Editor lifecycle- pick the most appropriate editor when opening a logical model element  - whether from model-specific view or generic view- pick the most appropriate editor when opening a file  - whether from model-specific view or generic view  - handle case for shared resource (e.g. WSDL file)  - handle case for 1 file : N model elements- consistent and predictable treatment of Open (or double-click) and Open With- consistent and predictable treatment of icons for elements (consistent withdefault editor choice)  - for files, content types are not taken into account for performance reasons- consistent and predictable treatment of both initial case, and case whereeditor is already open- navigation from marker (e.g. in Problems view) to appropriate editor- selecting element within target editor- remembering last choice (for both resources and model elements)- sort order in Open With- treatment of platform default items in Open With > Text Editor, System Editor,In Place Editor, Default Editor  - should only show or enable ones that apply  - Text Editor may not make sense- revealing mapping from logical to physical as needed Here is anothr usecase for interception of editor opening: bug 117746 [EditorMgmt] Editors should be able to treat large files specially (e.g. deny opening huge files) I've released the first cut of the support for custom editor opening strategies to HEAD.  The Open With menu is now populated from an OpenWithInfo created by merging the OpenWithInfo objects obtained from IEditorOpenStrategy objects associated with model providers.  There's a default ResourceOpenWithStrategy associated with the resource model provider, which encapsulates the previous content-type and file association-driven strategy in the IDE. I'm having second thoughts about the current approach, and will rethink this for M5. sorry I haven't been much help. The day job is becoming all consuming and I have not been able to give this or Spindle much thought in the last  6 weeks or so.Geoff No problem Geoff, we have other use cases besides Spindle's that are likely either identical or very similar. The model-provider-driven IEditorOpenStrategy approach did not pan out well, mainly because IEditorOpenStrategy required complete knowledge of all applicable editors, which goes against Eclipse's open-ended philosophy.I'm going to have to back out of this for 3.2. (In reply to comment #19)> The model-provider-driven IEditorOpenStrategy approach did not pan out well,> mainly because IEditorOpenStrategy required complete knowledge of all> applicable editors, which goes against Eclipse's open-ended philosophy.> I'm going to have to back out of this for 3.2.> Sorry to hear that and that I wan't able to contribute. I'm glad though that you were able to experiment with the idea even if the resulting implementation wasn't the right one.Geoff Created attachment 34453Removed code, captured here for posterity's sake. *** Bug 127437 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Bug 127437 has an interesting use case.A workaround is to define an external editor launcher, which can then do whatever it wants with the file.In the editor extension, specify launcher= instead of class=, where the referenced class implements IEditorLauncher.  The IEditorLauncher is given the file system path, which can be mapped back to IResource using ResourcesPlugin.getWorkspace().getRoot().findFilesForLocation(IPath).See also the Javadoc for IWorkspaceRoot.getFileForLocation for why findFilesForLocation is preferred.Note that this workaround interacts poorly with the editor navigation history though (Navigate > Back / Forward). > A workaround is to define an external editor launcher, which can then do> whatever it wants with the file.Thanks for a quick reply!I tried this workaround but like you said there's some nasty problems with navigation related features. Some of the scenarios here can be addressed using the IEditorMatchingStrategy support, which is intended to handle the case where one editor handles multiple files.  E.g. - open File A   - get editor E on files A and B- open File B  - activate existing editor E and show info for BIn the the editor extension for E, you can specify matchingStrategy=""SomeClassImplementingIEditorMatchingStrategy"".When opening file B, the editors' matching strategy gets a chance to say ""I can handle that"".  If the editor also implements IShowEditorInput, it can switch tabs, or whatever, to show whatever is relevant for the second file. Thanks Nick,I've been thinking about using the IEditorMatchingStrategy but can't figure out how it could help solve my issue. WicketEditor is a MultiPageEditorPart which embeds CompilationUnitEditor (or whatever Java editor the user prefers, e.g. aspectj editor) + editors for other related resources (html, properties). Since CompilationUnitEditor is not designed to be embeddable, there's a few features which I haven't been able to enable for embedded CompilationUnitEditor. The users of the plugin could live with that if non-wicket related java files could be opened with ""real"" java editor instead of non-feature complete embedded java editor. So, this issue is currently a blocker for me since I haven't been able to find a satisfactory solution without major drawbacks. I'm implementing a side by side comparison, albeit a quick/rough one. stay tuned I will attach a modified example project containing one each of a TiledEditor, a TabbedMultiEditor and an MPEP implementation.Now, of course I'm just starting to get into MultiEditor but here are a few thingsI've noticed already building the side by side comparison..1) IEditor parts in MultiPageEditor parts are not ""first class"" as far as the WorkbenchPage/EditorManager are concerned. these classes are aware of MultiEditors and so calls like IWorkbenchPage.getActiveEditor() returns the embedded editor part and not  the MultiEditor part (if an embedded was the active, of course). In the MPEP implementation I would get the MPEP back from getActiveEditor() and it would be up to me to determine that its an MPEP, cast, and ask it for the active editor.2) Closing Eclipse almost works right with a MultiEditor. I get the ""Save Resources"" dialog with the MultiEditor *and* any dirty embedded editors in it. In my case that's wrong as the MultiEditor itself has no savable state (I can fix that though). With a MPEP the list would only show the MPEP, saving/not saving embeded editors is not under user control.I expect that many of the ""just works"" features of Eclipse managing Editors would work the same with MultiEditors. If they don't...sounds like a bug!3) Opening multiple embedded editors (genericly) is cleaner (to me) in the MultiEditor than in the MPEP. Currently any action can create a MultiPageEditorInput and call IWorkbenchPage.openEditor(). Doing this in an action with MPEP means I basicly have created my own MultiEditorInput (an input that only my impl of MPEP would understand) and recreate the logic to instantiate the editors that I get for free in MultiEditor. Although, having done all that I get none of the features described in #1 and #2 above.The MPEP implementation was built to duplicate the TabbedMultiEditor. I've noticed some things so far:- how do you create an IEditorPart from an IEditorDescriptor without casting the descriptor to org.eclipse.ui.internal.registry.EditorDescriptor?- As noted above, closing the workbench prompts us only to save the MPEP, there is no choosing from the embedded editors.- can't add the editor label (gradient) shown in the MPEPImpl as CTabItem createItem(Control control) in MPEP is private. 42559	Eclipse 3.0 M3 - can't start Eclipse from the command line	"OS 10.2Eclipse 2.1 could be started from a shell using something like/<....>/Eclipse.app/Contents/MacOS/eclipseIn Eclipse 3.0 M3, Eclipse started this way is not properly initialized and can't be used (no event etc.).Is there any way to workaround this? In order to support SWT on Java 1.4.1 we have to use our own version of /usr/bin/java. This special version is called ""java_swt"" and lives in Eclipse.app/Contents/MacOS/java_swt(you can find more details about java_swt in bug #40003).As a consequence you'll have to specify this VM when launching Eclipse with""Eclipse.app/Contents/MacOS/eclipse"" via the -vm argument:./Eclipse.app/Contents/MacOS/eclipse -vm ./Eclipse.app/Contents/MacOS/java_swt[I consider to make java_swt the default for eclipse]In addition to launching Eclipse via the ""eclipse"" launcher you can now launch Eclipse viajava_swt too. Just use it like /usr/bin/java:./Eclipse.app/Contents/MacOS/java_swt -cp startup.jar org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main -application org.eclipse.ui.workbench -os macosx -ws carbonI will add this information to the SWT MacOS X Readme Did this work for you? This is now working. Thanks,Chris fixed for M4 "	2007-05-31 09:09:05	1180620000.0	resolved fixed	71eccb3	1180650000.0	java/org/apache/catalina/valves/ErrorReportValve.java
39875	[launching] Managing invalid launch configs	When the launch config index is initialized, we toss invalid configs from the index (but leave them in the file system). Examples are:(1) Configs with missing launch config types (due to missing plug-in)(2) Shared Configs which are out of sync with the local file system (remain tossed until refreshed)Exceptions are logged to note the problems. However, the user is never notified of the problems. Should we, and how do we notify the user of these problems? (the problems are noticed by the debug core (non-ui) plug-in). Deferred *** Bug 42709 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Re-opening for 3.0 consideration. Can you tell me how to get rid of the log message on each startup? It alwaysdrags my focus to the log on each startzp since I have to verify that the onlyproblem is the launch config one. Sorry, it's not written on startup but e.g. when I click Run... (but I stillwould like to keep the log clean ;-) Delete the old files in your metadata - org.eclipse.debug.core\.launches\. The folder contains all the lauch config files - delete the ones you want to get rid of.  *** Bug 44449 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Deferred *** Bug 183429 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** reopening Most of the errors logged are from a config being cached, for example the launch history, and does not exist at the next workbench startup (either the project the type belonged to is closed/unavailable, or the config has been deleted). To prevent these errors cluttering up users' log files we toss invalid configs from the the launch manager and launch history at startup without logging the exception.The two cases where exceptions are no longer logged are:1. the launch config type is missing, but the config is valid (will throw an exception the first time the config is touched)2. if the underlying storage of the config does not exits (if the exists() method of a config returns false)An exception will still be thrown in the case something more severe happens, like say the xml for the config is corrupt but the type and underlying storage exist. please verify Curtis W Verified 	2006-06-23 11:15:08	1151080000.0	resolved fixed	0ea4c7c	1179890000.0	java/org/apache/catalina/realm/RealmBase.java

42444	Error building feature; Cannot find plug-in versions	"I have a situation where I am utilizing a third-party plugin (specifically, a WSAD plugin) which I'll call plugin ""A"". I wrote a plugin called ""B"" which uses one of the extensions from ""A"". Plugin ""A"" requires [""org.eclipse.ui"" version=""2.1.0"" match=""equivalent""]. However, I have eclipse 2.1.1 installed in which ""org.eclipse.ui"" is at version ""2.1.1"" and version ""2.1.0"" does not exist. Plugin ""A"" works correctly in my eclipse environment and even my plugin ""B"" works using its extension when running the Runtime Environment. The problem is when I try to build the feature. It spits up a message saying ""Cannot find plug-in: org.eclipse.ui_2.1.0"". Shouldn't this be able to find ""org.eclipse.ui_2.1.1"" since match=""equivalent"" was defined? I've done some more testing and can reproduce the problem with one plugin...(I'm assuming Eclipse 2.1.1)1. Create a new plugin with the ""Default Plug-In Structure""2. Modify the ""org.eclipse.ui"" dependency ""Import Details""3. Change ""Version to match"" to...""2.1.0""4. Change ""Match rule"" to ""Compatible""5. Create a feature project that includes the newly created plugin.6. Try to export/build the feature.You will then notice the error. Is this expected behavior? This behavior is expected.The matching criterias are runtime artefacts allowing flexibility and control on the requirements. If pde buid was applying the same kind of behavior, there would be uncertainties against what a plugin is being compiled.The only work around is to build a target platform (and refers it from the pde preferences) containing all the versions that you need that will match the requirements you have in your plugins. Here is a concrete example where supporting matching rule can be problematic.I'm writing plugin P which specifies ""import org.eclipse.ui 2.1.0 compatible""In my development environment I have org.eclipse.ui 2.2.0 available.In the code of P, I make use of a new API available in 2.2. Everything compile and run fine.Now when I ship my plugin P, nothing prevent it to be run on a 2.1.0 version (according to the matching rules) and so the customer of P will have errors (undefined method or classes) because P makes use of API not available in 2.1.I sounds like if the only case where the matching could used in a safe way is where ""equivalent"" is specified, since service releases are only bug fixes. *** Bug 44674 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** I just want to give my two cents on this. I hit this problem because the pluginI am working on imports another plugin from WSAD. This import has an import toorg.apache.xerces 4.0.5 (compatible).Even though everything is fine for runtime, I am unable to create the build.xmlfile to create my plugin. I found that by removing the src element from thebuild.properties I can at least have the build.xml file generated.The comment about the versions at runtime is true but it is also true in anyother situation. The framework should not preclude the developer from trying towrite code. If you feel strong about it, maybe a warning can be produced in thecase of compatible but not for equivalent. I would have to question why this is expected behavior. I too am extending WSAD plugins. IBM ships WSAD 5.1 with several plugins that have an import to ""org.eclipse.*"" of a version lower than what is installed. For example, an IBM plugin imports org.eclipse.ui_2.1.0 and WSAD is shiped with org.eclipse.ui_2.1.1. My plugin doesn't even use any of the ""org.eclipse.ui"" APIs and doesn't import it, however, I can't build my plugin because of the dependency of a third party plugin? I would agree with Francisco that if ""compatible"" is set, a warning should be displayed. Isn't that the purpose of ""compatible""?, it kind of implies ""risk""?And I guess I kind of agree with the concrete example in that it could be problematic if I were using a higher version API. However, by using this ""compatible/equivalent"" technique, I, the developer, must be aware of the plugin's compatibility and assume responsibility.Unfortunately, IBM didn't provide the plugin versions WSAD was built against. In cases like this where there are good arguments on both sides of a design point, it usually makes sense to allow both to occur.   Can an option be added to allow plugin dependencies at build time to be treated the same as they are at runtime?   The default could remain as it is today, with strict adherence to version numbers, but giving the user the choice would solve this problem I believe.Just to add my 2 cents to the mix, I think that as Eclipse evolves as platform for integration of components potentially built/tested by completely different teams/companies, this situation will come up more and more.   The fact that some component of WSAD was built with version 4.0.7 of a dependency, and another was built with 4.0.13 of that same dependency should not force us to ship both versions just so that extension writers can use the PDE.   Thanks.Jeff Turnham (WSAD Release Team) Since there are good arguments on both sides, a flag allowing flexibility will be added in 3.0. Any chance of fixing this on 2.1.1 stream? It is really frustrating that Icannot get Eclipse to build my plugin for me. From the current Eclipse plan andWSAD's plan, having to wait for the new version seems to be a long wait. The final 2.1.2 build has already happened.This will be fixed for Eclipse 3.0. *** Bug 43072 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** To add the duplicate bug thought to this report (see https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=43072).There is a way to zap Eclipse to allow what you want. I'm aware that 2.1.2 build has already happened but is there any way to resolve this bug in a fix pack to 2.1.2? The bug blocks us from providing a complete solution to our customers.From description to 48317:""We are developing an IBM product that is targeted against Eclipse 2.1.2. Part of this product will require that the end-user will have the ability to deploy a feature. Therefore this is currently a blocking issue for us. Given that we are seeing a 2.1.3 maintenance build of Eclipse start, can we get this plug-in/defect fixed now (we see that many do not want to wait till V3).Even if it is my silly zap, anything that works will get lots of broken scenarios fixed.  I'm fairly sure many are broken that don't even know how to find the patch provided in the other defect, and this frustrates them quite a bit. Investigate for 2.1.3.Recommendation for 2.1.3 is to:1). relax the strict version checking when constructing the build.xml2). make this a preferenceThis also needs to make it into the 3.0 stream.  Two possible fixes:- first: resolve the registry and use the PluginPrerequisiteModel.getResolvedVersion() method which indicates the way matching rule has been resolved. Doing that will prevent the building of the multiple version of the same plugin (not library plugins). Although in matter of number of line this change is small, the semantics impact are wide.-second: change the behavior of AbstractBuildScriptGenerator.getPlugin(String, String) to take into account the matching rule. The matching needs to be done according to the state of the art, which means that the correct plugin need to be searched for. This changes require more code changes (more new lines are being added) but is safer than the first one.In either case a preference will be introduced to enable or disable the perfect matching. Created attachment 7514Patch implementing solution 2 It seems to me that, we do not want to be changing the semantics (or even the timing behavior) of anything in a patch release. I would vote for the second change on that basis. Fixed. Released to 2.1.3 build stream. Will port fix to 3.0 stream. I have verified that the following scenerio does not work in 2.1.2 but does workin the latest 2.1.3 candidate build. (m0225)- create plug-in A version 1.0.1- create plug-in X- X requires A version 1.0 (match=equivalent, match=compatible or no match rule)- File -> Deploy plug-in X (or Create Ant Build File for X's plugin.xml) *** Bug 23599 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 38126 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 64715 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** "	2007-05-17 08:15:53	1179400000.0	resolved fixed	776736f	1179600000.0	java/org/apache/catalina/valves/AccessLogValve.java

42039	JDT package explorer doesn't trigger decoration for java files	"This is with build 200308261317 and earlierI have a plugin which provides a custom lightweight decorator.In plain old navigator view, if I expand a directory with a bunch of files, thedecorations appear as they are calculated if the resources don't already havedecoration.However, in the package explorer, if I expand a package to display source files,my decorator does not get triggered (breakpoint in decorate() never gets hit) toupdate the resources that don't currently have decorations.  Actually - it isonly java files that don't get decorated, other things like gifs/html/etc do getdecorated.  Also, for directories that are not packages, the package explorerdoes do the right thing and updates the decorators. IMO the problem is that you only decorate resources (e.g files and folders) but packages aren't folders and *.java files aren't object of type IFile. *.java files are represented via the type ICompilationUnit and packages are represented via the type IPackageFragement. If you only want to deal with files you can use ""adaptable"" to convert Java specific types into resources.Please reopen if this doesn't help. That did the trick - I added the ""adaptable"" attribute to the decorator extension.  Strange how this used to work in 2.1 without this flag though... 41166	Runtime Arguments improperly passed	"When running a JAVA configuration, if you specify a ""Program Argument"" within quotations, the quotations can be dropped when the arguments are passed to the JRE.  For instance- if you specify an argument ""*"", the main() loop of the target class should receive the a String with the a single asterix as its only character.  Instead, the asterix is interpretted as a UNIX *, and the args[] array will contain every single filename within the home directory.  Conversly, this behavior probably should exist if you simply specified an asterix as a program argument (without the quotes). Launch issue Jared, please investigate. Cannot reproduce. If you create a ""Java Application"" launch config and add ""*"" to the Program Arguments, the main() method is passed the single character '*'. Perhaps I didn't describe properly, but the action Jared describes exactly reproduces the bug.  The issue is that if you intend a ""*"" to be passed to the JVM, instead a '*' will be passed which in turn acts as a UNIX '*'.  It seems like the behavior is that entering ""*"" on the Program Argument text box should cause ""*"" to be passed, not '*'.  Is the intention that \""*\"" needs to be entered into the command line in order to pass ""*"" to the JVM?  This seems non-intuitive. Ah, I see. Yes, I believe it is. This shouldn't be non-intuitive. You have to do the same thing on the commandline. Quotes demark the beginning and end of a single argument. You need to escape quotes to pass in the actual "" character. Here's why it isn't intuitive (nor sensical)-  Supposing you provide a list of arguments to the JVM on the command line; you have every expectation that quoting and escaping work in the conventional sense- bounding a string, or inserting a control characater.  What I (which I don't think is abnormal :) expect will happen with the arguments that I provide in the Eclipse ""Program Arguments"" text field is that they are what WOULD appear on the command-line had I run them that way myself.  Otherwise you get into binds like what if you want a '\' to be passed to the JVM?  from the command line you would pass '\\' and then from eclipse you would pass what?  An escaped-escaped-escape character?  That's not the most practical example, but it should generally illustrate the serious problem with eclipse parsing the tokens that are going to be parsed again by the JVM.brad How would you distinguish between the single argument ""foo bar"" and the two arguments ""foo"" and ""bar""? Won't change. 40820	Installing patch via New Updates search doesn't respect missing optionals	"Problem: Errors are reported when trying to apply a fix in a valid situation. Use Help > SoftwareUpdates > NewUpdates to search for fixes.  It reports that a patch for FtrA is available.  Attempt to install it.  You get an error message saying that the ftrB plugin is not found.What's going on:During an install from a bookmarked site the user is shown the ""optional features"" panel.  Since FtrB isn't installed, that choice is not selected by default.  However, when installing via ""New Updates"", this panel is bypassed, and it seems that the default selections in that case includes FtrB.I have a working demo of this available if needed. Marking as fixed "	2006-10-26 07:52:03	1161860000.0	resolved fixed	a1b1bed	1167780000.0	java/org/apache/catalina/core/JasperListener.java
41074	[RFP44] 4.1.7 Transactions spanning multiple life cycle operations	"There are two main issues here; 1) OSGi currently only supports the install/uninstall/update of one bundle at a time.  There is no inherent ability to do ""what if"" queries to better understand the resolution effects of various changes and there is also no way of guaranteeing the atomicity of modifying a group of bundles as a unit (e.g., what happens when you fail halfway through installing a product consistening of 50 bundles?).2) since all management operations are individual, there is no obvious way of batching BundleEvents.  Currently a BundleEvent is generated for each and every individual change to a bundle (install, start, ...).  This is fine if you only ever have a few bundles.  Eclipse products can have 1000s of plugins/bundles so you can imagine the flurry of events when installing a new function set (for example).  Further, to maintain the extension registry structure (an Eclipse thing) we catch these BundleEvents, update the extensions registry and broadcast more events to registry listeners.   These bundles in turn do potentially costly (high overhead) updates to their internal sturctures (e.g., in the UI they create and destroy views, menu entries, ...).  When a whole product is (un)installed some 500 bundles may be at play.  Having the UI update its internal structures 500 times would be slow and cause visible flicker etc.  Instead, we are hoping for a commit() like action at the framework level that will commit a number of changes to the bundle structure.  In turn, the framework would generate one composite BundleEvent (or some such).In the current prototype there are two different though similar approaches described, the PlatformAdmin service and the Resolver service.  Both allow for the formation of alternative states of the runtime (i.e., set of installed bundles, resolution state, ...) and the committing of an alternative state to become the current/real state.  The main differences revolve around API style and the number of possible alternative states.  The PlatformAdmin service allows for one ""future"" state while the Resolver services allows for any number of alternatives (some of which may never be committed).Under the covers there is some amount of packageadmin-like work to be done on commit.  It is unclear if commit() should be eager or lazy in terms of resolution.  [personal opinion: the Resolver (and perhaps PlatformAdmin) allow for detailed setup/investigation of an alternative state before committing.  As such, there does not appear to be any value in delaying the re-resolution past the commit point].Note: the Resolver is a very preliminary specification of the idea and there is no implementation. I think this feature is needed for M4.  Is there anyway we can mark the feature requests to indicate which milestone they are needed by?  Maybe by using the priority field.  P1 would mark the feature is needed for the next milestone (M3), P2 the next after that (M5) and so on. Good point.  Added milestones to the Equinox product.  Tag bugs as appropriate. Need to capture that in a RFC. Jeff to write RFC see also bug 43913 *** Bug 43913 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** What is the status on the RFC? RFC written.  Ready for submission after a few edits. *** Bug 90965 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Is the RFC for this available somewhere? This is marked P2, but it has seen no activity since July 2006. There is ongoing work in OSGi to consider transactions.  But so far the progress has been slow. This bug hasn't had any activity in quite some time. Maybe the problem got resolved, was a duplicate of something else, or became less pressing for some reason - or maybe it's still relevant but just hasn't been looked at yet.If you have further information on the current state of the bug, please add it. The information can be, for example, that the problem still occurs, that you still want the feature, that more information is needed, or that the bug is (for whatever reason) no longer relevant.--The automated Eclipse Genie. There are no plans to provide this enhancement. "	2006-11-29 05:35:54	1164800000.0	resolved fixed	5f9c18d	1165550000.0	java/org/apache/jasper/compiler/Generator.java

41057	Option to export and import break points at the Breakpoints view	"Please add an option to export and import break points from the break points view. So, it will be possible to share the same advanced breakpoint settings (i.e hit count, enable condition and probably other settings) between developers. Time permitting, for 3.0. We can likely do this in the debug platform by allowing debug models to contribute a breakpoint factory to create mementos for breakpoints and create breakpoints from mementos. This would be, of course, optional, by debug model. Is there are any new on this feature? Darin, maybe you can suggest some approach for easy import/export, so it willhelp somebody else to put it together at least for JDT platform. Sorry, we may not have the resources to do this in the 3.0 timeframe. I think it should be able to be debug model indpendent, since currently breakpoints are persisted using marker support in the platform. We'd just need a way to persist the marker info such that they could be recreated. Can you point out on more details? How external plugin can retrieve breakpointmarkers? Any other pointers to API? Thank you. You can get the breakpoint markers from the breakpointsIBreakpointManager.getBreakpoints()IBreakpoint.getMarker()However, the problem area will be in re-creating the breakpoints. We have code to do this in the breakpoint manager, but it isn't API. I.e. see BreakpointManager.createBreakpoint(IMarker) (private method). Any chance to get this feature implemented/resolved in 3.1 release? Thank you. DJ, is there a public way to persist/recreate a marker in an XML file?  No, there isn't any way to import/export markers yet. Bug 52614 makes thisrequest... Marking as later, depeding on the platform feature to export breakpoints. Darin, wouldn't it be simplier to implement this feature without dependency onproject markers? I actually only interested to export/import conditional breakpoints, so I canshare them between workspaces, so something simple for that would be very, veryhandy. E.g. select group in a breakpoint view and export it to some file, thenimport it maybe even without sticking to the project. This way I should be ableto export even breakpoints assigned to system classes like java.lang.String Sorry to buther you again, but it is almost 1.5 years since I filled thisrequest. Just can't believe there is nothing can't be done about it. Right now Ihave to use more heaviweight things like AspectJ and bugdel fromhttp://www.csg.is.titech.ac.jp/~usui/bugdel/demo/demo5/index.html but reallyprefer to stay with a standard and simple debugger and be able to share thesesettings across the team (which is as far as I know one of the high prioritythemes for Eclipse foundation). New debug groups makes this feature even moreattractive. Anyway, is there are any workaround possible for this? E.g. some quick and dirtyplugin for jdt only that will allow to export and import selected break pointdefinitions to/from external file. The ""quick & dirty"" way would be to find where the marker is persited, and copy that to the appropriate file. (But, I don't know where that is). The file is at<workspace>\.metadata\.plugins\org.eclipse.core.resources\.projects\<projectname>\.markers and it is a binary. I wonder is there is an API or something thatI can use to nicely import/export just selected breakpoint? I really miss thisfeature and woud like to work on it. There is no complete API for this. You'd need to persit the info to re-create an equivalent marker (its attributes, type, resource, etc). Then you'd need to recreate a breakpoint object from the marker (but there is not public API for this). Looking at the problem in more detail, here is the approach I think we should use:* The operation should be integrated with the Import/Export function in the workbench (via the importWizards/exportWizards extension points)* Ideally the ""export"" page would allow you to select the breakpoints to export, and would be seeded with the current selection in the breakpoints view. The ""selection"" viewer on the page would (ideally) mimic the breakpoints view current groupings, and provide checkbox selection for choosing breakpoints to export. However, the checkboxes in the export page represent selection (not enablement).* To persist/restore breakpoints, we should use the IPersistableElement/IElementFactory interface. Currently, we provide element menentos for breakpoints (to restore breakpoints working sets), but the mementos only work if the same marker exists in the workspace. We'd need to improve the mementos to actually persist/restore markers as required. IResources also provide mementos that could be leveraged. Mementos can be saved in XML files via XMLMemento.* The import operation should provide the option to replace all breakpoints or merge (handing duplicates - which would be done by the memento restoration).* We would provide API on the breakpoint manager to create a new breakpoint of a given type (id), which could then be called with #setMarker(...) to restore it. Darin, I believe that from user experience it will be more natural to findexport/import breakpoints actions in ""Breakpoint View"". In general, Wizard is sounds good, even so it seems somehow overcomplicated, butif it will allow to simply click on ""Finish"" after selecting file name forexport and still will export selected breakpoints it will be fine.Also, I'd suggest to have a simple choise on import about what do do withduplicates: skip all, replace all, etc.   By the way, there is another interesting and more powerful approach onimport/export. If breakpoints were stored in some xml or properties file within.settings directory of project (e.g. have some preference if breakpoint ispublic or local/temporary), then you can commit them into version control, soeverybody can see them automatically. Deferred again due to time/resource contraints for 3.1.  This is should be the one of most long living enhancement requests already... :-( *** Bug 93439 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Features to consider* Hook into global import/export wizard* Also have import/export actions in the Breakpoints view context menu* Will not export grouping information (i.e. show as >), since this is view settings (presentation), not raw breakpoint information* Import will attempt to create the breakpoints, merging with existing breakpoints in the workspaceConsidering for 3.2 Suggested approach:Export:* create XML file representing breakpoints  - entry for each breakpoint consists of     - associated resource XML memento     - marker attributes     - marker typeImport* parse XML file, creating markers    - find assoicated resource (Error if does not exist)    - look for potential duplicate marker based on marker attributes       - don't create if already exists    - create associated marker type (Error if does not exist)    - set attributes on marker    - create breakpoint for the marker Darin, that is a great news! thanks for considering this for 3.2I'd like to suggest one thing just in case. 37509	Open Declaration opens class declaration for local variables	"When the cursor is positioned on a local variable representing an object, and ""Open Declaration"" is selected, e.g. from the pop-up menu, Eclipse opens the file where the variable's class is declared. Instead, Eclipse should just jump to the position of the local variable's declaration.When the local variable has a primitive type, nothing whatsoever happens. This is the intended behavior. Currently, we do not have an element representation for local variables (which is what we answer back from codeselect). A text range would be more generic, but less informative for clients (like search references to selection). Forgot to mention that we plan to address this issue for 3.0. *** Bug 37511 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Similarly. If you want your app to run as an Eclipse plugin and be notified of Copy keystrokes then you need to register actions with the workbench, I think based upon the action (ie.- ""copy"" as opposed to hardcoding to Ctrl+C) . 34956	Provide build.xml target to export binary plugin.	"It's been noted that most Eclipse teams still maintain exportplugin.xmlbuild files for building their plugins locally instead of using PDE's generatedbuild.xml file.The only real problem that the build.xml file has is that it dumps the outputinto the input directory. The nice thing about the exportplugin.xml files isthat they build the plugins and output the binary plug-in in a plugin-exportdirectory that is at the same level as the workspace, not inside it.I would gladly change to using PDEs build.xml files if there was a way to getthe same behavior. Either by default or by passing in a property to specifywhere the binary plug-in should be output. PDE now has 'Export' wizard for building plug-ins into the specified target zip file. It leaves no files behind in the workspace. Does this wizard allow me to export all of my source plug-ins to binaryplug-ins located outside the workspace? Can I do it in a close approximationof one click? Using ant, we currently have a single ""master script"" that callsall of our exportplugin scripts. If we switch to using the build.xml files,we'll still want to maintain the master script that calls all scripts toexport all of our source plug-ins at once. Incidentally, does anyone ever want the build.xml files to dump the outputinto their source project? For us, this only clutters our source project withfiles that we don't want to release to CVS and doesn't make a binary projectthat you'd actually want to deploy (it still contains all the source in folders). Give wizard a test ride - it shows you a list of plug-ins you can check to export, so it is close to one click (not exactly one, though). We don't dump into the source project - we build and export into the zip file outside the workspace. Resolving - already addressed using Export wizard. The export wizard doesn't solve our problem. What we want is a way to use PDEto build export a ""binary plugin"" from the source plugins that we develop.The goal here is to allow us to stop using our custom exportplugin.xml filesand use PDE instead. I think my original request may have been a little lessthan what we want. Allowing a property to be passed in to override the outputdirectory would still be good, but I think we really need a new ""exportbinary"" target that does what the exportplugin.xml scripts do now. I'veupdated the bug summary to reflect this. If you prefer, I can open a new bugreport instead.Specifically, build the plugin jars and copy the jars and the appropriatedirectories as specified in the build.properties file (like icons) to createa binary plugin. That's a nice 2.2 line item for us :-). Is this bug still relevant?  The export wizard has been incrementally improving over the past 4 years.  closing as INVALID, please REOPEN if still valid. 40518	Quick diff results vary after reloading	"please move back (as ASSIGNED) to inbox if you don't have time for this. fixed > 20030930 Gerrit change https://git.eclipse.org/r/40518 was merged to [master].Commit: http://git.eclipse.org/c/papyrus/org.eclipse.papyrus.git/commit/?id=0e184d2e01f20e7e38518978e3861b6ac80e8f69 Gerrit change https://git.eclipse.org/r/40518 was merged to [master].Commit: http://git.eclipse.org/c/papyrus/org.eclipse.papyrus.git/commit/?id=0e184d2e01f20e7e38518978e3861b6ac80e8f69 Eclipse 3.0M2Writing a quick diff provider that uses a remote file as reference, it looks like the quick diff view is providing different results after reopening the file. Example:Reference:01: /**02:   * First Line03:   * Second Line04:   */If you delete the ""second line"" (03) then insert a line in front of ""first line"" (02), you get the following result:01: /**02:   *03:   * First Line04:   */02 and 03 will now be highlighted as ""Changed lines"". If you close the file and reopen it, line 02 will be displayed as ""Added line"" and at the bottom of 03 will be a ""Delete line"" indicator showing 02 and 03 as deleted content. This is a known shortcoming of the incremental diff computation algorithmcurrently used in quick diff. When a file is reloaded, the diff bar isinitialized with the correct diff (i.e. the shortest edit script from thereference document to the actual one), which might differ from the one createdby multiple edits and the incremental diffing.The reason for incremental diffing lies in the fact that a correct diff can onlybe computed by comparing the entire documents, which is in O(n^2), where n isthe maximum number of lines in either of the documents, which cannot be done onevery key stroke.I agree that the situation as it is now is not satisfying. "	2006-09-15 09:13:40	1158330000.0	resolved fixed	fda223a	1158810000.0	java/org/apache/catalina/core/StandardContextValve.java
34399	Wrong build file generated when $os$ variables are specified	"The build file generated for a plugin or a fragment which uses $os$, $ws$, etc. in its library name is bogus.Indeed the variables are not expanded and so instead results in the creation of folders called $os.The solution consists in replacing carefully the appearance of those values into the build.xml.Here is an example of a bogus target:<target name=""$os$/win32.jar"" depends=""init"" unless=""$os$/win32.jar"" description=""Create jar: $os$/win32.jar."">  <property name=""destdir"" value=""${temp.folder}/$os$/win32.jar.bin""/>  <delete dir=""${temp.folder}/$os$/win32.jar.bin""/>  <mkdir dir=""${temp.folder}/$os$/win32.jar.bin""/>  ...</target> Created attachment 4020Fixes the described pb If this is targetted to RC3 please consult with DJ.  Otherwise, fix the code for 2.2. Consider for RC3. yes. but review the code carefully. Released. 38676	can't debug into class if  file/class name identifier  has  _$$_	"I got a problem: _$$_ is legal identifier for class name. Eclipsecan run it properly, but there is problem to debug into it. This is a test case(file name:B_$$_uckets.java).  When put in same package, error message is :""""There is no source file attached to the class file B_$$_uckets.class""When put in difference packages, error message is :""The source of the type 'B__$$__uckets' could not be shown as the type was not found"".Examples:/** * Counters of random values that fall within each interval. */public class B__$$__uckets{    private static final int MAX_BAR_SIZE = 50;    private AlignRight ar = new AlignRight();    /** number of intervals */      private int n;    /** counters per interval */    private int counters[];    /** minimum random value */     private float rMin;    /** maximum random value */     private float rMax;    /** from min to max */          private float width;    /**     * Constructor.     * @param n the number of intervals     */    public B__$$__uckets(int n)    {        this.n = n;        this.counters = new int[n];        clear();    }    /**     * Return the counter value for interval i.     * @param i the value of i     * @return the counter value     */    public int get(int i) { return counters[i]; }    /**     * Set the minimum and maximum random values.     * @param rMin the minimum value     * @param rMax the maximum value     */    public void setLimits(float rMin, float rMax)    {        this.rMin  = rMin;        this.rMax  = rMax;        this.width = (rMax - rMin)/n;    }    /**     * Determine a random value's interval and count it.     * @param r the random value     */    public void put(float r)    {        // Ignore the value if it's out of range.        if ((r < rMin) || (r > rMax)) return;        // Determine its interval and count it.        int i = (int) ((r - rMin)/width);        ++counters[i];    }    /**     * Clear all the interval counters.     */    public void clear()    {        for (int i = 0; i < counters.length; ++i) counters[i] = 0;    }    /**     * Print the counter values as a horizontal bar chart. Scale the     * chart so that the longest bar is MAX_BAR_SIZE.     */    public void print()    {        // Get the longest bar's length.        int maxCount = 0;        for (int i = 0; i < n; ++i) {            maxCount = Math.max(maxCount, counters[i]);        }        // Compute the scaling factor.        float factor = ((float) MAX_BAR_SIZE)/maxCount;        // Loop to print each bar.        for (int i = 0; i < n; ++i) {            int b = counters[i];            // Interval number.            ar.print(i, 2);            ar.print(b, 7);            System.out.print("": "");            // Bar.            int length = Math.round(factor*b);            for (int j = 0; j < length; ++j) System.out.print(""*"");            System.out.println();        }    }}I have tried Jbuilder, which can run/debug fine under exact same situation. Fixed. We were incorrectly assuming that $ could only be used to delimit inner types.Changes in PackageFragmentRootSourceLocation, ArchiveSourceLocation, and DirectorySourceLocation. Added tests to SourceLookupTests, DirectorySourceLookupTests, and ArchiveSourceLookupTests. Please verify, Darin (S). Verified. 39699	Javadoc Taglet option missing [javadoc]	"Since JDK 1.4, javadoc supports the -tag:cm:description argument which provides a nice and simple way of specifying new javadoc tags. http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.4.2/docs/tooldocs/windows/javadoc.html#tagThe use of this cmd line argument is not supported in Eclipse (while theuse of doclets seems to be) and could be easily integrated in the IDE,e.g. as a project preference.This request is fueled by a university course where we teach programming using the contract model - and while the @require and @ensure tags are still being kept as ""future"" tags, we would like to have a simple configurationoption that allows us to generate documentation for the contract model _now_.http://forum.java.sun.com/thread.jsp?forum=41&thread=72830 Martin, can you please comment. Thanks for the pointer. I think we currently have no UI at all for the javadoc1.4 options.Note that you can always use the 'Additional options' field to enter the 1.4command line arguments.I don't know if we find time to add more UI to the wizard, maybe somebody fromthe community would be interesseed to bring the Javadoc wizard up to date? If we introduce taglets, JCore should store them. Problems in Javadoc commentscould then include the taglet rules. Will reconsider post 3.0 In addition to the taghead (to be used for Javadoc export via'-tag tagname:Xaoptcmf:""taghead""' and for rendering in the Javadoc hover), the preferences should also contain an option that tells whether the tag needs a tag description (see bug 222902). As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported.Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you. Reopening, this is still a valid request.
